column2: ROME, Aug. 19 (Reuters) --Romans appear irked at the practice among foreign tourists of cooling their feet in Rome's majestic fountains. Some newspapers, including Il Momento-Sera, have called for police action.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (AP)--"I can't go along with you this trip" was what Gov. Joe Foss of South Dakota told Harold E. Stassen when his help was asked in stopping Vice President Richard M. Nixon's renomination.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 --Mrs. Katherine St. George, parliamentarian for the Republican National Convention, expressed the hope today that women would be received better here than they were at the Democratic convention in Chicago.
DETROIT, Aug. 19 (U.P.)-- For want of two nails a $40,000 model home may be lost.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19-- Politicians have learned that when they deal with Gladys Ellsworth Knowies, a Montana cattle rancher, they cannot safely judge her fighting ability on the basis of her height--"five feet, one-half inch in high heels."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19-- President Eisenhower made plans today to arrive at the Republican National Convention a day earlier than previously scheduled.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 19 (AP)--Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, attacked tonight free trade agreements and called the proposed Organization for Trade Cooperation an attempt to "destroy the United States through internal economic hemorrhage."
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 19 --Mr. and Mrs. J.F. Cavanagh's Night Lilly from Glen Head scored 15 points to win the junior hunter championship during the first junior Brookville ...
Christians who "live strictly by the rules" but do not seek the core of religion can become victims of pride and self-righteousness, the Rev. Arthur Mason Brown declared yesterday.
The New York City Housing Authority's annual report shows that 1955 was a good year for progress, with more new construction begun than in any previous year since 1950.

The Minerals and Chemicals Corporation of America has elected Charles A. Specht as chairman of the executive committee and chief executive officer, James Deshler 2d, board chairman, and Wright W. Gary, president, announced over the week-end.
BREWSTER, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP)--Seventeen cars on a ninetysix-car freight train of the New Haven Railroad were derailed early today.
Martha Raye, one of television's topnotch comediennes, has signed contracts to star in a new revue called "Boffola." The producers of the venture are Harry Rigby and Herbert Jacoby.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) --The Interior Department announced today the awarding of $240,000 in contracts to three Arizona public school districts to provide classroom space for Navajo Indians. The space will be for Navajo children from reservation areas not now served by the districts.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 19 (AP)--Two schools of thought were heard today at the Far Eastern Affairs Conference on the question of admitting Communist China to the United Nations.
ELMONT, L.I., Aug. 19-- Three hundred children attended an outing on the picnic grounds at Belmont Race Track here today.

Waxman Brothers, builders of Seaview Village, a colony of 2,000 homes at Rockaway Parkway and Avenue M, Brooklyn, report passing of title to six buyers of houses. The new owners are Donald Swirsky, John Mario, Edward Pullman, Nazzareno Montalbine, Jerome Salzman and Arnold Smith.

Three two-story garden apartment buildings on a plot 175 by 100 feet at 641-53 Chestnut Avenue, Teaneck, N.J., have been sold by Alice M. Kenniston to the Chestnut Gardens Holding Company through J.I. Kislak, Inc.

CHICAGO, Aug, 19 (AP)--Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, indicated today the Democratic party's platform proposal to cut income taxes might cost $4,000,000,000 a year in revenue. But he said the plan was sound and justifiable.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP)--Hillman Robbins of Lackland Air Force Base, Tex., sank a thirty-five-foot putt on the final hole yesterday to win the Air Force world-wide golf tournament by one stroke with 285.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19--Irregular fluctuations featured the lard futures market last week.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19-- A pledge to "support the independence of Israel against armed aggression" is contained in a proposed foreign policy plank forthe Republican National Convention.
MANILA, Aug. 19 (U.P.)--Senator Emmanuel Pelaez said today the Philippines had asked for a reduction in the size of three United States military reservations here.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19--Activity in grain and soybean, futures last week increased sharply over that of the preceding week, but was considerably lighter than a year ago.
A community welcome has been arranged for the dozen families who will become today the first tenants of New York's tallest public housing development.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19--The most important moral issue facing the United States during the next four years is that of racial integration on a basis of full freedom and equality.
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 19-- Miss Lilyan Tanya Belinky and Lawrence I. Wolther were married in Temple Emanuel this evening by Rabbi Arthur Buch.
WESTERLY, R.I., Aug. 19 (AP)--A thirty-foot rescue boat from the Point Judith Coast Guard Station was beached on ...
A NEW method of processing food seems to combine the best features of freezing, canning and dehydration. It is as exciting to home cooks as it is to manufacturers.

AMERICAN professors of history, it has often been charged in this space and elsewhere, are usually sound scholars but too often poor writers. When they write books, most display great diligence in research and scrupulous respect for the facts.

Capital expenditures to be made this year by the Gulf Oil Corporation may exceed $400,000,000, a new high, according to a report to shareholders by W.K. Whiteford, president, and S.A. Swensrud, chairman.

ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP)--George Breen of Buffalo, a member of the United States Olympic team, won the national A.A.U. four-mile swim today in a record 1 hour 32 minutes 25 seconds. The old fourmile national record was 1 hour 35 minutes 12 seconds.
WASHINGTONVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 19 (AP)--Two Newburgh, N.Y., men were killed today when their rented plane smashed into the ground not far from Toro Hill Lodge, a resort hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19-- Left-handed pitchers still find the Dodgers hard to beat. Curt Simmons became their second straight victim before 22,891 fans at Connie Mack Stadium today on a ninth-inning rally that downed the Phillies, 3--2.
The seventh annual city fishing contest for boys and girls 10 to 16 years old will be held Wednesday.
Burlington Mills and the Amerotron Corporation announced yesterday that they would suspend synthetic weaving operations for a week beginning Sept. 3. The companies are major producers in the field.
CAIRO, Aug. 19 (U.P.)--A group of Egyptian scientists will go to Moscow Tuesday in connection with a Soviet-Egyptian agreement for cooperation on development ...
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (Reuters) --The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda today accused the Western powers of attempting to take over the Suez Canal under the aegis of an "international authority."
FORT CARSON, Colo., Aug. 19 (UP)--Pvt. Donald O'Brien of the 502d Engineers at Fort Carson wouldn't watch his weight. It cost him $110.
The marriage of Miss Sandra Bangilsdorf, daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. Harry Bangilsdorf of Binghamton, N.Y., to Jerome Joshua Klein, son of Mrs. David ...
EAST MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 19--For the fourth successive year, Camp Pa-qua-tuck on Montauk Highway today put out its welcome mat for a large ...

Americans owning registered State of Israel Independence' Bonds may exchange them at full face value for newly issued shares of "Isras"--Israel-Rassco Investment Company, Ltd.--according to the American Palestine Securities Company of New York, the underwriter.
Cooler air from the Northwest approached the East last night and, with it, promise of an end to several days of hot, humid weather.

The vicar of a church founded in 675 A.D. was guest preacher at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, yesterday. The Rev. Canon Hartley A. Wareham, Vicar of Linthorpe, Middlesbrough in York, England, was the preacher.
Frank Parker, who formerly sang on the Arthur Godfrey show, will offer daytime competition for his old boss when he appears for two weeks on the National Broadcasting Company's "Bandstand" program.
A masked robber was killed and two of his confederates were captured in a pistol battle with the police last night after the three had attempted to hold up a midtown Park Avenue restaurant.
The John Fritz Medal for 1956 will be awarded to Admiral Ben Moreell, retired, chairman of the board of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP)-- An error and two singles enabled the Cleveland Indians to score an unearned run in the eighth inning and post a 2-1 victory over the Kansas City Athletics ...
Leases of stores in shopping centers on Long Island and in Westchester County were reported over the week-end by the developers.
HAVANA, Aug. 19--Minister of State Dr. Gonzalo Guell has requested the Cuban Embassy in Washington and its consulate in Los Angeles to determine if ...

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 19-- A group of enthusiastic young soldiers is going through infantry basic training here. The lads are enjoying it and are very good at it, and, so far as the Army is concerned, it is all a pleasant surprise.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18 (AP)-- A shift of several departments from New York to Kansas City was announced today by the longlines department of the American ...

The Brooklyn Italians, the newest member of the American Soccer League, lost to the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven, 3--1, in an exhibition game yesterday. The game marked the Italians' debut against American League opposition.

DETROIT, Aug, 19 (AP)--Six speed boats were named today to compete for the right to represent the United States in the Harmsworth (British International) Trophy race next Saturday on the Detroit River.
The city is running short of open land that can be used for housing construction.
AHMADABAD, India, Aug. 19 --Ahmadabad, one of India's major industrial centers, was ruled today by a few thousand students.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 19 (Reuters)--Dr. Hobart Bauman Amstutz, 59-year-old American, who has worked as a missionary for more than thirty years in Malaya, today was consecrated Methodist Bishop for Southeastern Asia. He succeeds Bishop Raymond Archer, who is retiring.
The election of Craig Senft as a vice president of Prentice-Hall, Inc., was announced over the week-end by Richard P. Ettinger, chairman of the publishing concern.
The White House has been warned that textile mills face a hard choice: They can go out of business or reduce wages "to levels that are, and rightly should be, wholly unacceptable to American labor."

MONTREAL, Aug. 19 (Canadian Press)--John Marvin of the Eastern Yacht Club, Marblehead, Mass., took a two-point lead today after five races in trials for the United States Finn class entry in the Olympic Games yachting competition.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 19 --Miss Camilla May Master, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Master of 125 East Seventysecond Street, New York, and of Harrison, became the bride at noon today of Dr. Isadore Rosenfeld.
WOODMERE, L.I., Aug. 19-- In Congregation Sons of Israel this evening, Miss Lois Dail Frank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Frank of Brooklyn, became ...

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 19--Sis Hibberd, in the Lightning, Splash; Bus Mosbacher's International, Susan, and Pat O'Gorman's Star, Wahini, made it two straight today as the Huguenot Yacht Club ended its two-day Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Aug. 19 (AP) --The Norwegian ship Skaubryn left Saigon today for France carrying more than 1,000 French and Eurasian refugees. Most of them fled from Communist North Vietnam more than a year ago and were unable to find work in the south.
An advertising man has finally spoken--in paid space--for the martini as a cocktail instead of a beaker of gin.
UNION, Conn., Aug. 19 (AP)-- A car containing $7,000 in furs and clothing was stolen in Sturbridge, Mass., today and recovered here an hour later, the state police said.
ZURICH, Aug. 19--Until last Thursday there was doubt here that the London conference would be able to end the Suez Canal crisis quickly.
EL TORO, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP) --A Marine pilot killed in a Panther jet crash near Fallon, Nev. was identified today as First Lieut. Thomas F. Tague, ...
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19-- Hamilton Richardson's quest for his third successive leg on the Newport Casino Cup failed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (AP)--Minnesota delegates to the Republican National Convention will be "practically solid" for Vice President Richard M. Nixon to seek re-election, Senator Edward J. Thye, chairman of the twenty-eight-member delegation, said today.
YONKERS, Aug. 19--The Yonkers-Alpine ferry across the Hudson River announced today a reduction in vehicular fare effective Wednesday.
A SENTIMENTAL crusade is under way to revive the music and memory of James A. Bland. The plan is to bring his body to New York from the obscure Negro cemetery in ...
A band concert and a display of some of the small craft that daily patrol New York's harbor, on the water and in the air, will be held tomorrow at the Battery.
TOKYO, Aug. 19 (AP)--Five persons were crushed to death today in a landslide on a mountain road thirty miles northwest of here, the Nishi-Tama county police reported today.

Crude oil production in Saudi Arabia in July averaged 1,033,563 barrels a day, compared with 942,362 in July last year, the Arabian American Oil Company announced over the weekend. For the first seven months of this year output averaged 1,045,101 barrels daily, against 944,027 in the similar period of 1955.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19-- Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York disclosed today that he would make speeches for the Republican national ticket this year.

Contract negotiators between the Western Electric Company and representatives of 18,000 unionized telephone installers reported "some progress" early today as they adjourned their session until later today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP)--Jim Davis of the Chicago Cubs stopped the St. Louis Cardinals with six hits for a 3-1 victory today after Murry Dickson had pitched a two-hit, 6-0 triumph for the Cards in the opener of a double-header.
Federal Prison Industries, Inc., a wholly owned Government corporation, deposited in the Treasury dividends amounting to $4,000,000 in the past fiscal year.
The marriage of Miss Deborah Ann Fleishman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fleishman of 1009 Park Avenue, to Michael Kenneth Roth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Roth of New York, ...
POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J., Aug. 19--Miss Rosina Guadagnino, 21 years old began her reign as Miss New Jersey Seafood Princess today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)-- A twin-rotor Army helicopter has set a world record by flying non-stop for 1,199.07 miles. The previous record of 778.3 miles was set by France three years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19-- Rapid tax amortization certificates for twenty-two new or expanded facilities amounting to $14,533,893 were issued by the Office of Defense Mobilization ...

The Police and the District Attorney's office were checking yesterday to see whether there was a connection between an East Side murder Saturday and the blinding by acid of Victor Riesel, labor columnist.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19--Dr. Konrad Maril, who headed the Austrian service of the United States Information Agency's Voice of America, died of a heart attack here today. He was 67 years old.
A driver testing clinic to detect faulty driving techniques and to offer corrective advice will be conducted again this year by the Greater New York Safety Council, beginning Aug. 27.

LONDON, Aug. 20, Monday-- Bernard Cardinal Griffin, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster and primate of his church in England and Wales, died of a heart attack this morning on vacation in New Polzeath, Cornwall. He was 57 years old.

Fewer export and import cargoes traveled in American ships in 1955 than in any year since 1946. Despite a substantial increase in the tonnage volume of United States water-borne foreign commerce last year, the ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (U.P.)-- The Democratic National Committee announced today the appointment of John S. Johns of Canton, Ohio, as chairman of labor activities for Ohio, and Willard Murphy of Kansas City, Kan., as chairman of labor activities for Kansas.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 19 (AP)-- Oil bubbled up over the front lawn of a large Hollywood home today and threatened to spilt out into the street.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 19 (AP)--Dr. Herbert L. Jenny, former head of the music department of Wheaton College, Norton, Mass., died here yesterday. His age was 70.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 19-- Shawhan Fox, yesterday's winner with Naughty Lady, repeated today in the 110 Class as the Riverside Yacht Club played host to the Eastern Division Y.R.A. fleets.
Art censorship by Baltimore's Mayor will be the subject of a suit in the Maryland Court of Appeals.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP)-- The Cleveland Plain Dealer early today said good-by to the East Sixth Street-Superior Avenue site, its home since 1896.
BOMBAY, India, Aug. 19-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru accused the Opposition parties today of fomenting trouble over the revision of India's state boundaries.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 19 (AP)--The Amsterdam Soccer Club defeated the Iraklis team of Greece, 4--1, today.
OCEAN CITY, N.J., Aug. 19 (AP)--John McCausland's boat stayed upright in a strong southeast wind today to win the Moth class honors at the twentyfirst annual Ocean City regatta.
A frozen brake shoe on a Queens-bound E train caused a ninety-minute suspension of service early yeterday on the Independent subway between Fifth Avenue and Queens Plaza.

LONDON, Aug. 19--Britain's output of goods and services increased in volume by a third from the beginning of 1946 to the end of 1955, the Central Statistical Office reported today. Half of this increase has been made since 1952.
IS filling a hope chest as novel a practice among today's young girls as wearing a strapless dress to a party would have been to their sisters of yesteryear?
LONDON, Aug. 18--Stock market prices improved somewhat this week as hope increased for a reasonable and peaceful settlement of the Suez Canal dispute.
To the surprise of many of Wall Street's foreign securities specialists, Egypt's seizure of the Suez Canal has stimulated demand in this country for the shares of the Suez Canal Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (AP)--Hugh McElhenny's eightyyard touchdown run fired the San Francisco Forty-Niners to a 28-17 victory today over the Cleveland Browns. It was the opening National Football League exhibition for both teams.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19-- There are three major questions before the delegates at the Republican National Convention:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) --Spending by Federal, state and local governments dropped by 1 per cent in the 1955 fiscal year, the Department of Commerce reported today. The total was $109,500,000,000.

IT came as a jolt to the baseball world a week or so ago that Frankie Frisch had been felled by a heart attack. When medi cal reports later revealed the rugged Old Flash was recovering rapidly and soon would be up and about again, the rejoicing was great.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 19 --A strong delegation of Canadian athletes from the Provinces of Quebec, Ontario and Manitoba invaded Lake Sebago today and helped bring a wellearned victory to the Dominion in the North American Canoe championships.
In its general form and tone, the national platform produced by the Democratic party in Chicago last week was in the best sophistical tradition of that uniquely American political institution.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 19--Robie D. Marriner, president of the American Book Company, New York publishers, died last night of a heart attack ...

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Aug. 18 (AP)--Control of the Selby Shoe Company, manufacturer of women's footwear, has been purchased by three Brooklyn and Chicago men, it was announced today by Roger Selby, chairman and son of the founder.

Miss Barbara Anne Shomer, daughter of Mrs. Mitchel Schneider of Bronxville, N.Y., and Paul Shomer of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Dennis M. Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Stein of Brooklyn.

AACHEN, Germany, Aug. 19 (Reuters)--Four coal miners were buried by a cave-in 1,170 feet underground in the Sofia Jacoba mine in Huecklehoven, near here, last night. Officials said there was little hope of rescuing them.

VIENNA, Aug. 19 (Reuters)-- Hundreds of Viennese cheered the Duke and Duchess of Windsor when they arrived here by automobile today with their party on a private visit to Austria. They are expected to leave next week for Velden am Worthersee in south Austria.
Farrell Dobbs and Myra Tanner Weiss were nominated last night as the Socialist Workers party candidates for President and Vice President, respectively.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 19--Authorization of eight oil concessions in Lake Maracaibo has been confirmed in The Official Gazette.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP)--The University of San Diego announced today it would open its first football season against the United States Air Force Academy here on Sept. 29. San Diego plans a schedule of seven games.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP)--Roy Sievers' double in the eleventh inning, scoring Clint Courtney from second, carried the Washington Senators to an 11-10 victory over the Boston Red Sox today to complete a doubleheader sweep.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 19--The Dutch Cabinet-forming process enters its tenth week and a new significant phase tomorrow.
Ely Walker, St. Louis, a member company of Burlington Industries, Inc., announced yesterday it would supply a diversified...
PIGGOTT, Ark., Aug. 19 (U.P.) --Piggott went to the dogs today. The Missouri and Arkansas dogs, 380 all told, were rounded up for a scene in the movie, "A Face in the Crowd."
Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Greeff of 164 East Seventy-second Street have made known the engagement of Mr. Greeff's daughter, Miss Evangeline ...

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Aug. 19--The eighty-second annual festival of the Plattdeutsche Volkfest-Verein came to an end today with the rededication of the Fritz Reuter Altenheim, a home here for aged people. The verein sponsors the home.

WEST WASHINGTON, Me., Aug. 19 (AP)--A noted painter and sculptor who is an inmate of the Augusta State Hospital was shot and severely wounded yesterday. The police said he had been shot at a nursing home by the husband of the establishment's operator.
Tony (Tex) Gonzales, Orange (N.J.), middleweight, will oppose Fernando Spallotta of Rome in the ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena ...

Herman R. Freund, former vice president and chief engineer of the Intertype Corporation and prominently known for his typographic accomplishments, died of a heart attack Saturday at Doylestown, Pa. He was 70 years old.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 19 (Reuters)--Dr. Hermann Heinz Ortner, Austrian writer and dramatist, died of a heart attack here last night during a Salzburg Festival performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni." His age was 60.
Dennis Briody, 13 years old, of 251 Forest Avenue, Massapequa, L.I., who was the personal guest of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt, arrived at New York International Airport ...

A corner store in the building at 292 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-first Street, has been leased by the Remington Rand Division of the Sperry Rand Corporation for a midtown electric shaver service center. Cushman Wakefield, brokers, arranged the lease. The Cross Brown Company is agent for the building.
A $106,000,000 industrial prize is likely to be on the block within several months.
The Parks Department has opened a new playground at Lee Avenue and Taylor Street, Williamsburgh, Brooklyn, next to Public School 16.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 19--Venezuelan practices on oil concessions will be imitated by Saudi Arabia, Abdullah Tariki, head of her petroleum division, announced here today.
Miss Marcia Phillips was married yesterday at noon to Arnold Weinberg in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza by the Rev. Morris Goldberg.
The contribution of a single Protestant missionary, who traveled more than 15,000 miles by horseback, was lauded yesterday by the Rev. S. Ralph Harlow.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19-- The Republican National Convention will NOT open in San Francisco tomorrow.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Monday, Aug. 20 (Reuters)-- The Malay Federation Government said today it had reduced Communist terrorists in Malaya to "more of an annoyance than a threat to the very life of the country."
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (AP)-- The Gulf Oil Corporation called today for "firm and reliable" international control of the Suez Canal. The company operating the canal recently was nationalized by Egypt.
Arthur Karpf's My Syn yesterday won the Mohawk Trophy, emblematic of the North Atlantic Coast Snipe championship in the Sound off City Island.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 --The Eisenhower Administration tonight was apparently preparing to consider a modified civil rights plank that would be acceptable to Southern delegations to the 1956 convention.
The United Cerebral Palsy Research and Educational Foundation, Inc., is spending more than $500,000 this year to solve the problems of the disease.
The New York Public Library is making available for reference a three-part study, "The Communist Record in the United States," presented to it by the Fund for the Republic.

HONG KONG, Aug. 19--Representatives of four United States news-distribution agencies are planning to enter Communist China Thursday despite the State Department's refusal to approve their visit, the China Travel Bureau said today.

The American Hellenic Educational Progressive Association, a Greek-American fraternal organization with 100,000 members in the United States and Canada, yesterday elected John L. Manta of Chicago as Supreme President.
Sales and earnings of the Melville Shoe Corporation reached record highs in the six months ended June 30, the shoe manufacturing and retailing concern has reported.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19--It has not yet been announced by the White House, but President Eisenhower's "people-to-people" conference has now been set for Sept. 11.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (U.P.)--Fay Crocker of Montevideo, Uruguay, carded a 68 today to win the Norwood Hills women's open golf tournament. Her 288 for the 72-hole event was worth $880.

The future belongs to those who rise above existing conditions, the Rev. Dr. Benjamin E. Mays said yesterday in a sermon at Riverside Church. He is president of Morehouse College in Atlanta and vice president of the United Negro College Fund.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 19 (AP)--The Syrian press said today seven persons had been killed and 257 injured in recent proEgyptian demonstrations in the British protectorate of Kuwait.
BETHPAGE, L.I., Aug. 19-- Archie Young scored four goals as the Brookville poloists turned back Wheatley Hills, 8--6, at the State Park today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week closed with mixed net changes, up 22 points to down 5 from the preceding week's close.
There is real pleasure in recommending "Sterling-Dollar Diplomacy", by Richard N. Gardner, a revealing and stimulating work that should be required reading for legislators.

Shipments of ingot brass and bronze dropped to 17,364 tons last month from 18,842 tons in June, and compared with 18,513 tons delivered in July last year, the Defense Council of the Ingot Brass and Bronze Industry reported over the week-end.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 (AP)-- Ed Furgol staged a comeback today to win the $35,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament with a fifteen-under-par 265 for seventy-two holes.

Summer appears to be over in so far as vessel owners in the charter field are concerned. Last week the owners showed no inclination to negotiate, but offered their tonnage on practically a take-it-or-leave-it basis.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 19 (AP)--Defense Minister Abdul Hassib Raslan said today Syria, Egypt and Saudi Arabia had agreed to extend permanent financial aid to Jordan's National Guard to help "equip this important defensive organ against the Israeli threat."
William Lombardy, an 18year-old master, drew with Samuel Reshevsky, the international grand master, for the fifth consecutive game yesterday in their training match at the Manhattan Chess Club.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 19-- Edward F. Dannemiller's Tranquil, a Class C boat, captured the J. Brion Foulke Jr. memorial trophy today with the best corrected time for the 36-mile overnight race from Babylon to Bellport and return.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19 (U.P.)--Orville D. Hodge, former State Auditor who admitted taking $637,000 from the state of Illinois, may enter prison in the next twenty-four hours, authorities said today.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Aug. 19-- Premier Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia steered his little country skillfully last week between Arab nationalism and economic isolation.
Brown Brothers Harriman Co., investment bankers, today will open new Chicago offices in the Field Building, 135 South La Salle Street, under the management oft Stephen Y. Hord, a partner.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (U.P.)--A pair of two-run innings, one resulting from Bill Hoeft's wild pitch, today gave the Chicago White Sox a 4-1 victory in the second game of a double header with the Detroit Tigers.

LIVERPOOL, England, Aug. 19 (Reuters)--Two Britons who worked for the Anglo-Egyptian Oilfields Company in the Suez Canal Zone and were given twenty-four hours to get out of Egypt arrived here by ship today--still not knowing why they were expelled.

LONDON, Aug. 19--After week-end talks between delegates, Western observers expected tonight that fifteen or more of the twenty-two nations at the Suez Canal conference would support international operation of the waterway.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19 (AP)--Pat Flaherty's doctor said tonight the condition of the 1956 winner of the 500-mile Indianapolis auto race had improved sufficiently to remove him from the critical list. Flaherty was injured yesterday when his auto crashed during a race at the Illinois State Fair Grounds.
"Goldsmith of the Waldorf" answered his telephone at the hotel yesterday and said:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19--The Yankees had to settle for a split of their four-game series here when the Orioles came up with three runs in the seventh inning to win today's finale, 3--2. A crowd of 20,844 saw the game at Memorial Stadium.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 19 (AP)-- The United States finished fifth today in the fencing portion of an international pentathlon competition. The top American was Bill Andre, a Navy ensign, who was third with twenty-one victories and 913 points. After two days, Hungary leads the team standing with 5,353 points.

The United States is about to conclude its largest deal, thus far, for the sale of surplus agricultural products. Under its terms something like $400,000,000 worth of wheat, flour, rice and cotton will go to India. The period of shipment is to be about three years.

MIAMI, Aug. 19 (U.P.)--National Airlines, which ordered a partial shutdown because it feared a strike by its pilots, called back 300 employes today. But it said full operation would not be resumed until the pilots promised not to walk out.
The Police Department reported yesterday that the week-end increase in plainly marked police cars was "proving successful" as a deterrent to speeders.
Bobby Bragan, the imaginative pilot of the Pittsburgh Pirates, continued to employ unorthodox batting orders against the Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP)--Shirley Fry of St. Petersburg, Fla., today defeated second-seeded Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., 6--1, 4--6, 6--2, to win the Essex Country Club's women's invitation tournament for the second straight year.
PARIS, Aug. 19--Louis Madelin, French historian and member of the French Academy, died here yesterday. He was 85 years old.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 19 (AP)--The United States men's volleyball team beat the Dutch national team, 3-1, last night. The American women's team lost to the Dutch women by the same score.
JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 19--A short tap by Herb Pennell with 45 seconds of play remaining enabled the Jericho Poloists to earn a 5--5 deadlock with Meadow Brook at the Meadow Brook Club today.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced over the week-end a new life-insurance policy that covers both present and future members of the family.
YESTERDAY afternoon there was a toss-up whether the Republicans took over television or vice versa.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19--Twentieth Century-Fox is continuing its preoccupation with wartime dramas.

The Union Switch and Signal Company, a division of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company, announced over the week-end the development of a new signal system expected to expand the use of centralized traffic control on railroads.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 21-- The Central Illinois Public Service Company reported today net income of $2,134,179, or $2.47 a common share, for the twelve months ended July 31. A year ago it reported earnings of $8,435,699, or $2.24 a common share.

An off-duty policeman shot and wounded a youth on a Times Square subway platform last night. The police said the youth had attempted to flee after having been arrested on charges of molesting a young woman.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24--Sal Maglie gained the decision over his old team-mate, Larry Jansen, but neither was around at the finish of tonight's game, which the Dodgers won from the Redlegs, 6--4, for their sixth straight triumph.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 24-- Jordan has taken another stride toward joining the "neutralist," or anti-Western, bloc headed by Egypt.

A strike in the set-up paper box industry was threatened yesterday by a union representing 4,500 employer in the metropolitan area. Negotiations for a contract to follow a two-year pact expiring on Aug. 31 have bogged down, the union said.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 24-- Dr. Otto John, former head of the West German Office for the Protection of the Constitution, was charged today with having committed treason. Dr. John defected to East Germany July 20, 1954, but returned to West Germany eighteen months later.
Both the Democratic and Republican platforms indulge, as we have previously noted, in traditional flights of fancy that have no necessary relationship to reality.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24--First money was $36,100 in the sixty-fifth Spinaway Stakes at the Saratoga track today. It was easy money for William Haggin Perry's Alanesian, the 3-to-5 favorite. She won with eight lengths to spare.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24-- Three Australian teams reached the semi-final round of the national doubles tennis championships today with Victor Seixas and Hamilton Richardson.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24--A Soviet translator at the United Nations has been dismissed for attempting to obtain secret data on United States military aircraft.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 --Patrick Wayne, 17-year-old son of film star John Wayne, formally entered the movie business today when Superior Court Judge William McKesson in Los Angeles approved terms of a seven-year contract between the youth and C.V. Whitney Pictures, Inc.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 24--Hans von Herwath of 310 East Fifty-fifth Street, New York, a collector of rare plants, died here yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in his summer home, Weybourne Hill. His age was 58.
Selections from the writings of Anne O'Hare McCormick, who was a member of the editorial board of The New York Times, will be published Sept. 17 by Knopf under the title "The World at Home."

Experimental development of a new electronic printer that translates 4,000 coded signals a second and prints up to forty different business documents a minute was announced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.
Cotton futures moved 2 to 9 points (10 to 45 cents a bale) higher yesterday in moderate trading.

WHEN Princess Juliana was born, thus giving promise of at least one more generation of Netherlands rule by the House of Orange, so great was the jubilation that a parish sexton in a tiny Frisian village broke the church bell with the frenzy of his ringing.
One of the more hopeful developments in the troubled Far Eastern area is an apparent easing of the tension that has prevailed between Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Emanuele Ronzoni, founder land president of the Ronzoni Macaroni Company, Inc., of Long Island City, Queens, died yesterday in his home at 36-05 166th Street, Flushing, Queens. His age was 86.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 24 (AP)-- A three-run rally in the ninth inning paced by Bill Tuttle's home run gave the Detroit Tigers a 4-to-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 24 (AP) --Joe Brown of New Orleans, a 30-year-old former carpenter with a buzz-saw left hand, floored Wallace (Bud) Smith, the defender, twice in the fourteenth round tonight and went on to win the world lightweight title on a fifteen-round split decision.

Deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks increase $76,000,000 during July, $21,000000 less than the increase in the similar month a year ago, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.
The backlog of senior financing on the market for new longterm capital has declined below $1,000,000,000 for the first time in many weeks, but the total is still large.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--The Justice Department asked the United States Court of Appeals today to prevent pro-segregationists from interfering with a local school board's effort to integrate classes.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 24 --The Lions' Club Hondo team of Roswell, N.M., won the Little League world series today before a crowd of 12,000.
DALLAS, Aug. 24--Judges of state courts sat in jundgment here today on the Supreme Court of the United States and found it wanting.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Aug. 24--President Eisenhower celebrated his renomination today by playing his first full eighteen-hole round of golf since his operation.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24 (AP)-- Warren Spahn scattered five hits and Joe Adcock and Eddie Mathews hit home runs tonight to give the first-place Milwaukee Braves a 6-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

DUBLIN, Aug. 23--The Irish Government said today it had authorized the Central Bank to build up dollar reserves in its general fund. Hitherto, remittances in dollars through legacies, gifts or securities have gone to the British dollar pool in London.
New York's first Jazz Festival opened a two-day stand under a cloudless sky at Randalls Island Stadium last night. The firstnight audience was estimated at 15,000.
PLAINVIEW, L.I., Aug. 24-- The body of Peter Weinberger, victim of kidnapping when he was 33 days old, was discovered here today.
Coffee drinkers soon wiill hav to pay more for their favorit brew. Yesterday three of the nation's leading roasters increase wholesale prices of vacuum packed coffees 3 cents a pound
King Saud of Saudi Arabia yesterday gave a large, brilliantly colored prayer rug to the Moslem Students Association of Columbia University.

James G. Cummins stands six feet seven inches tall, or, in the words of one associate, "a little lower than the angels." He looks like a Norman Rockwell portrait of a fullback. He is 14 years old. He chases butterflies.
TRENTON, Aug. 24--Gov. Robert B. Meyner today urged all citizens of New Jersey to register immediately to become eligible to vote at the election Nov. 6.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24 --The James Cain novel "Mildred Pierce" will be televised Sept. 20 to mark the start of the fall season of the "Lux Video Theatre" on the National Broadcasting Company network. No performers have been set yet for the melodrama.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 24 (Reuters)--An explosion killed one Greek Cypriote and seriously injured another in the Larnaca area of southeast Cyprus tonight. Tension in the British colony was increased over a new terrorist threat to resume the sixteenmonth campaign of violence.

LONDON, Aug. 24--Representatives of the five nations selected to present to Egypt the plan for international operation of the Suez Canal met for the first time today. They constituted themselves the Suez Canal Committee.

Water from a broken twelveinch main under Wall Street flooded the basements of three buildings in the financial center yesterday. It disrupted traffic, inconvenienced hundreds of persons and caused considerable damage.
Mayor Wagner conferred yesterday with Senator Herbert H. Lehman, whom he may seek to succeed.

Commodity futures prices on the New York, exchanges were mostly irregular yesterday in quiet trading. Cottonseed oil, sugar, wool and burlap declined; coffee, potatoes, cocoa, and rubber rose, while price movements for hides were mixed.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24-- Thomas Jefferson believed that "whenever the people are well-informed they can be trusted with their own government."
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 24--Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard announced today "the solution of difficulties" in the Dutch royal family.
A hundred teen-agers from ten eastern states will attend a Torah leadership seminar next week at Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue and 168th Street.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 24 --Two 19-year-old youths who rank far down at Nos. 28 and 34 were named today on the United States Davis Cup squad for the forthcoming interzone round match with Italy.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24-- The Republican National Chairman today fixed Sept. 15 for the probable start of the Presidential campaign. He also warned that "complacency" was the party's greatest enemy.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 24--This town's two-year quest for a new commuter railroad station appeared to be nearing its end today.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) --C.W. Brown of near-by Dayton today won trapshooting's biggest prize, the Grand American Handicap.
Improved street lighting is being planned by the city as a weapon in the fight against crime.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 24--An Army helicopter landed on a slab of concrete beside the Pentagon this afternoon, ending the first non-stop transcontinental flight by such an aircraft.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24-- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, called on President Eisenhower and Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, today to halt discrimination among civilians, employed by the armed forces in Europe.
PARIS, Aug. 24--The results of the London conference on the future of the Suez Canal were received without enthusiasm by the French Cabinet today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--The Navy announced tonight the recovery of the body of one of the sixteen crew members of the patrol plane attacked this week off the coast of Communist China.
The decision to set up an office of umpire of transit system labor relations with final and binding powers of arbitration over grievances that arise under contract is a logical forward step.

WHITTIER, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP)--Francis A. Nixon, 77year-old father of Vice President Richard M. Nixon, today fought off a set back and regained ground in his critical illness. He was described by his doctors as 'a tough member of a tough generation."
PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 24-- Willie Turnesa, who won the tourney in 1938, gained the semifinals of the Metropolitan amateur golf championship today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24-- Mrs. Marian MacDowell, widow of one of America's greatest composers, died here last night at the home of a friend.
CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 24-- Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, said today that law schools were producing "infinitely better-equipped" attorneys than thirty years ago.

Rights to 725 Metro-GoldwynMayer feature films were obtained yesterday by television stations in twelve cities for an announced price of $20,000,000.
ALBANY, Aug. 24--Governor Harriman charged today that the Republican National Convention had been characterized by "pretense, evasion and phony promises."
The Rich Plant Corporation of Yonkers, N.Y., has purchased the warehouse and parking lot at 170 Saw Mill River Road, in Elmsford, Westchester County, for the storage and distribution of frozen foods.

There is a ticker-tape tizzy in Birmingham, England. Yesterday it was reported in eight restrained lines by Reuters, the British news agency, and in thirty-five lively lines by The Associated Press, that a woman had applied for membership on the Birmingham Stock Exchange.

TOKYO, Aug. 24--Communist China complained tonight that United States planes were violating its territory in their search for a Navy plane with sixteen aboard apparently shot down off Red China Thursday. The plane was downed in the East China Sea, presumably by Communist aircraft.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24-- The United States Consumer Price Index soared 0.7 per cent between mid-June and mid-July to a record for the second straight month.
PHEASANT hunters, who now are or should be get ting their dogs and gear ready, will have a pretty good season in New York State this fall if the usual indicators can be trusted.
The influx of tourists highpowered cars built in the United States has prompted the Mexican Government to increase gasoline efficiency.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, N.J., has purchased the three-story building at 99 Central Avenue, Newark, for occupancy by the Mount Carmel Guild, an institution for the handicapped.
The threat of inflation looms again as a darkening shadow upon the horizon of the American economy.
MIDDLEBORO, Mass., Aug. 24 (AP)--James A. Brennan, song writer and musician, died today after a long illness. His age was 71.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 24 (AP)--Don January of Lampasas, Tex., shot a seven-under-par 65 today for a thirty-six-hole 133 to lead the St. Paul open golf tournament as forty-two players stood at under-par figures at the halfway mark.
ALBANY, Aug. 24--Governor Harriman reported today that a drive against state income tax delinquents had increased such collections by 113 per cent in the last two years.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 24--Eben Starr Abbott, a nautical engineer, died of a heart ailment here today at his home 786 Pelhamdale Avenue. He was 76 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--The index of average primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 114.6 per cent of the 1947-49 level, the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

HEWLETT, L.I., Aug. 24-- Hamilton Pell, financier and industrialist, and founder and member of the stockbrokerage firm of Pell Co., died of a heart attack this morning at his summer home here. Mr. Pell, who made his legal home at Palm Beach, Fla., was 68 years old.

GENEVA, N.Y., Aug. 24--It may be necessary to establish a special marine bureau of the New York State Police to enforce laws regulating motor boats on the state's waterways. Assemblyman Charles A. Cusick, Republican of Auburn, said today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24--After early weakness today on the Board of Trade, wheat prices moved above yesterday's closing levels. Commission absorption took the slack out of the pit, with short covering following.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Aug. 26 (AP)--Dean Chenowith of Xenia, Ohio, and David Kough of Hawthorne, N.J., each won a pair of titles in the eighth annual national stock outboard championships today.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Aug. 26--Mr. and Mrs. Frederic P. Clark have announced the engagement of their adopted daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Johnson, to Benjamin C. Bixby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chesley T. Bixby of Haverhill and Kingston, N.H.A. June wedding is planned.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 26-- Clyde F. Farmer, vice president in charge of traffic for the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, died here tonight at his home, 6 Fernwood Road, after a short illness. His age was 67.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 --Alan Ladd temporarily will step out of his dual role as starproducer to go to work for Twentieth Century-Fox in "Boy on a Dolphin." It is understood, however, that Mr. Ladd, who has his own independent company known as Jaguar Productions, will get a percentage of the picture's prospective profits in addition to a guaranteed salary. He will co-star with Clifton Webb and the Italian actress, Sophia Loren, in the comedydrama.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 26 (AP)--Bill Chennault of Kansas City, driving a big speedway type car, today took the championship event at the Minnesota state fair. He covered the twenty laps in 8 minutes 46.33 seconds.

Dr. I.I. Rabi, professor of physics at Columbia University and William Gregory, Jr., senior partner in Gregory Sons, New York investment bankers, have been elected directors of Hycon Manufacturing Company, Pasadena, Calif., the company announced over the week-end.

ULAN BATOR, "Outer Mongolia, Aug. 26--In and around this evoling capital of a still largely trackless, pastoral land little known to the Western world, the modern age is being installed according to Communist formulas.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 26 (UP) --Al Downing today pitched Trenton to the Babe Ruth world series championship with a threehit 1-0 victory over Huntington Park, Calif.

SEATILE, Aug. 26 (AP)-- Richard Mizuhata, 13-year-old Seattle Boy Scout who survived six days on the slopes of Mount Rainier with almost no food or water, ate a big breakfast in a Seattle hospital today.
New state and municipal financing scheduled for this week includes $49,840,530 in bonds and $520,000 in short-term notes, ...
CERVIA, Italy, Aug. 26 (AP)-- Mr. Pinza has canceled his contract to appear in a new play next season.

FARGO, N.D., Aug. 26 (AP)-- Jack Rule, Waterloo, Iowa, shot a 3-under-par 69 today to defeat Jack Nicklaus, Columbus, Ohio, in an eighteen-hole play-off for the championship in the Jaycee junior international golf tournament. Nicklaus had a 71. Each shot a 288 over the regulation seventy-two holes.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 26-- Premier David Ben-Gurion warned tonight that peace would not be established in the Middle East unless Israel was assured complete freedom of navigation in the Red Sea strait and through the Suez Canal.

DUQUOIN, Ill., Aug. 26 (UP)-- Dick Klamforth, Groveport, Ohio, won the 15-mile American Motorcycle Association national championship race today. John Tibben, 18, Victor, Iowa, was thrown through a guard rail when his motorcycle overturned during eliminations. He was hospitalized with a head injury. Klamforth led five finishers in 11:6.30.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP)--The Kansas City Athletics rallied for a 7-6 victory over the Boston Red Sox on Al Pilarcik's tenthinning ground-rule double today.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26--Gerry Staley, making his first start since July 4, pitched the Chicago White Sox to a 5-1 victory over Baltimore today after the Orioles had defeated Billy Pierce in the opener, 8--1.
West Coast longshoremen have endorsed the demand of the International Longshoremen's Association for coastwise bargaining.
A 93-year-old retired Bishop of the Methodist Church summed up yesteday his views on "Life, God and I."
SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 26-- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin was renominated by acclamation, today for a third term as Governor.

Dr. Gordon Watkins Douglas has been appointed Professor and chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Genecology of the New York University College of Medicine, a unit of New York University-Bellevue Medical Center.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26 (AP)--Dr. Earl L. Green, 43 years old, Associate Professor in the Department of Zoology at Ohio State University, has been named director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory.

Zionist leaders charged yesterday that President Nasser's seizure of the Suez Canal Company and Egypt's arms pact with the Communist bloc were "the inevitable outcome" of an appeasement policy by the State Department toward the Arab states.
CAIRO, Aug. 26--President Gamal Abdel Nasser agreed tonight to meet the Westernsponsored five-nation committee on the Suez Canal crisis.
Workmen labored over the week-end at repairing two holes made in the surface of Wall Street by a water main that burst early Friday morning.

Two five - story apartment buildings at 582-86 East 140th Street, the Bronx, have been purchased by David B. Solove for investment. The property contains forty apartments and is assessed at $62,000. It is on a plot 76 by 100 feet.

TOKYO, Aug. 26 (AP)--Union officials said that more than 100,000 Japanese workers left their jobs at United States military bases throughout the country tonight in a twenty-fourhour protest against new rules involving sleeping or drinking on duty and being late to work.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (UP)--Sir Winston Churchill played host to the Japanese Foreign Minister, Mamoru Shigemitsu, at a private lunch today at his Chartwell estate south of London. Mr. Shigemitsu, who has been in London for the Suez Canal conference, was greeted at the door by Sir Winston as he arrived by car.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 26-- Tommy Goodwin, a 43-yearold member of the Westchester Country Club, capped a twenty-five-year quest by winning the metropolitan amateur golf championship today.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. --The new Hazard Memorial Hospital, named for the late Dr. Edward C. Hazard, who founded the hospital in a frame building on the same site in 1923, will be opened here Saturday with a public ceremony and inspection. Dr. Anthony Pisani of Rumson, chief orthopedic surgeon at St. Vincent's Hospital, New York, will be chief of the new fiftyinstitution.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 26--The First Secretary of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party has revealed a little of the economic turmoil forced on the Communist countries of Eastern Europe by the Korean War.

A building being erected by Samuel H. Golding Sons at 95-44 to 95-48 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park, Queens, has been leased for fifteen years by the Simon Ackerman Company, clothier, through Riker Co., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) --The Defense Department has drafted a radically rivised personnel security questionnaire designed to stem the much-criticized practices of "guilt by association" and "guilt by kinship."
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 26 (UP)--A daughter, their second child, was born to Mrs. Peter Lawford, wife of the actor, at St. John's Hospital last night.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 26 (AP)-- Jim Bryan of Phoenix, Ariz., averaged 92.7 miles per hour today as he won the 250-mile national championship big car race at State Fair Park. Bryan finfished in 2 hours 41 minutes 45.1 seconds.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26--The Royal Bermuda Yacht Club kept possession of the Aberfeldy Trophy today when its four Luders-16 helmsmen won the fifth and final race of their team series with Indian Harbor skippers, 20 to 16.

Smith-Corona, Inc., typewriter manufacturer, announced over the week-end the election of two new directors. They are Emerson E. Mead and Edward F. Kleinschmidt. Both are officers of Kleinschmidt Laboratories, Inc.
DENVER, Aug. 26 (AP)--Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge set a Ladies Professional Golf Association record today, winning the Mile High women's open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 284.
Vladimir Surin, Soviet Deputy Minister of Culture, said yesterday his Government would consider any United States projects for expanding cultural exchanges on a reciprocal basis.
MONTREAL, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press)--Few upsets were recorded today in the second round of the first Canadian open chess championship.

The Chinese have a wise saying: "If you would be happy for a week, take a wife; if you would be happy for a month, kill your pig; but if you would be happy all your life, plant a garden." In her forthcoming book, "Men and Gardens,"...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) --Rocky Colavito drove in all Cleveland's runs today as the Indians defeated the Washington Senators, 4--1, behind Early Wynn's four-hit pitching.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (AP) --Jim Hewson of Buffalo and Henry Laskau and Bruce McDonald of New York today gained the walking berths on the United States Olympic team.

ATHENS, Aug. 26 (AP)--A Greek Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight that secret documents were stolen early today from the Greek Embassy in Ankara, Turkey, and that Greece had filed formal protests.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Aug. 26-- A.H. Merkel's 5-year-old bay gelding Fighting Irish from Brookville scored 18 points to win the working hunter championship in the forty-first Smithtown horse show at the Knox School today.
IF the first New York Jazz Festival had done nothing more than to present Dizzy Gillespie's new orchestra to an audience of 20,000 people it would have served a worthy purpose.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26--Trade in wheat, corn and oats was of considerably smaller volume on the Board of Trade last week.
LIBERTYVILLE, Ill., Aug. 26 --Coming soon to your television screen: "The Man From Libertyville," with an attractive co-star.
Plans for Lawrence Welk's new Monday night television program were reported here yesterday by the American Broadcasting Company.
The city's expense budget will be higher than ever in 1957-58, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame declared yesterday.

Mrs. Morris Auerbach died yesterday of skull injuries received when an automobile pursued by the police crashed into the car driven by her dentist husband. Mrs. Auerbach, 37 years old, lived at 34 Plaza Street, Brooklyn.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug26--Harry Cooper of Metropolis, with David Wax, and Al Brosch of Woodmere, with Mitchell Jelline, shared the victory in the Hampshire Country Club's seventh annual pro-andmember charity golf tournament today.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 26--The Netherlands Bank over the week-end raised the discount rate from 3 to 3 per cent.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Aug. 26-- A five-goal flurry in the fourth chukker, led by Al Marenholz' three tallies, gave Blind Brook a 9-6 victory over Meadow Brook in a national twelve-goal championship elimination contest at the Blind Brook Polo Club today.

The untimely death of Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey takes from the American scene an important and valuable, as well as controversial, figure. Whatever may have been the reaction to his findings--and to the unscrupulous use of some of them--the fact remains that he was first, last and always a scientist.
Trial delays in civil cases throughout the nation showed little or no reduction last year, and the trend is toward even longer delays.
RAVENNA, Italy, Aug. 26-- Ezio Pinza, the famous basso, suffered a slight heart attack near here last Friday. Tonight his condition was reported to be improving.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Aug. 26--Following is the text of a White House statement on Soviet tests of nuclear weapons:
LONDON, Aug. 26--The Suez Canal Company declared today its conviction that the safety of its staff in Egypt was beyond its control.
PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 26-- Ralph Cameron's Running Wild made it two in a row today to annex Star Class series honors in the annual invitation regatta of the Domino Yacht Club.

The Coast Guard yesterday prepared to call off a search south of Nova Scotia for the missing fishing vessel Angela B. Mills after receiving word from Trepassey Bay, N.S., that the craft's seven-man crew had been picked up by another fishing boat.
DETROIT, Aug. 26--Busy Sunday hours running well into the night was Canada's strategy for overcoming the United States lead in the Harmsworth Trophy speedboat test.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26--Most steel companies last week began wiping out at least two months of orders on steel products. Only in that manner was it possible to bring some order to mill books. Even by this expedient it was believed that many steel mills still would be far behind on deliveries at the end of the year.

The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, Louisville, Ky., has purchased the Joseph Garneau Company, Inc., a century-old import house, W.L. Lyons Brown, chairman of Brown-Forman, announced over the weekend.

B. Altman Co. will open tomorrow its store on Morris Turnpike at River Road, Short Hills, N.J. The store is arranged on two principal selling levels, with a third-level penthouse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26--The success stories of twenty-one noted persons from other lands appears in a new, illustrated pamphlet published by the United States Information Agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26-- Republican officials are not the only ones who have noticed Terry Carpenter, the Nebraska delegate who almost placed "Joe Smith" in the lists for their Vice Presidential nomination.

ALBANY, Aug. 26--Justin N. Feldman, a New York lawyer, has been appointed interim director of the New York regional office of the State Department of Commerce. The regional director, Anthony B. Akers, is the Democratic nominee for Congress, Seventeenth Congressional District, in Manhattan. He is on a leave of absence.

SARAGOSSA, Spain, Aug. 16 --A few miles north of Saragossa, in northeastern Spain, the Americans are building one of the most unusual air bases of any that the United States Air Force has around the world. There are really two complete and separate bomber bases, one...

BERLIN, Aug. 26--Delegates from youth organizations of sixty-five countries concluded a two-week meeting here today with a call on Communist countries to let young people organize on a voluntary basis.

WAYNE, Me., Aug. 26--Miss Bridgid Kerr-Baulch, daughter of Mrs. Victor G. Kerr-Baulch of Surrey, England, and the late Mr. Kerr-Baulch, was married this afternoon to Charles B. Edinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward I. Edinger of Brooklyn, New York.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 16--China's 12,600,000strong Trade Union Federation is the Communist party's industrial whip-cracker.

The world premiere of the motion picture "Lust for Life," which depicts the life of Vincent van Gogh, will benefit the student fellowship program of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The event will take place on Sept. 17 in the Plaza Theatre.

The Greater New York Safety Council's mobile driving clinic will open a week-long stand in City Hall Park. Four thousand motorists are expected to take the free tests for vision and emergency reaction time. Expert advice will be available on how to correct flaws that make for unsafe driving. Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley is scheduled to open the clinic at 11 A.M.

The marriage of Miss Mae Feuer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mac Feuer of Forest Hills, Queens, to Robert Scheff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Scheff of Hempstead, L.I., took place here last evening in the Plaza. Rabbi Harry E. Schwartz performed the ceremony.
Sturdy, attractive foliage is a decoration item worth cultivating. Helpful guidance in raising plants is offered in a new course the New York Botanical Garden will conduct in October.

Tha appointment by Governor Harriman of Sherman J. Mauhs as Conservation Commissioner of the State of New York will, we hope, signal a new era for the Conservation Department. While Mr. Mauhs is not the completely nonpolitical appointee that ought to be named as a matter of course to nonpolitical agencies of government, he has ...

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 26 (UP)--Sven Davidson of Sweden won the men's singles final of the Istanbul international lawn tennis tournament today with an 11--9, 8--6, 6--1 victory over Budge Patty of the United States.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26 --America's prospects of winning back the Davis Cup looked anything but propitious today as Australia's crack combination of Lewis Hoad and Kenneth Rosewall scored a conclusive victory in the final of our Diamond Jubilee national tennis doubles championship.

CAEN, France, Aug. 26 (UP)-- Harry Schell, an American living in Paris, won the Grand Prix de Caen today. He drove his Maserati over the 153-mile circuit in 1 hour 54 minutes 19 seconds for an average speed of 80,305 miles an hour.

The assistant chief of the New York Public Library's circulation department, Miss Margaret Wehler, will retire on Friday after a twenty-nineyear career of library service. Miss Harriet E. Kemp, Richmond regional librarian, will succeed her.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Aug. 26 (AP) --Candidates of the governing National Front won overwhelmingly in today's elections to fill ten vacancies in the Constituent Assembly. Only one Opposition candidate ran, and he lost. The results showed Premier Habib Bourguiba still had the bulk of the people behind him.

Miss Ann Kay Honig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lou Honig of Brooklyn, and Stanley Seeb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Seeb of Englewood, N.J., were married last evening in the Brooklyn Jewish Center. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Israel H. Levinthal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26-- Foreign-owned assets in this country last year reached the record level of $29,600,000,000 the Government reported today. The figure compares with $26,800,000,000 in 1954.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 (AP) --Two sororities, Delta Zeta and Delta Sigma Epsilon, announced today they would merge into one national sorority of 43,000 college students and alumnae.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 26 --Miss Judith M. Dinhaupt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dinhaupt of Massapequa, was ...
