THE Pharmacie Legoll specializes in French herbs, drugs, liqueur components and imported nostrums dear to the hearts and palates of Gallic patrons all over the United States. It seems a tiny shop, hidden behind a pale green and gold front at 581 Tenth Avenue, above Forty-second Street, but behind a modest partition it swells out in vast space crowded with French stock.
The promotions of George W. Dietz and C. Albert Rollenhagen from assistant vice presidents to vice presidents was announced over the weekend by the Irving Trust Company.

CAIRO, Aug. 26 (Reuters)-- The Egyptian Customs Administration published statistics today revealing that 26 per cent of Egypt's exports had gone to the Eastern bloc in 1955 compared with 14 per cent the previous year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) --The Maritime Administration reported today that the United States had 373 merchant ships on the Great Lakes at the end of last year compared to 261 vessels owned by Canadians. The Canadians had thirty-seven tankers to twenty-four for the United States.
FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 26 --The united labor movement's hierarchy started gathering today for a meeting that will determine labor's role in the Presidential campaign.
HILLSIDE, N.J., Aug. 26 (AP) --Phil Rizzuto, a New York Yankee shortstop since 1941, today said his release by the club was a shock.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 28 --Ann Voorhees of Short Hills, N.J., dominated the third day of the Monmouth County Horse Show today.
DETROIT, Aug. 26--The Studemaker-Packard Corporation reported today a loss of $35,465,456 during the six months ended June 30.
CAIRO, Aug. 26--Egyptian intelligence officers ordered three Western newspaper correspondents today to leave the country in twenty-four hours. No reasons were given for the expulsions.

TOGUS, Me., Aug. 26 (AP)-- Yonkers, paced by Don Dichiarra's grand slam, captured the first game of a double elimination series with Everett, Mass., 10--0, today in the Section A final of the Junior American Legion baseball tourney.
LONDON, Aug. 26--Operations on the stock market were at an unusually low level this week, but there were relatively few fluctuations in price.

ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP)-- Governor Harriman today invited Adlai E. Stevenson, his successful rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination to stay at the Executive Mansion on Sept. 10. Mr. Stevenson is to address his party's state convention in Albany that day. He accepted the Governor's invitation, subject to the needs of his schedule.
New wage proposals by both union and Western Electric Company negotiators were offered yesterday.

ORTISEI, Italy, Aug. 26 (UP) --Mrs. Thelma Long of Australia won the women's final in the fourth Ortisei international tennis tournament today with a 6--0, 6--2 victory over Signorina Lazzarino of Italy. Nicola Pietrangeli of Italy beat Giuseppe Merlo, 6--3, 4--6, 4--6, 6--2, 6--2, in the men's final.

LONDON, Aug. 26--The British Government charged today that Archbishop Makarios, exiled Ethnarch of Cyprus, had personally directed the terrorist activities of the National Organization of Cypriote Fighters (E.O.K.A.).

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. Aug. 26 (AP)--Two associates accused of having conspired with Orville E. Hodge, former state auditor, in a million dollar swindle face arraignment tomorrow. They are Edward A. Epping, Hodge's office manager, and Edward A. Hintz, Chicago banker. Both are expected to plead innocent.

Mrs. Beatrice Benjamin Cartwright, an heiress who was prominent in society in this country and abroad, died Saturday at her villa in Cap d'Antibes, France, after a long illness. Her New York home was at 820 Fifth Avenue.
A 16-year-old Queens boy was killed last night at a Coney Island shooting gallery when a bullet from his companion's target rifle struck him in the chest.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 26--The new pet dog in the John Blazi home here can thank Yale University for his name.

HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 26 (AP)--Soviet President Kliment Y. Voroshilov hailed Finnish-Soviet relations today as an example to the world of peaceful coexistence. "Nothing can cloud our relations," he said in an interview as he departed for Moscow after a five-day visit to Finland.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., Aug. 26-- District Attorney Joseph Gagliardi will seek prompt grand jury action against Edward F. Eckwerth, 29-year-old coffee salesman, held without bail in the Westchester County jail here in the death of Rosemarie Spezzo.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 26 (Reuters)--President Theodor Heuss of West Germany attended the 800th anniversary celebration today of the founding of the Maria Laach Abbey, about twenty miles south of here. The abbey once hid West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer from the Nazis after they deposed him as Mayor of Cologne in 1933.

Because of geographical factors reports of the latest Red Chinese incursions in northern Burma take on more significance than those that have gone before. The threat is more clearly pointed up and the Red Chinese action is apparently more reckless.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Aug., 26 (AP)--The Moral ReArmament movement today was credited with averting "a war without mercy" between France and Tunisia.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26 (AP) --A party of five Margate boatmen escaped with only minor blisters today when an explosion sank their cabin cruiser in flames about 1,500 yards off shore.
OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 26 (AP)--Mrs. Millard E. Tydings announced today she would ask the state's Democrats to name her to the Senatorial nomination relinquished by her husband one week ago.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 26--To the young went the top prize in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association fourball championship that was concluded at the Spring Brook Country Club today. Stan Mosel, 24, and Al Mengert, 27, trounced Tommy Harmon, 57, and Jack Mitchell, 55, by 7 and 5 in the final of this pro-pro best-ball tournament.
CAIRO, Aug. 26 (AP)--Egypt has started stamping her outbound mail with a big cancellation slogan reading: "Free navigation of the Suez Canal guaranteed."
Suctions without and pressures within may shatter the sterling area before long, according to Philip W. Bell, author of "The Sterling Area in the Postwar World."

TAMPICO, Mexico, Aug. 26 (AP)--Mexican wetbacks being deported from the United States forced the old ship Mercurio Primero to put into this port today in a protest demonstration against crowded shipboard conditions.
Increasing demand for freighters to carry bulk cargoes of coal, grain and scrap metals made itself felt last Week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) --A Housing and Home Finance Agency spokesman said today the insurance industry had agreed to help the Government sell flood insurance on a subsidized basis. The industry is convinced, he said, that flood policies cannot be sold on a break-even basis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) --Purchase of arms by Latin American countries from nations other than the United States is endangering United States military leadership in the Western Hemisphere, Representative Porter Hardy Jr., Democrat of Virginia, said today.
ASBURY PARK, Aug. 26-- After two rounds of the Atlantic Coast championship sponsored by the United States Chess Federation, four were tied tonight for first place with scores of 2--0.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) --The district office of the United States Army Engineers has announced that it will spend nearly $11,000,000 million dollars on the Delaware River in the year ending next July "for maintenance and improvement."

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 26 --A four-foot earthwork barrier is rising on the center strip of a seven-and-a-halfmile stretch of the Garden State Parkway. Its purpose is to prevent headlight glare from annoying drivers coming the other way.
BERLIN, Aug. 26--An all-day celebration marked the departure today from Oranienburg of seventy Soviet fighter planes and an unspecified number of troops of the 221st Air Division.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) --Democrats will start consolidating the operations of their 1956 Presidential campaign tomorrow, but under three roofs instead of one.

DUBLIN, Aug. 26 (Reuters)-- Trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra honored Ireland's President Sean T. O'Kelly on his seventy-fourth birthday here yesterday when they presented to him a score, especially commissioned for the orchestra and a gold medal struck on the symphony's seventy-fifth anniversary.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 26 --Two host club skippers, Horst Orbanowski with his Atlantic, Ann, and John Judge, with his S boat, Celerity, triumphed today in the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club's regatta.

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Barrett of Wilton, Conn., on Friday in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mrs. Barrett is the former Miss Mary Ellin Berlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Berlin of New York. The child, who will be named for her mother, is a granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Barrett of San Diego, Calif.
James Michael Curley, nonpareil of Boston Irish politicians, plans to have the last hurrah. He has found a publisher for his version of his life story.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) --Some 9,000 metal workers are expected to resume work at nine plants in five states tomorrow with the end of the twenty-fiveday strike against the Reynolds Metals Company.
America's Christians were called upon yesterday to give articulate witness to their faith as a means of sharing it with their "spiritually hungry" countrymen.
Two 16-year-old boys were arrested on felonious assault charges yesterday when identified as having been among the assailants of an off-duty patrolman who tried to stop a Brooklyn street fight.

Mount Vernon Mills of Baltimore has acquired the assets and assumed the liabilities of the Newnan Cotton Mills. T.M. Bancroft, president of Mount Vernon Mills, said stockholders of the Newnan, Ga., company on Aug. 23 ratified the disposal of the property for 100,000 shares of Mount Vernon common.

Michael Mutolese, production manager, has been promoted to vice president in charge of manufacturing and production for H. Daroff Sons, Inc., and the House of Worsted-tex, Inc., Michael Daroff, president, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (UP)--A film on high school football rules will be produced this fall at Redlands, Calif., the National Federation of State High School Athletic Associations announced today. The film will be made available to the organization's forty-seven-member state high school athletic associations for use in rules training programs.

GALVESTON, Tex., Aug 26 (AP)--The immediate family of Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias gathered around her bedside today as physicians reported she lost ground last night in her fight against cancer.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 26-- More than 10,000 lawyers and jurists were gathering in Dallas today for the seventy-ninth annual meeting of the American Bar Association.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 26-- One of Argentina's leading intellectual societies announced last night it had suspended the membership of an editor who publicly declared there was limited freedom of the press in the country.
James McCutcheon Co., department store operator, has named Jack E. Lewis president.

The Ford Foundation has granted $195,000 to Columbia University's School of Law. The money is to be used for a threeyear study of economic cooperation between industrialized and economically under-developed countries. Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of the university, made the announcement yesterday.

The eighth annual Virginia World Trade Conference will take place Oct. 4 and 5 in Richmond, Va. William T. Watkins, general chairman of the conference, said yesterday that more than 500 business men, students and transportation executives were expected to attend.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week rose 17 to 34 points, with the greater advances registered by the more distant deliveries. The week before, prices closed up 22 to down 5 points.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP)--Bob Friend of the Pittsburgh Pirates blanked the last-place Chicago Cubs, 2--0, on four hits today and then came back in the eighth inning of the second game to preserve a 2-1 victory for Ronnie Kline.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP)--Bob Friend of the Pittsburgh Pirates blanked the last-place Chicago Cubs, 2--0, on four hits today and then came back in the eighth inning of the second game to preserve a 2-1 victory for Ronnie Kline.
SHELTER ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 26--Freckle, sailed by Herbert and Al Blake, today won the Donald Abbott Memorial Trophy, emblematic of the Long Island Sound Wood Pussy championship.

The Republican and Democratic conventions played to surprisingly small television audiences, a study by a Philadelphia research organization asserts. The study, made by Sindlinger Co., Inc., tended to confirm rumors that statistically the political sessions might emerge as a rather formidable television flop.
The Port of New York Authority has set Sept. 26 as the official opening date of the Manhattan heliport at West Thirtieth Street and the Hudson River.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 26-- Jordan has prepared her own irrigation plan in the Jordan River valley for using the waters of the Yarmuk River. The next session of Parliament in November is expected to vote 500,000 Jordanian dinars ($1,400,000) for the initial work on it.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 26-- A second suit was filed in Maryland last week seeking to prevent integration of public schools.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (UP)--Gordon Pirie, an Olympic distance runner, will be using his legs more than usual this week. His car was stolen last night.
EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Aug. 26 (AP)--The Eau Claire Braves clinched their second straight Northern League pennant last night by defeating the St. Cloud Rox, 6--4.

ATHENS, Aug. 26 (Reuters) --Authoritative sources close to the Greek Government said tonight that British charges against Archbishop Makarios were aimed at diverting world opinion from the Archbishop's conciliatory terms for a solution of the Cyprus problem. The sources said:

CLINTON, Tenn., Aug. 26 (UP) --The executive secretary of the Seaboard White Citizens Council was jailed tonight on charges of "inciting a riot" by encouraging picketing at a high school scheduled to integrate white and Negro students tomorrow.
ROME, Aug. 26 (UP)--Motorists have to detour around one of the busiest intersections in Rome so vibration will be minimized in the vicinity of the Colosseum.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26--The entire Arab world will rise to Support Egypt by all means, including battle, if Britain and France try to impose international operation of the Suez Canal, the Arab League's observer at the United Nations said today.

BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 26 (AP) --A giant landslide today blocked traffic through the Brenner Pass, the Alpine lifeline between Italy and Austria. Hundreds of workers were called in to clear the highway and railway which were clogged by about 1,000 cubic yards of rock for 100 yards. Experts said they hoped to have the pass open again by tomorrow night.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 (AP)-- The Philadelphia Phillies belted sixteen hits today in trouncing the Cincinnati Redlegs, 11--4, in the second game of a doubleheader. The Redlegs took the opener, 10--5.
SELINA TIPPETT didn't like life in London during the blitz any more than any one else. She had troubles enough of her own without raids and bombs and noise and nights without sleep.

NEWARK, Aug. 26 (AP)-- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said tonight he intended to ask the Legislature on Sept. 17 to approve a cent-a-gallon gasoline tax increase. He said the money would help the state raise funds to improve its highway system.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) --The Weather Bureau said today its tornado warning system had helped to save thousands of lives.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (UP)--Arthur Larson, Under Secretary of Labor, said today there was little difference between the political philosophies of President Eisenhower and Adlai E. Stevenson.

ALL over the land now, tanned, sinewy young men who have been swinging picks and shovels, working in construction gangs, driving trucks, serving as life guards and been otherwise gainfully employed in hard labor outdoors are about to head back to the campus.
A 69-year-old widowed father of ten children was fatally wounded on a bench near the Manhattan end of the Triborough Bridge early yesterday. He had been stabbed in the thigh.
The New York-Buffalo Thruway will be opened for its entire 427-mile length Friday with completion of the last three-mile leg through Yonkers to the Bronx line.

At present the most important country on the Asiatic mainland, in terms of what President Eisenhower calls our "enlightened self-interest," is India. Like Soviet Russia, which is as much Asian as European, and like Communist China, India is in the throes of revolution.
Once again an illegal strike against the public by civil service employes has brought punishment no more severe than a tap on the wrist.

LIBERTYVILLE, Ill., Aug. 26 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Payne Kellogg of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheila Kellogg, to Ludwell Ebersole Gaines Jr., son of Mrs. Gaines of Fayetteville, W. Va., and the late Mr. Gaines. A Thanksgiving Day wedding is planned.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 26-- Wendy Hanson, Sydney Gadd, Michael Plumb and Sandy Glynn took the major honors as the seventeenth annual Fairfield County Junior Hunt Club horse show closed today.

WATERWAYS, Alberta, Aug. 19--This man-made river port at the end of the rail line in northern Alberta, 250 miles north of Edmonton, is having the greatest boom since its establishment about twenty years ago.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 26 (AP)--The Known death toll of a windstorm that struck Germany yesterday rose today to ten. The police said seven were killed in West Germany, one in Berlin and two in East Germany. Damage from the storm was estimated unofficially at $1,000,000.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 (AP)-- Ted Corbett of the New York Pioneer Club won the National Amateur Athletic Union thirtykilometer championship today. He topped a field of fifteen runners over a one-mile course at near-by Lunken Airport.
TELEVISION has sharpened its focus on interior dec orating to such an extent that some viewers consider a piece of furniture the star of a performance.
The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended June 30 net income of $5,871,506, or $3.60 a share.
A Transit Authority patrolman was arrested in Queens yesterday after having admitted that he had shot and killed a man with his service revolver, according to the police.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 26-- Angelo John La Marca, who the police say has confessed the kidnapping of Peter Weinberger, was questioned again today by Inspector Stuyvesant A. Pinnell, chief of Nassau County detectives.
The Coliseum listed yesterday twenty-seven public expositions and trade shows to be held in the next ten months in New York's $35,000,000 exhibition hall at Columbus Circle.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP)--A group of great star clusters in the far distant reaches of the universe is rushing to outer space at a speed of 75,000 miles a second, an astronomer from Mount Wilson and Palomar Observatories reported today.

DEAUVILLE, France, Aug. 2 (AP)--Tall Chief, owned by the Aga Khan, today won the 1,000 000-franc ($20,000) Grand Pu de Deauville over a 2,600-meter course. Tall Chief, a son of Theran and La Li, was followed by Montval and Claudion III.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $72,353,237,627.
The Collegium Musicum will give an open-air chamber music concert tonight at 9 o'clock in Washington Square Park under the direction of Fritz Rikko.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (UP)--The San Francisco FortyNiners won their second National Football League exhibition game today by defeating the Washington Redskins, 20--0, before a sun-baked crowd of 27,812 in Kezar Stadium.

Nicholas J. Stockhammer, retired treasurer of the Great Northern Railway, died Friday night in Kings Highway Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. His age was 72. He lived at 163 Clinton Avenue, Jersey City.

The eighty-seven-year-old Welch Grape Juice Company has been sold for $28,600,000 to a group of farmers banded together as the National Grape Co-Operative Association, Westfield, N.Y. Douglas M. Moorhead is president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) --The United States Navy today eased restrictions it had placed on Far East news and picture coverage of developments in the downing of a Navy patrol plane in international waters off the coast of Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UP) --Representative Walter Nor blad, Republican of Oregon, said today the development of the intercontinental ballistic missile would bring this country "close to push-button warfare." Mr. Norblad spoke on the American Broadcasting Company television program "Celebrities Parade."
LIBERTYVILLE, Ill., Aug. 26. --Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator Estes Kefauver set out tomorrow to cultivate local Democratic organizations and raise money.

Other signs of approaching fall, besides the lengthening shadows, are the growing activities along Shubert Row. Today four shows will assemble their casts in rehearsal halls, small studios and temporarily unoccupied theatre stages to take their initial steps toward Broadway materialization.
Properties in Brooklyn Heights were among realty holdings passing to new control in deals reported over the week-end.
In the operation of the State Department's program for International Exchange of Persons we are to have the pleasure of entertaining two distinguished editors from India.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Aug. 26--Lawrence Rust Hills of 434 Roslyn Road, a retired sales executive of the General Electric Company, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
The appointment of Roger Bumstead as media director of MacManus, John Adams, Inc., was announced over the week-end.
"When we attend mass it is the same as if we were present at Calvary," the Rev. Francis Degnan said yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral during the 10 A.M. solemn mass.

NEW BEDFORD, Ill. Aug. 26 (AP)--Bob Harding of New Bedford, Ill., opened the International Softball League world tournament tonight by hurling a perfect 2-0 triumph over Providence, R.I. Handing, a righthander, retired twenty-one men in order in the seven-inning contest.
Reserpine, a tranquilizer drug, has been produced in radioactive form. It will be used at Columbia University in studies of physiological and bio-chemical actions in the animal body.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 26 (AP)--Mike Souchak of Grossinger, N.Y., finished with six straight birdies and a record-tying 62 for 271 to win the St. Paul open golf tournament today. Souchak had started the day seven strokes behind the leader, Don January of Lampasas, Tex.
LONDON, Aug. 26--The staff of the five-nation negotiating delegation headed by Mr. Menzies waited till late tonight for a message from President Nasser.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26--The grain market became overbought last week. In the absence of aggressive buying support, prices declined as futures were liquidated by longs.

NEWARK, Aug. 27--Charges of unfair labor practices were filed today against Local 825 of the International Union of Operating Engineers with the New York regional office of the National Labor Relations Board.
The acid blinding of Victor Riesel and the execution of the thug who threw the acid were ordered by the same person, United States Attorney Paul W. Williams said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- United States officials persist in optimism about the prospects for negotiations with Egypt.
MILFORD, Mich., Aug, 27--A vice president of the General Motors Corporation made a strong defense today for putting high-powered engines into modern cars.

The world's most powerful high seas towing vessel, the 4,200-horsepower Dutch Diesel tug Zwarte Zee, is pausing at an East Coast port between two long-distance towing jobs that will cover almost 10,000 nautical miles.

UNION CITY, N.J., Aug. 27 --Lewis B. Eastmead, an assistant Hudson County counsel, former Mayor of Union City and member of this city's first City Commission, died today at his home, 1201 Central Avenue. His age was 72.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug 27--The American Bar Association was warned today that concentration of power in the Federal Government, particularly the Executive Branch, threatened to destroy United States political institutions.
MOST adults who earnestly desire their children to be neat are neat people themselves. In helping youngsters develop habits of tidiness, this parental quality can prove either a blessing or a bane.

PARIS, Aug. 27--An attempt to explore and photograph the Italian liner Andrea Doria on the bottom off Nantucket Light is planned by the French underwater experts who helped produce the book and motion picture "The Silent World."
The first national convention of the Communist Party of the U.S.A. since 1950 is to be held in this city next Feb. 9 to 12, the party's national committee announced yesterday.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 27 --Ian Fraser of the Larchmont Yacht Club, sailing Phantom, held a quarter-point lead in the fourth annual Long Island Sound invitation Blue Jay regatta after two races today off Pequot Yacht Club. He had 90 points.
The proposal to sell the city's rapid transit power plants and purchase power from the Consolidated Edison Company was vigorously opposed yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 27--British officials are hopeful that the direct talks they are to have with Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta will solve the controversy with the Mediterranean island colony over economic and other questions.

CAIRO, Aug. 27--President Gamal Abdel Nasser mapped plans today for negotiating with the Western-sponsored five-nation Suez Canal committee on the basis of all proposals made at the recent London conference, informed sources said.
FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 27 --The united labor movement got tough today with three scandal-linked unions.
Retail coffee prices made the predicted ascent yesterday, with increases averaging four cents a pound.
The Hilton Hotels Corporation achieved record gross revenue and net income in the first six months of this year, Conrad N. Hilton, president of the chain, reported yesterday.
Shipping on order or under construction at Norwegian shipyards is nearing the 1,000,000gross-ton mark as the result of a flood of new orders received during the first half of this year.

PARIS, Aug. 27--Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin, generally identified as a spokesman for ultraconservative French colonials, proposed tonight the grant of a large measure of internal autonomy to Algeria.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP)-- Bernie Katz, a 215-pound manufacturer, led twenty-four Chicago area qualifiers today for the United States amateur golf championship tournament to be held at Lake Forest, Ill., Sept. 10-15.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 27--The largest field of the season for a Westchester Golf Association pro-amateur tournament, 128 teams, turned out for this week's test at Fenway Country Club today.

NOVOSIBIRSK, U.S.S.R., Aug. 26--Nikita S. Khrushchev's dream of making Siberia into a vast granary may turn into a nightmare unless rain, bungling and nature can be brought under control soon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27--Most grain and soybean futures prices declined in early trading today on the Board of Trade. Selling diminished on the drops, and there were rallies in rye and wheat, which failed to hold. Corn was heavy throughout the session, and soybeans failed to recover early losses.

Net sales of the KimberlyClark Corporation in the quarter ended July 31 rose to $62,990,772 from $56,941,574 a year before. Net earnings, however, were little changed, totaling $4,707,385 against $4,901,188.
Tight money and political and industrial uncertainties created a wait-and-see tone in the stock market yesterday.
MEMPHIS, Aug. 27 (AP)--Lloyd T. Binford, long regarded by the movie industry as the nation's toughest censor, died in a nursing home today. He was 89 years old.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 27--Roy Campanella hit a three-run single in the eighth inning off long Gene Conley today and plunged 42,290 County Stadium fans into gloom.
ROME, Aug. 27--Pietro Nenni, Left-wing Socialist leader, confirmed today that a merger between his party and Giuseppe Saragat's Right-wing Socialists was in the making.

Since press box tenants bear little resemblance to ostritches--the exceptions are too rare to rate mentioning--a guy returning to work immediately finds himself confronted by a disagreeable event. CINCINNATI, Aug. 27--Now that he is virtually sure of being retained as manager of the Giants, Bill Rigney is going to start asking for things. Nothing unreasonable and, in one request, not even original, but he knows what he wants and he hopes to get it.
MELBOURNE, Australia,--Aug. 16--China's leaders are proud of what has been done in three and a half years of their first fiveyear plan.

The Southern Railway and Seaboard Air Line Railroad offered yesterday to acquire joint control of the Florida East Coast Railway from bondholders when that raliroad is reorganized.
BARNSTABLE VILLAGE, Mass., Aug. 27--The Cape Cod Tuna Tournament opened today with a reverberating squeak.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 27-- Jordan's Chief of Staff asserted today that war between Britain and Egypt would inevitably lead to an alliance of the Arab world with the Soviet Union.

The television networks rallied quickly yesterday to rebut any suggestions that the Democratic and Republican conventions were a video failure. The politicians may not have been statistically spectacular, it was argued, but they were average.
Cotton futures were steady yesterday and advanced 1 to 39 points (5 cents to $1.95 a bale). The far months showed the most strength.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J, Aug. 27 --Leon Earl Colvin, treasurer of the Silver Burdett Company, textbook publishers, from 1942 until his retirement last June, died today at his home on Rensselaer Road here after a long illness. Mr. Colvin was 62 years old.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Aug. 27--President Eisenhower ended a four-day golfing idyl by the Pacific today and prepared to return to the White House and politics tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27--The Democratic National Committee's 1956 campaign "Fact Book," now being mailed to party leaders around the country, puts major emphasis on the question of President Eisenhower's health.
CAIRO, Aug. 27--Egyptian authorities arrested two Britons and four Egyptians today on charges of spying for Britain.
Eighty scholars returned yesterday to a subject they believe still needs clarification--the meaning of human equality.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 27-- The state Democratic convention voted today to pledge its Presidential electors to support Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator Estes Kefauver for President and Vice President in the November elections.
DETROIT, Aug. 27--The British international trophy race for the famous Harmsworth award was tied today by a Canadian triumph over the United States on the second leg.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP)--Mrs. John D. Hertz' La, Parisienne, with Eddie Arcard astride, defeated the favored C.V. Whitney's Gun Fly by a nose in the seven-furlong Susquehanna Handicap today. Mrs. Philip Bieber's Roman Princess was third in the field of seven 3-year-old fillies.

ARANJUEZ, Spain, Aug. 18-- About thirty-five miles south of here, a complicated earth-moving machine is digging a threefoot ditch slowly and steadily across the Manchegan plain just east of the village of Manzaneque.

The border between the United States and Canada provides a lesson in international goodwill. Orators on both sides are fond of saying this, and indeed the truth of the statement lingers long after the temporary platforms and bunting of oratory have been taken down.

An agreement wes reached yesterday between the Western Electric Company and the Communication Workers of America on ternis for a new one-year contract. A company spokesman said the pact provided for increases of 8 to 12 cents an hour, plus fringe benefits.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 27--Maryland's faction-ridden Democrats picked George P. Mahoney tonight as their Senatorial candidate to replace former Senator Millard E. Tydings.
The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation of Louisville, Ky., has acquired the Joseph Garneau Company, Inc., an import horse, through purchase of stock. The price was not disclosed.
DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP)--The nation's auto plants built fewer than 70,000 cars last week. The General Motors Corporation accounted for 58,000 of them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27-- The Department of Agriculture announced today it had begun the Administration's Rural Development Program in fifty-five low-income counties of twentyfour states.

That the Soviet Union set off another nuclear explosion in Central Asia should not astonish newspaper readers--thirteen announcements of Soviet nuclear explosions have been made by the United States Government since 1949.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's backlog of orders is at a peacetime high of $1,390,648,000, up 31 per cent above the level a year ago. Robert E. Gross, president, reported the figure yesterday in announcing first-half earnings of $7,534,000, which equaled $2.66 a share.
SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 27-- Adlai E. Stevenson opened his 1956 campaign after a crowded reception here today.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 26 --President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla denounced today what he called a "campaign of unjust discredit to Colombia" in the foreign press.
SANFORD, Fla., Aug. 27 (UP) --A damaged Navy bomber caught its wing on a pine tree while seeking a spot to land today and slammed into two houses.
The installation of the city's career and salary plan was the "outstanding achievement" in 1955, of the Department of Personnel, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.

Jean Shepherd, the offbeat personality who was dropped by radio station WOR for presenting an unsponsored commercial in behalf of Sweetheart soap, had a new job offer yesterday, it came from Sweetheart soap, which wants to sponsor him (paid time, that is) on WOR.

Another filter-tip cigarette is about to make its appearance nationally. The newcomer, a product of the American Tobacco Company, has been tested and will be marketed before the year-end, it was announced yesterday by Paul M. Hahn, president.

In the last five years the Greens of West Sixty-first Street have, with an increasing number of children, kept one jump ahead of slum clearers' steam shovels. Now they have decided to fight City Hall rather than move again.

ULAN BATOR, Outer Mongolia, Aug. 27--More than 10,000 Chinese have come to the Mongolian People's Republic during the last year to help fill manpower needs in industry, agriculture and building construction, officials here have disclosed.
Jerry Luedee, a New Haven, Conn., middleweight, stopped Bob Provizzi of Brooklyn in the sixth round of the main bout listed for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 27--A Soviet invitation to visit Moscow has women delegates at the United Nations in something of a dilemma.

Cocoa prices fell yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange on the second heaviest volume since 1941. The 841 lots (30,000 pounds to a lot) compares with the recent high of 865 on April 12. Final quotations dropped 59 to 72 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).
HONG KONG, Aug. 27--A young American physician who holds the highest South Vietnamese decoration for heroism said here today he had returned to Asia to fight communism with medicine.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 27-- Gov. Thomas B. Stanley called on an applauding state legislature today to use its power of the purse to fight racial integration of Virginia's public schools.
New York waterfront employers told the International Longshoremen's Association yesterday that they wanted no part of a coast-wide collective bargaining agreement.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Wednesday, Aug. 29 (AP)--A bomb tossed at the home of a British Army major ripped Nicosia's uneasy stillness early today.

Television and radio reporting of major fires and disasters should be delayed "at least fifteen minutes" to permit firemen to get to the scene unimpeded by swarms of sight-seers, a New Jersey fire chief said yesterday.

ASHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 28-- Miss Edna Pennypacker Stauffer of 125 East Sixty-third Street, New York, retired Assistant Professor of Art at Hunter College and for many years a summer resident here, died here yesterday. Her age was 73.
MRS. IRVING HUSNEY, a sightless clerk at the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, called the maintenance man in the low-rent housing project at 1536 Lexington Avenue at 9:30 o'clock the other night.

Commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light in most markets, but cocoa registered the third largest number of sales this year, and hides, the fourth largest.

The Ocean Drilling and Exploration Company, which operates submersible oil drilling barges and holds oil and gas leases in offshore waters of the Gulf of Mexico, is making a subscription offering of 208,395 additional shares to holders of its common stock.

DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 28--A New York broker described to lawyers here today the role of "people's capitalism" in the "miracle of American wealth."

W.C. Hamilton Sons, makers of high-grade printing and book paper, plan to split the common stock on a two-for-one basis and increase the authorized shares to 600,000 from 200,000. Stockholders will vote on the proposals at a special meeting Oct. 24.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Senator John Marshall Butler, Republican of Maryland, opened his campaign for re-election today in both Baltimore and Washington.

DETROIT, Aug. 28--James B. Webber Jr., executive vice president and general manager of Detroit's largest department store, the J.L. Hudson Company, died last night of a heart attack while on vacation in northern Michigan near Alpena. He was 44 years old.
Former Premier Imre Nagy, the "Malenkov of Hungary," has been readmitted to the Hungarian Workers (Communist) party, the Yugoslav Communist organ Borba reports.
Legislation is being prepared with the aim of changing the City Charter provisions relating to such concessions as the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 28 --Bert Kohlmann, a southpaw golfer from the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club, led the metropolitan qualifiers for the United States Golf Association amateur championship today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28-Wheat and soybean futures prices declined in early trading today on the Board of Trade, but prices later rallied from the lows.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--Secretary of State Dulles gave Egypt's President a tentative pat on the back and assailed the Soviet Government today for its tactics in the crisis over the Suez Canal.
Hundreds of thousands of dollars a year will be saved by railroad and bus passengers in the New York metropolitan area because of the easing of the 10 per cent Federal transportation tax next month.
Egyptian President Nasser's decision to meet with the five-nation committee set up by the London conference on the Suez Canal is a constructive move.

THIS is in the nature of a delayed report. It was assembled during a visit to Bur lington, Vt., Where the New York Football Giants were flexing their muscles in preparation for the forthcoming season. Circumstances beyond control prevented the report from berg presented earlier. It will be filed in absentia because the Giants already have fled to the Pacific northwest for exhibition games.
A third waterfront representation election between rival longshore unions in the Port of New York became a virtual certainty yesterday.

Miss Maud M. Mason, an artist who was known for her paintings of flowers, died late yesterday in Manhattan General Hospital of a heart ailment. Her age was 89. A charter member of the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, she had occupied a topfloor apartment there for the last fourteen years.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 5 to 18 points yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 28-- Dr. Frederick Leroy Hutson, professor emeritus of classics at Princeton University, died today in the Sun Lawn Nursing Home, Hightstown, after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

Taking a forthright step to hasten their rebuilding, the Giants yesterday signed Mike Francis McCormick, a 17-yearold left-handed pitcher from Bakersfield, Calif., to a bonus contract believed to call for a sum in excess of $60,000.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28-- Two large-scale research projects into mysteries of the human brain are being started by two California scientific centers. The studies are being supported by grants of the Ford Foundation of nearly $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --Canned tuna may be put under a mandatory Federal standards that would require accurate labeling to describe the contents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--A study of recent Soviet press and radio dispatches supports the charge of Secretary of State Dulles today that Moscow is trying to make it hard for Egypt to negotiate any kind of Suez settlement without losing face.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company established new records in sales and earnings for the nine months ended July 31, according to the results announced yesterday by David L. Luke Jr., president.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Aug. 28 (UP)--The Secretary of Agriculture scored the Democratic farm plank today as "a tossed salad of inaccuracies, half truths, platitudes and promises impossible to fulfill."

ALBANY, Aug. 28 (AP)--With more than 3,500,000 New Yorkers protected by the Salk vaccine, poliomyelitis has stricken only about a third the number of persons in the State so far this year than it did in 1955.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 28--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Eulis Cobb of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Ruth Cobb, to Lieut. David Byron Diver of the Air Force. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Martin Diver of West Henrietta, N.Y.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28--The Dodgers today blew a chance to make a substantial gain on the league-leading Braves when they lost the second game of a double-header to the Cubs, 4--3, after winning the opener, 6--4.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28--The Oliver Corporation, manufacturer of farm equipment, reported today that its net earnings for the nine months ended July 31 dropped 89.9 per cent to $402,000, from $3,898,000 a year ago.

A Legal Aid Society attorney complained in Felony Court yesterday that a rule put into effect by the Department of Correction was forcing his organization to use a washroom to interview prisoners. The room is two floors above the courtroom.
DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 28-- An Indiana Representative questioned today the advisability of putting increased power in automobiles.

IN fifteen years as a labor relations expert, Theodore Woodrow Kheel has been meeting professionally two kinds of people--those who think in terms of problems and those who think in terms of solutions. The former, he finds, look for obstacles; the latter for paths of action.
Ray Bolger, the dexterous dancer, has been reinstated on the National Broadcasting Company's television schedule for the fall season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 --Carol Channing is going back to Broadway. First, the comedienne will look into a musical revue being written by Charles Gaynor, author of the 1948 revue, "Lend an Ear." She had a relatively small part in that show before becoming the toast of Manhattan in "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes."

Continued development of the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut metropolitan area in the next twenty years as the pre-eminent administrative, financial and management center of the nation was foreseen in a survey issued yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28--President Sukarno of Indonesia arrived in Moscow today for a two-week tour of the Soviet Union.

CRAMERTON, N.C., Aug. 28 (AP)--George Holden Tinkham, lawyer, big-game hunter and globe-trotter who had served fourteen terms is the United states House of Representatives, died here in his sleep today at the home of a sister, Mrs. Stuart V. Cramer Sr. His age was 85.
The Chicago Park District borrowed $12,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of serial bonds maturing on Sept. 1 from 1958 to 1976 to finance improvements.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28--Edward Seinfeld's 4year-old colt, Admiral Vee, hasn't been running in stakes, but as far as number of successes is concerned he's the champion of the Saratoga race meeting. In today's main event he started for the third time and became the first three-time winner of the meet.

Billy Rose has paved the way for Kermit Bloomgarden to proceed with "Maiden Voyage," Paul Osborn's "Olympian comedy" dealing with Greek mythology. At Mr. Osborn's request, clearance was obtained from Mr. Rose, who is abroad, in a cable to the author.
BIRMINGHAM, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Alabama voters apparently approved today constitutional changes that would permit the State Legislature to abolish public schools rather than mix Negro and white pupils.
Theodore W. Kheel accepted the post of impartial arbitrator for the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union yesterday.
BARNSTABLE VILLAGE, Mass., Aug. 28--There must be something special about tuna, and there certainly is something special about tuna anglers when they are trying to beat each other.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Dale Long smashed a three-run homer tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-4 victory over the first-place Braves.

BUFFALO, Aug. 28--After three rounds of the New York State chess championship tournament at the University of Buffalo had been completed today, George Scirabine of Syracuse, Jack W. Collins of Brooklyn and Anthony E. Santasiere of the Bronx were in a three-way tie at 3--0.
A century ago this month quarrymen at work in the Neander Valley near Duesseldorf, Germany, dug up some human bones in a cave. They were the bones of Neanderthal man.

BERLIN, Aug. 28--East Germany's legislature meets tomorrow to deal with excessive centralization in administration, The purpose is to end "the often noticeable method of keeping people in an undue state of dependence and of commanding them," according to Neues Deutschland, Communist party newspaper.

OSLO, Aug. 28--The United States automobile industry has lost the Scandinavian market this year, according to sales statistics published in Oslo today. During the first six months of the year about 88,000 new automobiles were registered in Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Only a small percentage of these cars came from the United States.
Large losses for a few speculative favorites characterized yesterday's stock market, the slowest since Aug. 15, 1955. Turnover was only 1,400,000 shares against 1,420,000 on Monday.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 28 (AP)--Miss Constance Drexel, a former feature writer for the old Philadelphia Public Ledger, died here today at the home of a cousin, Frederick Drexel. The cause of death was not immediately determined. Miss Drexel was 68 years old.

Net farm income for 1956, it is now predicted by the Department of Agriculture, will show an increase over that of 1955. If this estimate holds this will be the first annual upturn in farm net income since 1951.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP)--The American Motors Corporation announced today the signing of bank credit and long-term loan agreements of $67,570,000 to meet financial needs for the next two years.

WHEN older writes are asked by young writers for advice they usually fall back on one time-tested bit of sage counsel, "Write about what you know." It is good advice and most good writers follow it. Victor Sawdon Pritchett, who is unquestionably a good writer, has drawn on his memories ...

Mickey Mantle moved five games ahead of Babe Ruth's record sixty-homer pace of 1927 last night by walloping No. 45 as the Yankees defeated the Athletics 4-0, in an on-again off-again contest called because of rain at the end of six innings.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28--Why the Redlegs continue as solid contenders and the Giants are where they are--seventh--was obvious tonight at Crosley Field. The evidence was there as Birdie Tebbetts' Cincinnatians overwhelmed the New Yorkers, 11--1.
CAIRO, Aug. 28--Two British diplomats implicated by Egypt in an alleged spy ring here were asked today to leave the country.
TWO directors of the Paris house of Christian Dior have compiled a small but valuable booklet, "Quelques Bonnes Tables de Paris" ("Some Good Tables of Paris").
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 28 --Two 20-year-old college girls, one an Italian and the other an American, received $200 each here today to spend in two hours of shopping in a department store.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 --The cost of half-hour television scripts is going up. Hal Roach Jr., head of the Hal Roach Studio, said today that the company currently was paying approximately 25 per cent more for story material than it did last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--Following is a transcript of the record of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today, as edited and made public by the State Department:

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., ug. 28--A blacksmith shop that had stood since 1870 on an estate in Armonk received a hazardous ride atop a truck today. The trip was to its new permanent home in Rochambeau Park here.

Manufacturers of refrigerators, automobiles, television sets, hardware and whisky are making a concerted effort to take away from jewelers a sizable slice of the gift market, Walter B. Jaccard, chairman of the Jewelry Industry Council, said here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28--Fortysix Western railroads are preparing to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission for a freight rate increase that might range from 5 to 10 per cent above current schedules.

LONDON, Aug. 28--Egypt's agreement to meet with the delegation appointed to present a United States proposal for international operation of the Suez Canal was delivered today. No conditions were attached to the meeting by President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

LONDON, Aug. 28--The British Government announced tonight its consent to the sale of the Trinidad Oil Company to the Texas Company. Earlier it had given its approval in principle, subject to certain conditions.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 28 (AP)--The leader of Tallahassee's Negro boycott against segregated city buses was arrested today for the second straight day for driving a car-pool automobile without a "For Hire" sign.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 22-- The United States Strategic Air Command's base, 25 miles southeast of Seville at Moron de la Frontera, is going to be the southernmost of the land-based planes' fields in Spain.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (UP)--Following is the text of a note from Australian Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies to Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser proposing a conference on the Suez Canal, as broadcast by the Cairo radio:

PORT SAID, Egypt, Aug. 27-- The old Suez Canal Company maintained rigorous training standards for pilots. Between seven and ten years' experience was usually required before a pilot was appointed to the senior class, which permitted him to navigate ships of about 25,000 tons. Some years more were needed for appointment as a major pilot to take through the largest vessels.

Two Australians, Lewis Hoad, the Wimbledon champion, and Kenneth Rosewall, were seeded first and second, respectively, yesterday in the draw for the National singles tennis championships. Richard Savitt also was accorded a place in the favored group.

MORE than 10,000 buyers for fancy food stores all over the country wandered through the Sheraton-Astor Hotel's grand ballroom this week. Order blanks in hand, they nibbled here and there among the 4,000 delicacies, some domestic, some imported, assembled for the second annual National Fancy Food and Confection Show, which closes today.

The Western Union Telegraph company announced yesterday it had reached an agreement to purchase a minority interest in the Teleprompter Corporation through acquisition of 20,000 authorized but unissued shares of the company.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug. 28 (UP)--The national convention of the Constitution Party of the United States recommended to its state organizations today that they "draft" T. Coleman Andrews, former Internal Revenue Commissioner as a Presidential candidate.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn will offer Saturday banking hours, starting next Saturday, at its sidewalk tellers' windows, which are outside the entrance to its main office at DeKalb Avenue and Fulton Street.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Aug. 28 (AP)--A gradual integration plan for Little Rock schools was upheld today by a Federal district court.

MADRID, Aug. 28 (Reuters) --One of the most elaborate floating exhibitions ever organized has sailed from Bilbao on a 10,000-mile trip to Central and South America to foster trade and tourism between the American nations and Spain.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 28-- Attorneys for Angelo John La Marca, confessed kidnapper of Peter Weinberger, asserted today that his defense would be based on a plea of insanity.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) --The United States may be able to stop adding to its mountain of surplus cotton by next year, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

GENEVA, Aug. 28--Spokesmen from Arab and Communist countries have been making the most of recent sessions of the United Nations conference on slavery to snipe at Britain. Today, however, a spirit of conciliation was evident and the business of the conference proceeded fairly quietly.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 28--The Foreign Office and the Marine Ministry have opened separate investigations into reports of a mutiny off Tampico Sunday aboard the Mexican ship Mercurio One.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Erie Railroad today to shift its principal Hudson River passenger terminal operations from Jersey City to Hoboken, N.J.
Critics of the city's methods of rehousing families dislocated by slum clearance decided yesterday to place a picket line in front of City Hall tomorrow morning.
Before starting on his final round against Tommy Goodwin in the Metropolitan amateur golf championship last Sunday, Willie Turnesa made some observations concerning match play.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 28 --Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru saw to it today that India's capital gave a top level official welcome to Chief Justice Earl Warren of the United States.
CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 28--Charles Kingsley Jr. of Huntington sailed to a decisive victory in the opening race of the seventh national Raven Class yacht championship today.
FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 28 --The leadership of the united labor movement gave its official support today to Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator Estes Kefauver for President and Vice President.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 28-- The chairman of a United Nations commission that adjudicates border disputes between Israel and Lebanon has been prevented by Beirut authorities from leaving Lebanon, a United Nations source in Jerusalem said tonight.
James T. Farrell, novelist, resigned yesterday as chairman of the American Committee for Cultural Freedom.
The United Nations Children's Fund will benefit as a result of the Waldorf-Astoria's Silver Anniversary Ball. The event will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the hotel the evening of Sept. 28.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 28--In his first important match on grass in several years, Richard Savitt defeated Neale Fraser of Australia today at the Westchester Country Club.
VANCOUVER, Wash., Aug. 28--Adlai E. Stevenson asserted today that he intended to sharpen the Democratic charge that President Eisenhower was a "part-time President."
ALBANY, Aug. 28 (AP)--Grasshoppers have invaded downtown Albany and Schenectady.
Mayor Wagner yesterday put off until later in the week his decision on whether to seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- The Egyptian embassy announced today that it was undertaking to recruit in the United States "highly qualified pilot captains" for service on the Suez Canal.

YONKERS, Aug. 28 (UP)-- Menace, owned by the Gray Brothers of Rhode Island and R.M. O'Connell of Massachusetts, scored a two-length victory over Mayfield Boy in tonight's Saw Mill pace at Yonkers Raceway.
EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 28-- Poor planning of land for residential uses can prove costly to real estate developers, a Chicago planning consultant warned builders and lenders today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 28 (AP)--German-born Doris G. Fuchs, 18, and her sister, Ingeborg E. Fuchs, 19, today took their oaths of United States citizenship and became eligible for America's Olympic gymnastic team.
Dual-purpose containers are assuming greater importance in the fancy food trade.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 28 --Dr. Ruslan Abdulgani, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, returned today from the London conference on the Suez Canal and from talks with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 28 --The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation today announced the acquisition of the Jack Daniel Distillery at Lynchburg, Tenn. The acquisition was de

Use of blends containing cotton and 65 per cent or more Dacron, a synthetic fiber produced by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., will increase from about 3,000,000 yards this year to about 5,000,000 yards in 1957.
The hardening attitude against school integration taken by Gov. Thomas B. Stanley of Virginia, with the backing of Senator Harry F. Byrd's Democratic organization, is discouraging but not decisive.

WEST HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 28--Mr. and Mrs. Arthur, Bickel have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Grace Bickel of New York, to Robert C. Mix Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Mix of Woodbridge.

ARMONK, N.Y., Aug. 28-- Protests against the large-scale excavation, of gravel in residential neighborhoods of North Castle Township were filed to day with officials of the state and Westchester County.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28-- Stockholders of Food Fair Stores, Inc., at today's annual meeting approved an increase in authorized indebtedness from $35,000,000 to $60,000,000 and an increase in authorized common stock from 5,000,000 to 10,000,000 shares.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 28--The festival company from Stratford, Ont., making its first appearance in this country at the Assembly Hall here tonight, gave a performance of Shakespeare's "Henry V" remarkable chiefly for clear speaking, speed, and vitality.

ROME, Aug. 28--The early withdrawal of Giuseppe Saragat, Right-wing Socialist leader, from the Italian Government is foreseen here. He would step out as Vice Premier in Premier Antonio Segni's Cabinet so as to be free to dedicate himself entirely to merging his party with the leftwing Socialists and drawing them away from their alliance with the Communists.

IT'S all over but the shouting. Paris has shown its fall fashions and America's stores and ready-to-wear manufacturers have bought heavily. The first shipment of clothes is about to clear through New York Customs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) --Vice President Nixon will start his campaign for re-election with a "very extensive and vigorous" swing of ten to fourteen days by airplane next month, it was announced today.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Aug. 22-- The French explorer Henri Lhote has returned from the Tassili des Ajjer mountains in the heart of the Sahara to report on one of the world's richest deposits of prehistoric art.
"Atomic Quest," by Dr. Arthur Holly Compton, is a firsthand account of the development of atomic energy.
New York City's largeness is never brought home so forcibly as in the figures that affect the taxpayer's pocketbook. It is a city of 8,074,000 population.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --The major steel companies were rushing today to get in line for major tax benefits to aid plant construction, if any are granted.

Dr. Louis Greenwald, a physician who specialized in the diseases of the blood, died Monday evening of a coronary attack aboard an Eastern Airlines plane flying to Boston. He was scheduled to attend the International Hematological Convention there. His age was 67.
A thirty-foot sewer pipe on wheels hit the road yesterday on a 50,000-mile tour of major cities.
For the last two days airline passengers arriving from abroad have been "receiving a travel brightener from an unexpected quarter--the United States Customs Service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--The Eisenhower Administration reported today that continued prosperity and fiscal prudence promised to yield a Federal budget surplus of $707,000,000 in the current bookkeeping year.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 28--A two-week-old strike of provincial school instructors supported by students ended in Mendoza early today after a violent protest against the national Government resulted in injuries to twenty-one persons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Communist China has informed the United States that its fliers shot down an aircraft at about the time and place where a United States plane was lost last week.

Large space at 730 Fifth Avenue, at Fifty-sixth Street, has been leased by the Pulse, Inc., a marketing research organization specializing in radio and television work.

CAIRO, Aug. 28--An authoritative source said tonight that President Nasser hoped to receive the five-nation committee on the Suez Canal crisis in Cairo within the next week.
STORRS, Conn., Aug. 28-- Chemists are hot on the trail of materials that may give farmers green thumbs such as Jack used to grow the beanstalk.

DETROIT, Aug. 28--Again it was the familiar story which Garfield W. Wood first wrote back in 1920. The Harmsworth Trophy stays in the United States.
The Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion conferred citations last night on Rabbi Mordecai M. Kaplan, Nelson A. Rockefeller and Roy Wilkins.

Prices of cotton futures moved 6 points (30 cents a bale) off to 1 point (5 cents a bale) up yesterday. The trading volume was small.
