MANY New York State deer hunters have been bellowing for some time for an antlerless deer season, and now they have it. A one-day anysex season is scheduled Dec. 1, May caution and luck protect us all.

TOKYO, Aug. 29--A statement by Secretary of State Dulles concerning the Japanese peace treaty has aroused fears here that the United States may seek to annex the Ryukyu and Bonin islands. Mr. Dulles re

PETERBOROUGH, N.H,, Aug. 29--Mrs. Marian MacDowell, widow of the composer, was buried here today beside her husband, Mrs. MacDowell, whose husband was Edward MacDowell, died in Los Angeles last Thursday at the age of 98.
LONDON, Aug. 29--France has received British permission to station French troops in Cyprus. Thus she formally linked her military build-up in the Middle East with Britain's.

NICOSIA, Cyprus--With an implied warning that a more drastic step may be necessary if there is a renewed outbreak of violence, the Cyprus Government today ordered the Bishop of Kitium confined to his residence.
RUSSEKS traditionally hits the tape first in the race of New York stores to show Paris imports. Yesterday it led the field again.
Michigan announced yesterday plans for the sale of $25,000,000 of highway bonds on Sept. 13. The money will be used for the development of the state trunk line system of limited access highways.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29-- The State Department ended today a year-long court fight and issued a passport to Leonard B. Boudin, New York lawyer.
STORRS, Conn., Aug 29--Pre dictions that science can feed, clothe and shelter a greatly increased world population overlook the time element, experts agreed today at a special symposium.
BERLIN, Aug. 29--The Volkskammer (parliament) met today in East Berlin with a fanfare of statements that democracy was growing in East Germany.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29--The St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation said today it would ask Congress next year for authority to borrow $17,000,000 above its present legal limit.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 29--An exploration of serious leaks in the spillway of New York City's Cornell Dam was begun today.

AKLAVIK, Northwest Territories, Aug. 25--Legislative history is being made in an embryo town being hacked out of the Arctic wilderness thirty-five miles east of this Eskimo and Indian fur-trading center.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 29--The coalition Government of Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo appears to be on a treadmill.

The requirements of the new compulsory automotive insurance law are outlined in leaflets to be distributed Saturday by the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles. Eventually 5,000,000 will go to car owners in the state, the bureau said yesterday.
CARLE PLACE, L.I., Aug. 29--Macy's Roosevelt Field, heralded as the largest suburban department store in the East, opened its doors here today to 20,000 potential first-day customers.
Dr. Meyer Levitz, chairman of the physics and general science department of Christopher Columbus High School, the Bronx, at his retirement last April, died yesterday in Royal Hospital, the

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP)-- Spider Webb, a former Olympic boxer, ended Rory Calhoun's winning streak of twenty-three bouts tonight. The Chicago middleweight gained a unanimous decision over the New Yorker in a thrilling ten-round bout at the Chicago Stadium.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 29--A whirlwind, last-minute effort paid off today. As a result, New City's American Legion junior band will be able to take part in next week's national championships. With $7,400 of the needed total of $10,000 raised by 3 o'clock this
CHICAGO, Aug. 28--Scoring five times in the first inning at Wrigley Field, the Dodgers romped to an 11-4 victory over the last-place Cubs today.

LONDON, Aug. 29--The prospective announcement of the drop in gold and dollar reserves in August--which Harold Macmillan, Chancellor of the Exchequor, confirmed today would be substantial--helped restrain any further gains in stock prices today.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 23-- History goes a full circle in this area, where the United States is building a supply base seven miles out of Seville at San Pablo for its naval and airfield program in Spain. Columbus
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 --The United States will begin construction this week on a modern embassy for its diplomatic mission in India.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29--Herbert C. Paschen, the Democratic candidate for Governor of Illinois, withdrew from the race today amid inquiries about an employes' welfare fund in his local office.
The world's largest generator will be built on the banks of the Wabash at Sullivan, Ind., the American Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday.
Two large New York City commercial banks have asked the Federal Reserve to permit banks to increase their interest rates on time deposits other than savings accounts.
The Transit Authority charged yesterday in a letter to Mayor Wagner that some officers of the independent Motormen's Benevolent Association were still "advocating" a general transit strike.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--Unemployement among executives and professional men over 40 years old was called today a problem second only to the plight of the farmer.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Aug. 29--Adlai E. Stevenson bid for the Midwestern farm vote again today. He accused the Eisenhower Administration of causing "human heartbreak" in the Farm Belt and fostering a farm depression that could spread to urban areas.

BOB JONES drove into the rough on the sixteenth hole of the final round of the 1925 United States Open championship at Worcester. The then 23-year-old golfer from Georgia was in a ding-dong contest with Willie Macfarlane for the title. Strokes were much too precious to be wasted.
Public Service Commission hearings ended yesterday on the New York Central Railroad's request for permission to discontinue or curtail its passenger service on the west shore of the Hudson River.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29 --William Faulkner's novel "The Sound and the Fury" has been bought for filming by Jerry Wald, who recently established his own producing company at Twentieth Century-Fox.
A "misunderstanding" that prompted Robert Moses to threaten to quit as chairman of the city's Slum Clearance Committee has been ironed out, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.
FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 29 --Union leaders voted today to curb the racketeers who inhabit the fringes of the labor movement.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 29--For the first time in its 53year history, the famed Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup today passed into the possession of America's oldest junior yacht club, the Pleon of Marblehead.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29--Mrs. John M. Branham, owner of Foxland Hall, a 500acre horse-breeding farm in Gallatin, Tenn., got a phone call from Saratoga late this after
The Graham-Paige Corporation reported yesterday that as of Aug. 29 it had increased its holdings of Thermoid Company common stock to 123,850 shares and that it had options to pur
OUR food bills today are eating up money--$450 on the average for each person in 1955, or about $1.25 a day.
Plans for a new fourteen-story newspaper plant costing $40,000,000 and running from 41 to 115 West End Avenue were filed yesterday by the New York Times Company with the Department of Buildings.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 29-- (Reuters)--Ghulam Mohammed, former Governor General of Pakistan, died after a long-illness tonight on his sixty-first birthday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UP) --Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, accused the Fund for the Republic today of using taxexempt money to run a "multimillion dollar propaganda machine."
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 29-- District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta will seek an early trial for Angelo John La Marca, who is accused of kidnapping and murdering Peter Weinberger last month.
Charles Edwin Potts, business executive who had been chairman of the corporation of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn for thirty years until 1952, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

HAVANA, Cuba, Aug. 21--The risk President Fulgencio Batista took in 1954 by embarking on a plan of deficit financing in the face of a declining economy is paying off in a measure of prosperity. This is due primarily to the rising world consumption of sugar.

Activity remained depressed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume rose from its one-year low of 1,400,000 shares on Tuesday to 1,530,000, but prices continued to sag, Rails closed a little higher.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 29 (AP)--Despite a heavy guard, thirty convicts fled today from a Kilby Prison gravel pit in a bold dash that ended in death for two prisoners. The other convicts were recaptured.
The nation's newest entrant into the field of primary aluminum production announced yesterday that it had brought a partner into the venture and stepped up its output expectations threefold.
Fifteen of the first seamen to reach the scene of the Andrea Doria disaster last month were honored yesterday at a buffet luncheon at the Downtown Athletic Club.
A large patron subscription list for the Bail of the Roses has been reported by Mrs. Donald F. Bush, patrons committee chairman. The event, a benefit dinner dance, given annually by the

COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 29 --Seventy-five prelates from many parts of the world attended the opening today of the seventy-seventh German Roman Catholic Congress. The prelates included Cardinals, Archbishops and Bishops.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy will employ all means available to reduce traffic deaths and injuries here over the Labor Day week-end.
New York State sought yesterday to get direct support from the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation for state development of Niagara River power.
The only nickel refinery in commercial production in this country is now in business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--The chairman of a Senate Constitutional Rights investigating subcommittee thanked the Army today for reinstating a civilian employe. The employe was jobless under a "security risk" cloud for three years.
INWOOD, L,I., Aug. 29-The Women's Long Island Golf Association's annual mixed foursomes tournament for the benefit of the American Red Cross was held today at the Inwood Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--The Republican high command voiced little concern today over the endorsement by labor leaders of Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator Estes Kefauver.

The Hidden Splendor Mining Company, an Atlas Corporation subsidiary, is acquiring a 30 per cent interest in the new Uranium Reduction Company mill at Moab, Utah, Floyd Odlum, president of Atlas, reported yesterday.

It's just fine for the United States Information Agency to send abroad for distribution in eighty countries of the world a pamphlet describing the contributions to America of some of our distinguished immigrants and emphasizing how warmly our country welcomes such immigrants to its shores.
The Roman Catholic Church urged organized labor yesterday "to eliminate from its ranks as rapidly as possible the cancer of racketeering."

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits declared yesterday that false, "vicious rumors" were being spread in attempts to block him from getting the Republican nomination for United States Senator Mr. Javits had arranged tentatively to appear at a closed hearing of the senate Internal Security subcommittee next Wednesday to rebut any charges.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 (UP)--Joe Taggart, a 48-year-old Canton (Ohio) driver, was "seriously" injured today when his boat flipped at a speed of about 140 miles per hour in a qualifying trial for the Gold Cup, America's top speed-boat race.
Federal Reserve member banks overborrowed in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 30--Bob Polhemus took the national Raven Class yacht sailling championship home to the Connecticut side of Long Island Sound today.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 30 --Finding local homes is going to be a good deal easier now that they are all getting street numbers, but many of the residents are furious about it.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany was the scene yesterday afternoon of the marriage of Miss Patricia Gade to Wendell Joseph Curtis 3d. The Rev. Dr. Lee H. Belford performed the ceremony. There was a reception at the Colony Club.
The United States must "set its own house in order" on race prejudice if it wishes to lead the world, Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan declared in a speech yesterday.
CHELSEA, Much., Aug. 30--A Texas member of Congress investigating traffic, safety suggested today the possibility of taxing automobiles according to horsepower rather than weight.

TOMORROW is the first day of September. There is nothing exclusive about this announcement. The same conclusion can be reached by anyone who has peeking privileges at a calendar. This manifestly includes Master Mickey Mantle for whom the date must hold an Ides of March significance.

The Coast Guard, with the police from Brooklyn, Queens and Bayonne, N.J., searched for eight hours through foul weather yesterday morning after distress calls were received from a plane that may never have existed.
LONDON, Aug. 30--Britain today ordered two Egyptian diplomats here to leave the country within seventy-two hours. This was her retort to Egypt's expulsion of two British diplomats.
LONDON, Aug. 30--Prices on stock exchange here fell further today on a warning by the chancellor that higher wages might drive Britain from her rank as a first class industrial

An impasse stalled negotiations yesterday between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America for a new contract covering 14,000 workers in the company's eight East Coast yards.
United States ship pilots have turned thumbs down on efforts of the Egyptian Government to recruit some of them for Suez Canal service.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- President Eisenhower gave his support today to a Republican get-out-the-vote campaign.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30--The longest-priced horse in the field of six, Montpelier Farm's 10-to-1 Mighty Mo, won the $11,400 Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap today. He was the outsider in the betting because he hadn't raced since last October and because he hadn't won since 1954.
STORKS, Conn., Aug, 30--A system for visualizing chemical control of plant cell growth and division is evolving from recent botanical experiments.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- The wife of the Egyptian Ambassador pledged her efforts today to promote goodwill between the United States and Egypt.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday his willingness to run for the Senate seat being vacated by 78-year-old Herbert H. Lehman. The Mayor's father, the late Robert F. Wagner, held the seat from 1927 to 1949.
BUFFALO, Aug. 30--The close race for first place in the annual tournament for the New York State chess title continued today in the fifth round.

TOKYO, Aug. 29--Japan's largest labor organization has compromised with communism in such a way that observers are divided as to whether the 3,000,000 member body has become more Leftist or more Rightist.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 30--Jim Frick of Innis Arden defeated David Mance of Sleepy Hollow in a four-hole play-off for the qualifying medal in the Westchester County Golf Association's thirty-second annual junior championship at the Westchester Hills Golf Club today.

LABOR DAY and the Jewish New Year fall in the same week this year, a coincidence that shoppers will not find cause for celebration when they look at beef prices. Rib roasts have jumped 2 cents to 75 a pound. Sirloin steak, now $1.10 a pound is 12 cents more than a year ago.

Announcement has been made by. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Woerz Doelger of 17 East Eighty-ninth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madeleine Shanley Doelger, to Charles John Brown Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown of Midland Park, N.J.

WARSAW, Aug. 19--Five mornings a week, except Saturday and Sunday, about 200 Polish Jews crowd outside the small private house that serves as the Legation of Israel. Each day a few of them get visas for Israel or notices that they will be given visas if they receive Polish passports.
An ominous campaign against the Government of West Germany is being carried out these days by the Soviet Union.
Anxiety was felt on the lower East Side yesterday as the three-week truce among warring teen-age gangs neared an end.

RIVERHEAD, Aug. 30--A special grand jury accused a Suffolk County official and three other persons today of conspiring to misuse the county's name and credit in the purchase of pharmaceutical supplies.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 30 --Smuggling is a multi-milliondollar problem in Indonesia and one with broad political overtones.
The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday that its net income in the first seven months of this year declined to $39,019,104 from $41,908,048 in the corresponding period of 1955.
Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians is determined once more to bar its members from investing in shows with which they are associated.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30--In the eleventh inning today Don Hoak hit a grounder down the firstbase line with two out and two on base. The ball hit the bag, bounding high in the air, and neither Gil Hodges nor Jackie Robinson could recover it.

The diamond jubilee championship singles of the United States Lawn Tennis Association begin today on the turf of the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills, Queens, with most of the world's leading players participating.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks continued to climb last week by increasing $60,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Two sophomore Yankees whose previous pitching experience in organized baseball totaled less than six seasons have kept this campaign from turning into a debacle for the pennant-defending Yankees.
Thomas Jefferson, who founded it about the year 1800, called it the Democratic-Republican party, an appellation not generally used today.

Now that Canadian editions of American publications will be subject to a 20 per cent tax, the first of what apparently will be a parade of price increases on advertising rates was announced yesterday.
Following is the text of Mayor Wagner's announcement of his willingness to become the Democratic candidate for United States Senator this fall:

The near-by rubber positions On the Commodity Exchange of New York fell sharply yesterday. Heavy speculator liquidation of September contracts was influenced by the circulation of nine delivery notices.

At one point in yesterday's stock market all 1956 gains had been wiped out. The low for the day in The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks was 331.36. The closing level for 1955 was 332.47.
KODIAK, Alaska, Aug. 30 (AP) --A Tokyo-bound Canadian airliner, afire on a night flight over the North Pacific, missed an airfield and smashed onto an Alaskan tideflat last night.
PARIS, Aug. 30--President Eisenhower's statement yesterday on the Suez Canal question was received more sympathetically here than that of Secretary of State Dulles Tuesday.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Aug. 30 --Vice Admiral Monroe Kelly, U.S.N., retired, who once made his headquarters in New York as commandant of the Third Naval District, died at his home here last night. He was 70 years old.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30--A group of psychologists today heard three national candidates put in their psychological places.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Egypt asserted her full sovereignty over the Suez Canal today and denied the waterway ever had been internationalized.
The brief and entirely unofficial visit of Japanese Foreign Minister Shigemitsu to this country has again pointed up some of the issues involved in the place of Japan in the Far Eastern struggle.
FISHING prospects for Long Island and New Jersey waters on the Labor Day week-end are about as good as any reasonable angler could ask.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30--The grain markets were irregular today. At the start, there was pressure on corn, while soybeans were fairly strong.
CAIRO, Aug. 30--President Gamal Abdel Nasser protested tonight against President Eisenhower's assertion that the Suez Canal was an international waterway.

A count of twenty-four-sheet billboards in California, which showed that Republican messages outnumbered those of Democrats by ten to one, has inspired a program designed to achieve equality of opportunity for political candidates.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--The value of the nation's farms rose to a record level last year despite declining agricultural prices and income.
The Transport Workers Union assailed the City Administration yesterday for its current role in the tangled transit labor situation.
Over-the-road truck drivers voted last night to reject a new contract negotiated with 345 trucking concerns.
SHEFFIELD, England, Aug. 30--British steel researchers have made a recognizable form of steel directly from finely divided iron ore without blastfurnace and other intermediate processes.
Two new ramps linking the South Street Elevated Highway with the Brooklyn Bridge area will go into service today.
DETROIT, Aug. 30 (UP)-- Walter Burkemo of Franklin, Mich., and Don Fairfield of Casey, Ill., clipped three strokes from par with 69's today to share the first-round lead in the Motor City Open.
Millions of Americans will climb into their automobiles beginning about sundown today and set forth on the nation's highways.
Preliminary plans for two office buildings on sites between Grand Central Terminal and the United Nations headquarters were filed yesterday.
SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 30 (AP)--The New York City Ballet Company ended a series of performances today at the Salzburg Music Festival to rousing cheers.
Robert Moses, chairman of the city's Slum Clearance Committee, joined yesterday the forces belaboring Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa for his stand against tax exemption for future housing projects.
Business and residential landmarks in the downtown and upper East Side districts of Manhattan passed to new control in transactions reported yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 34--The Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was summoned today to meet here Wednesday to consider the Suez Canal dispute.The NATO Council was called at the request of Britain ostensibly to inform its members of the latest developments in the crisis resulting from Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal company July 26.
CLINTON, Tenn., Aug. 30 (AP) --Racial tension over integration of Clinton High School flared into violence for the second straight day in this East Tennessee community.
Seven hundred college students will head back to the campus this fall with fatter wallets and some new practical knowledge.
DALLAS, Tex., Aug. 30--The House of Delegates defeated a proposal today that the American Bar Association appoint an accredited observer to the United Nations.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 30--The Boston Symphony Orchestra took leave of the Edinburgh International Festival tonight with Debussy's symphonic sketches, "La Mer," which ended the orchestra's final program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--The International Longshoremen's Association said today it would not back down on its demand for coast-wide bargaining even if it meant tying up every port from Maine to Texas this fall.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 30--With world cotton conditions remaining as they are, Mexico will quietly shelve its controversial barter plan through which Mexican cotton must be sold abroad as compensation for import permits on automobiles and other items.
ULAN BATOR, Outer Mongolia, Aug. 28--The development of this city exemplifies the effort by the Communist leaders to give a country of nomadic herdsmen an industrial base.

ABOUT a decade ago, former Mayor William O'Dwyer, chatting with some friends, noted a rather short, portly young man approaching and remarked, "Here comes young Bob Wagner, wearing his father's pants." Ten years and
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- The Democratic National Committee said tonight that a "secret poll" had shown that hardly anyone could think of anything worse to call the opposition than "Republican party."
Certificate of Proprietary Interest 390 has caused the Texas Pacific Land Trust a lot of trouble.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)-- The Coast Guard announced today proposed new safety inspection rules for 8,000 small vessels.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 20 (AP)-- Representative Olin Teague charged today that 2,000,000 veterans disabled in service were being denied increased benefits.

TOWN journals have told in detail how Maria de Ra mirez Kramer sold the Lincoln Hotel here and the Roosevelt Hotel in Washington to William Zeckendorf for $10,000,000 cash. They told little, though, of the extraordinary woman who swung the deal, single-handed.
IN 1906 the most fashionable resort hotel on Lake Como in the Italian Alps was the Bellevue at Cadenabbia.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30-- Want to buy a surplus buffalo? The Fish and Wildlife Service said today it was taking orders for 500.
A $150,000 study that is expected to produce a new plan for comprehensive rezoning of the city was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
GENEVA, Aug. 30--If the rains do not stop, central and western Europe are likely to have a hungry and an expensive winter.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 30 (AP)-- The Milwaukee Braves played to a 1-1 tie with Pittsburgh today but picked up half a game over runner-up Brooklyn in the National League pennant race.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--A joint military-civilian system of navigation for safer jet travel was adopted today by the Government.
Two new measures to ease the relocation of 7,000 Lincoln Square families were disclosed yesterday at City Hall. The families' homes would be razed by the eighteen-block redevelopment at the square.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 --Representatives of seven national civic and religious organizations re scheduled to put in twelve hours Sunday monitoring the content of network television shows.
FOREST PARK, Pa., Aug. 30 --The labor movement today projected an "educational campaign" to change the "whole mental attitude" of the South.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 30 --Adlai E. Stevenson heard from Democratic leaders of ten Southern states today enthusiastic predictions of a "solid South" in the November election.
The "vamps" and their ladies --3,000 altogether--marched up Broadway yesterday from Bowling Green to City Hall to the music of twenty-four bands.
Out of the National League cellar as a result of their most successful western trip, the Giants rested yesterday in advance of their five-game weekend series with the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds.
Seventeen different series of regular programs will be televised in color on a full-time basis next season by the National Broadcasting Company.
Some persons expressed fear yesterday of reprisal against possible informers among those arrested in connection with the acid blinding of Victor Riesel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 --The "nine-day wonder boys," Morton Fine and Dave Friedkin, will not be returning to television in a hurry, They have been signed to a one-year contract by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer; with options that could prolong their stay at the studio.

The American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., and the Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday the purchase of a 50 per cent interest in the Wind Tunnel Instrument Company Inc., of Newton, Mass.

BERLIN, Aug. 30--The East German Legislature's discussion today of a public problem had a semblance of parliamentary debate as it is generally understood in the West. If such debate occurred any other time in the seven years of the chamber's existence, it did not come to light.
MANILA, Aug. 29--United States negotiations with the Philippines on modernization of the military base system are making progress slowly.

Back around the turn of the century Nathaniel Greene Herreshoff, noted shipbuilder, put up an inn on one of the main streets of his native Bristol, R.I. It was constructed like a Herreshoff ship, with the finest of timber and by the most skilled workmen to be found.

Bil and Cora Baird's Marionette Theatre will begin a nineday engagement today at the Playhouse. There will be performances today at 10:30 A:M., 1 and 3:45 P.M. The puppet revue will feature "Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves," with book by Allan Stern and Mr. Baird, special songs and dances by...

Officials of the Indusrtial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America Will resume negotiations with the Bethlehem Steel Company on Thursday. They will be armed with the power to declare a strike if the talks appear to be fruitless.
THE old order changes, but fortunately in the case of the shop at 652 Madison Avenue it has not yielded to something entirely new.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 31-- The news that French troops were moving to Cyprus produced an immediate and bitter reaction in Lebanon and Syria today. As territories formerly ruled by France under a League of Nations Mandate, these countries are far more touchy about

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31-- President Eisenhower replied in a conciliatory tone today to the protest by President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt against statements that the Suez Canal was by treaty an "internationalized" waterway.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31--Adlai E. Stevenson said today he would welcome an offer from President Eisenhower to share with him secret intelligence reports on foreign affairs.

ALBANY, Aug. 31 (AP)--Two insurance executives have resigned as members of the state's temporary Health Insurance Board because of "conflicting interests," it was reported today by Alexander A. Falk, the board chairman.
The last set of turbines was installed yesterday in the engine room of the Independence, Forrestal-class attack carrier under construction in the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 31 --Drills began today for the Army football team. Fifty-five candidates spent the day blocking, running through formations, passing and kicking--half in earnest, half for the benefit of photographers.

Mayor Wagner has changed his mind and agreed to become the Democratic nominee for United States Senator to succeed Herbert H. Lehman if his party wants him. He says the decision was not an easy one to make. In fact, two weeks ago today he thought the job of Mayor of New York "more important."
In what brokers described as a normal technical reaction to its weakness of the past three weeks, the stock market yesterday more than won back Wednesday's and Thursday's losses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31-- President Eisenhower greeted Mickey Mantle tonight just before the Yankees and Senators squared off in the opener of a three-game series and wished the Oklahoma Kid the best of luck.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 31-- The West German Government reacted sharply today against recent Soviet attacks.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 31-- Brazil has suspended the export to the United states of minerals used for nuclear energy. She has also denounced the Brazilian-United States agreement for a joint uranium search in her territory.
The 1956 Knickerbocker Mixed Pair Championship was won early this morning by Mrs. Peggy Adams of New York and Murray Schnee of Forest Hills, Queens, with a one-session score of 203 match points.
Lucy Daniels, 22-year-old reporter on The Raleigh Times, who is the daughter of Jonathan Daniels, editor of The Raleigh News and Observer, will have her first novel published next week.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and United States Attorney Paul W. Williams and their assistants met yesterday for nearly three hours.
MANSFIELD, Tex., Aug. 31-- Texas Rangers moved into this angry town today to help county sheriffs preserve order.

Sabbath services in a Washington Heights synagogue were disrupted last night by two youths who followed two girls into the house of worship and started a fight. Several men at prayers were injured, one seriously.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 31 (UP)--Louisiana legislators today killed a proposal that would have allowed unsegregated athletic contests in New Orleans. In doing so they rejected a plea by a former football star who said that the action would doom the Sugar Bowl sports festival.

Jacob K. Javits, State Attorney General, ruled yesterday that the new state law establishing surveillance over union welfare funds applied only to funds created and maintained jointly by employers and employes.

WIANNO, Mass., Aug. 31-- Miss Patricia Muriel Sloan, daughter of Mrs. Theodore Robert Turner of Osterville and the late John MacArthur Sloan, was married this morning to Robert Archbold Jones. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Archbold Redmond Jones of Pueblo, Colo.
One of the jobs of the State Department of Labor is to put people who have positions available in touch with those who want them and can fill them.

Leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association held an hour-long conference in Washington yesterday with Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell. The union's plans to meet trouble on two fronts were outlined.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) --Manufacturers' sales dipped sharply in July because of the steel strike and wound up $3,500,000,000 below the June figure, the Department of Commerce reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 --Representative Melvin Price, Democrat of Illinois, appears to be getting a lot of mileage out of attacking and defending motion pictures of a somewhat controversial nature.
The president, a vice president and three members of the Motormen's Benevolent Association were dismissed last night by the Transit Authority for their part in the subway strike of June 14.
ACCRA, Gold Coast, Aug. 31-- An official inquiry report said today that the Government had connived at and condoned irregularities in the Gold Coast Cocoa Purchasing Company.
DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP)--Passenger car production this week will fall to 57,478 assemblies, compared with 69,977 last week and 85,851 in the similar 1955 week.
Over-the-road truck drivers who have rejected a contract offered by their employers will decide tomorrow whether to begin a strike next Tuesday.
A four-block area in Perth Amboy, N.J., has been sold by the City of Perth Amboy to A. Arthur Tracy and the Nassau Management Company for improvement with 275 apartments for middle-income families.

It was Tennyson that President Eisenhower quoted yesterday at his press conference, but he might well have thought of Lewis Carroll and "Through the Looking Glass." The talk was in reality of "cabbages and kings." The problem of the small farmer, on which the President solicitously touched, may often...

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 (AP) --A temporary restraining order halting a proposed merger of the Continental Can Company with the Hazel-Atlas Glass Company was lifted today by Federal District Judge George B. Harris.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--The index of average primary market prices remained unchanged at 114.6 per cent of its 1947-49 level in the week ended last Tuesday, the Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

A Waterfront Commission hearing ended abruptly yesterday afternoon when a stevedoring concern pleaded guilty to charges of permitting other persons to have a voice in the selection of its supervisory pier employes.

Russia took a 2-1 lead against Bulgaria in their sixth-round match in the international chess tournament in Moscow, according to a report from Soviet news sources yesterday. One game was adjourned.
The General Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday it had acquired about 75 per cent of the common stock and 40 per cent of the preferred stock of the A.M. Byers Company, wrought iron producer.
FIRST of the season's oysters already are in fish stores here, but word from Long Island, home of the blue point and Mattituck, is not encouraging.
OSLO, Norway, Sept. 7--A Norwegian parliamentary delegation returned today from a three-week tour of the Soviet Union.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 7--Madison Avenue's latest merchandising technique, "the soft sell," came to Yugoslavia today under the auspices of the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP)-- Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, will begin the Senate's special investigation of United States aid programs befor taking over as President Eisenhower's special Ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, his office said today.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 7--A retired general has asserted that Argentina's Superior War College is a breeding ground for totalitarian officers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Homer Stille Cummings, United States Attorney General from 1933 to 1939, during the Administration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died today at his home. His age was 86.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10--The Soviet Union has promised Yugoslavia 300,000 tons of wheat to tide her over the next two months.

Dr. Benjamin Minge Duggar, discoverer of aureomycin, died at Grace Memorial Hospital in New Haven yesterday after a short illness. He had been visiting his daughter, Mrs. John F. Adams of Hamden, Conn. Dr. Duggar was 84 years old.
Sometime between Thanksgiving and Christmas the nationwide teams organized to observe the man-made earth satellites are to hold a full-dress rehearsal.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10--Oil company agents sent spurious "pressure" telegrams last winter in a lobbying campaign for a bill to free natural gas from direct Federal controls.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10--The demand for grain futures today was not as keen as many expected in view of the Suez crisis, and there was pressure on wheat, soybeans and corn futures early in the session. Shorts were less anxious to cover than they were in the late trade Friday.

The premium field is trading up. The demand for lower-priced self-liquidators (tear off the box top and send with coin or stamps) has diminished and give-away items at 50 cents and up are wanted, according to exhibitors at the New York Premium Show.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) --Dry, hot weather coupled with a plow-up of some acreage under the new soil bank program reduced this year's cotton crop prospects 3 per cent during August.
The labor dispute last Friday at Pier 25, Hudson River and North Moore Street, was linked yesterday to the growing jurisdictional struggle between two rival waterfront unions.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 10-- A wide area in the Kabylia Mountains south of Bougie in northeastern Algeria has been cleared of nationalist rebels, and its inhabitants have been armed for their own defense.
Johnny Sullivan, British middleweight, scored a unanimous decision over Willie Troy in their ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 10--The Asian, Arab and African members of the United Nations have decided to press for consideration of the Algerian situation at the coming session of the General Assembly.

The 1956 world series will begin on Oct. 3 in the park of the winning National League club. The commissioner of baseball, Ford C. Frick, made the announcement yesterday following a meeting of contending club officials in the commissioner's office.

One of the most important contributions of the International Monetary Fund to post-war world stability has been its isolation of the virus that was causing an epidemic of inflation and educating the victims and potential victims as to its prevention and cure.
The Maritime Administration will start training courses for American merchant seamen today to teach them defense against atomic, biological and chemical warfare.
MOSCOW, Sept. 10--Food, clothing and shelter are serious problems for the average Soviet man and his family.
LONDON, Sept. 10--The Suez crisis dominated sentiment on the stock market here today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 10--The American Ballet Theatre scored a resounding success here last night in a program combining warhorses of the classical repertoire with contemporary American works.
The Erie, the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western and the Delaware and Hudson Railroads are studying a merger.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 10 --A debonair 64-year-old lawyer was designated Prime Minister of Pakistan today after a bitter nine-year struggle out of political oblivion.
FOR the next two weeks you need fly only as far as Berg dorf-Goodman to see the Paris collections. Draw up a bergere in their second-floor salon.
It was back to school again yesterday for children throughout the city. All told, about 1,264,000 boys and girls were present in public and parochial schools for the first day of the new term.
DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP)--The auto industry is almost through with making 1956 models.
Two unrelated announcements stressed yesterday the importance of Civil Defense Week.
Msgr. Thaddeus W. Tierney, pastor since 1932 of St. Raymond's Roman Catholic Church, Castle Hill and Tremont Avenues, the Bronx, died yesterday after an illness of three months. He was 81 years old.

The next big expansion of Celanese Corporation of America is to go forward in the chemical and plastics division. The company expects to spend about $100,000,000 over the next five years for this purpose, according to Harold Blancke, president.

General Electric Research Laboratories announced here yesterday that one of the major problems barring the construction of vehicles fast enough to breech the so-called "thermal barrier" apparently had been solved.
C.W. Post College is a liberal arts school in Brookville, L.I., one year old and already being measured for shoulder pads and football pants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon announced today he would undertake a 15,000-mile, thirtytwo-state campaign tour as part of a "running scared" effort to re-elect the Republican ticket.
ALBANY, Sept. 10--Adai E. Stevenson accused President Eisenhower tonight of operating a "Government with a false front." The Presidential nominee told more than 2,000 ...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10-- Spokesmen of the major political parties pledged today to cooperate with a special Senate subcommittee to keep clean the millions of dollars to be spent in the 1956 campaign.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 10 --Richard Basehart is about to take on the biggest role of his film career and one several other actors had eyed covetously. He will be starred in "John Paul Jones," life story of the "father of the American Navy." The actor currently is featured as Ishmael in "Moby Dick."
DETROIT, Sept. 10--An official of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago issued a warning today against inflationary tendencies in the nation's economy.
PORTLAND, Me., Tuesday, Sept. 11--Gov. Edmund S. Muskie led Maine Democrats yesterday to their greatest political heights in twenty years.
JAY THORPE set its cap for brides-to-be in 1925. Now, thirty-one years later, the store outfits 2,000 brides annually.
CAIRO, Sept. 11--A high Egyptian official accused the British and French tonight of having a "set plan" to engineer a situation giving them an excuse for armed seizure of the Suez Canal.

The French Premier and Minister of Foreign Affairs conferred with the Prime Minister and the Foreign Secretary at 10 Downing Street during the evening of Sept. 10 and again in the morning of Sept. 11.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11--Trading in grain and soybean futures was dull today on the Board of Trade. Buying and selling orders were of moderate volume as a rule, and pretty evenly balanced.

While there was considerable variation as between boroughs and between courts, the experiment of holding summer trials in personal injury cases in New York City was enough of a success to deserve a second test in 1957.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 12 --A peace agreement between the Soviet Union and Japan appeared to be in the making today.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11-- Frank Morey Coffin, the disarmingly quiet young lawyer from Lewiston, who broke a twenty-two-year Republican stranglehold on Maine's Second District seat in Congress ...
Legislative action to prevent discrimination in hiring against, persons 40 or more years old was pledged yesterday by the city's Republican candidates for the state Legislature.
Premiums are more popular than ever, according to speakers at the Premium Advertising Association of America's conference yesterday at the SheratonAstor Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) --Following is the unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President throughout.
Uneasiness and uncertainty appear to have settled over the stock market. The uncertainty is linked to the growing pressure on money rates and the uneasiness to the continued Suez crisis.
Nearque II, a 7-year-old horse bred in England by The Aga Khan and Prince Aly Khan, won the Murray Hill Handicap from eleven rivals at Belmont Park yesterday by three lengths.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., set a new high record in sales for a first-half period with $467,495,321 for the six months ended July 31. This represented a gain of 10.5 per cent over the $423,092,027 in the similar period last year.

WAYNE, N.J., Sept. 11--Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood took a one-stroke lead in the thirty-six-hole Scotch foursome tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association today.

BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP)--Larry Boardman turned loose a brutal right hand to knock down battlewise Jimmy Carter three times in the eighth round tonight for a technical knockout in 1:35 at the Boston Garden.
LONDON, Sept. 11--The rock 'n' roll craze is sweeping Britain and some of its teen-age fans are jiving their way right into police stations.
The steel industry turned out 8,148,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings last month as it sought to restore operations sharply curtailed by the nationwide steel strike.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 11--The Yankees moved still another stride closer to the 1956 pennant clinching tonight as they polished off the tail-end Athletics, 9 to 5, in the opener of a threegame series before 18,892 fans.
The man assigned to the biggest face-lifting job ever attempted in Brooklyn--which includes a new home stadium for the Brooklyn Dodgers--is Charles Joseph Mylod.

We are now well launched into the political season and prospective voters ought to check their election calendars, Nov. 6 is the day to vote. In New York City (and Westchester County) Oct. 8-13 inclusive is the regular registration period.
A group of executives were told yesterday that they should consider rewarding salesmen "with perhaps the most lasting incentive of all--a share of stock in your company."
Manager Fred Haney received a vote of confidence in the form of a 1957 contract before leading the Milwaukee Braves into last night's opener of an important two-game series with the Brooklyn Dodgers.

Commodity futures prices on the New York exchanges were mostly lower yesterday in featureless trading. Cocoa, potatoes, rubber, hides and copper declined; wool rose, and price movements for coffee, cottonseed oil, and sugar were mixed.

The Insurance Company of North America announced yesterday plans to return to the regular life insurance field after an absence of 139 years. Incorporation papers were filed with the Pennsylvania Insurance Department for the Life Insurance Company of North America, a new company.

LAKE JUNALUSKA, N.C., Sept. 11--Delegates to the ninth World Methodist Conference began debate here today on a 1,200-word message to churchgoers the world over. Approval is expected tomorrow, the final day of the conference.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11--Tourism is becoming a major industry in the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, Sept. 11 Republican legislative leaders served notice today that they planned to use the 1954 education issue as a weapon against Mayor Wagner in this fall's Senate campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--A special Senate subcommittee that is policing expenditure of the 1956 campaign heard today that the Republicans and Democrats had contracted for about $2,105,000 worth of television time.

For four years running now the savings banks of New York have introduced bills in the State Legislature which, if enacted, would have liberalized moderately the restrictions the law now imposes upon ...

IF a fellow had imagination enough, he could portray the events leading up to the Johnny Saxton-Carmen Basilio fight tonight in terms of the wild, wild West. There would be glimpses of Basilio, the old homesteader, having his welterweight championship rustled away from him while Julius Helfand, the grizzled sheriff, tried to right the injustice. However, Two-Gun Helfand had to duck the arrows and tomahawks of the hatchetmen in the underbrush.
A Waterfront Commission hearing officer recommended yesterday that the John W. McGrath Corporation receive a permanent stevedoring license.
Twenty members of the French Parliament arrived here yesterday for a seventeen-day tour of the United States.

A syndicate represented by Arthur B. Colwin, attorney, has purchased the six-story building containing stores, showrooms and apartments at 246-48 East Fifty-first Street from Nationwide Investors, Inc., Eugene A. Hegy Jr., president.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --The United States, reckoning with the possibility that its experimental earth satellites may become lost in the sky at times, is organizing a corps of about 1,500 volunteers to help keep track of them.

LONDON, Sept. 11--Prime Minister Eden and Premier Guy Mollet of France agreed today to wage a harsh economic campaign against Egypt to force her to accept international control over the operation, development and finances of the Suez Canal.

THE antique huntress, triumphantly bearing home her dusty quarry, is often squelched by a practical husband who asks, "What's it for?" Bloomingdale's has arranged for him to eat those words by acquiring an extensive collection of period cookie forms.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 11 --Bill Gooderham of Toronto was beaten by both of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club boats today, but remained a whisker ahead in his efforts to win the North American sixmeter sailing championship for the third straight year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Col. Herbert H. Frost, who had been widely known in the radio manufacturing field, died yesterday in George Washington Hospital after a long illness. He was 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission today charged nearly all of the West Coast tuna industry with engaging in an illegal conspiracy to fix prices and prevent competition.

CLINTON, Tenn., Sept. 11-- More than 75 per cent of Clinton high school students have returned to their classes with twelve Negroes who have been the target of riotous attempts to bar their admission.

ROME, Sept. 11--Roman Catholic physicians may not obey laws that call for actions in contradiction with the clearly manifested law of God, Pope Pius XII said today. Among such forbidden actions he specifically mentioned euthanasia (painlessly putting to death persons with incurable diseases) and abortion.

A POTENTIALLY provocative experiment in drama --a modern-dress version of "Antigone" done against impressionistic settings--floundered most disappointingly last night on the "Kaiser Aluminum Hour" over Channel 4.

Russias chess players, seeking to retain the Hamilton-Russell Trophy, defeated Britain, 3--0, with one game adjourned, in the opening round of the finals in the team tournament in Moscow, according to a report received yesterday through Soviet sources.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 11 (AP)--George D. Clyde forged ahead of Gov. J. Bracken Lee tonight in Utah's Republican gubernatorial primary.
The largest single tanker construction order in any United States shipyard was credited yesterday to the investment house of Dillon, Read Co.
City Council President Abe Stark is cutting short his European "second honeymoon" to return at once to New York.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 11-- The New York Central Railroad's application for an average rise of 26.4 per cent in commutation fares on its Hudson and Harlem Divisions was called proof today of a "calloused public-be-damned attitude."
Cotton futures advanced 2 to 32 points (10 cents to $1.60 a bale) yesterday. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly heavy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The United States has demanded full compensation from Communist China for the shooting down of a Navy patrol plane off the China Coast Aug. 23.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 11 --Air Marshal William Avery Bishop, leading Canadian ace of World War I who was in charge of Canadian Air Force recruiting in Ottawa during World War II, died at his home here today. He was 62 years old and had been in ill health for two years.

BREWSTER, N.Y., Sept. 11-- Representative Ralph W. Gwinn, Republican, who is seeking reelection to the House of Representatives, met head-on today with his Democratic opponent, William D. Carlebach. The issue was Federal aid for local school construction.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Federal tax agents are studying the oil industry's $2,000,000 "educational campaign" in behalf of the natural gas bill, which was vetoed.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 11--A survey just completed here indicates that nine companies, six of them new in Venezuela, will pay $350,000,000 for the first oil concessions authorized here since 1945.

DENVER, Sept. 11--Charles F. Brannan, former Secretary of Agriculture in the Administration of Harry S. Truman, and John A. Carroll, a former Representative, were locked in a close race tonight. They are seeking the Democratic nomination for the Senate.

MILAN, Italy, Sept. 11--Archbishop Edwin Vincent O'Hara of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Kansas City and St. Joseph, Mo., died of a heart attack today in a hotel here. He had celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday five days ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --Farm production prospects for 1956 improved during August despite drought damage in some areas. The harvest outlook is only moderately below last year's near-record figures.

PASSERS-BY in West Fiftyfifth Street these bright September afternoons may hear the tap, tap, tap of a cane as an elderly woman makes slow progress down the block between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 11 (AP)-- The Public Service Commission today cleared the way for the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines to complete its plan for reorganizing the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit System in New York City.
A man with only a year's college training who assertedly has been passing himself off as a physician for the last nine years was arrested here yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 11 --During his career of fifty-one years in the priesthood, Archbishop O'Hara served in many capacities, especially those concerning rural life, welfare and sociology.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- President Eisenhower said today that "every possible chink in the Iron Curtain" must be widened in the peace-building cause of making ordinary people of all lands understand each other.
New York City has borrowed $35,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due Nov. 5 at an interest rate of 2 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11-- Although 1,000 civil cases were disposed of by summer jury trials in the Third United States Circuit in a new program this year, this plan still is not the answer to crowded court dockets, Chief Judge John Biggs Jr. said today.

More than 2,000 Orthodox Jews met in Union Square last evening to protest the "persecution of religion in the state of Israel." The meeting was arranged by the National Committee for Freedom of Religion in Israel, with headquarters at 136 Broadway, Brooklyn.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Sept. 11 --Texas' perennially warring liberal and conservative Democrats clashed in a showdown battle at the party's state convention today.
Pedestrians and drivers in midtown came to a halt yesterday afternoon as a real "cops and robbers" scene unfolded.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--A complete change of the Eisenhower Administration's attitude on home-building was urged today by the National Association of Home Builders.
For the record, American Telephone and Telegraph stock closed yesterday on the Big Board at $173 a share. The day before it finished at $183.75.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 11--The United States Embassy here received today the first verification and details of the murder of a New York artist by Indians in the jungle state of Chipas.
New York City is seeking a way to give tangible help to near-by communities in this and neighboring states whose water supply troubles are steadily becoming more acute.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 12 (U.P.)--United States B-29's criss-crossed the Japan Sea last night and early today, hoping despite darkness and heavy seas to find some trace of sixteen airmen missing since a typhoon-tracing B-50 vanished Monday.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 11--Proposals to implement a bold regional program of nuclear development were presented today to the annual Southern Governors Conference.
MATOAKA, W. Va., Sept. 11 --The back of the boycott against school integration appeared today to be broken in this village and two outlying coal mining communities.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- President Eisenhower ruled out today the possibility of United States participation in any British-French military action against Egypt "under present circumstances."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- President Eisenhower gave a convincing demonstration today of a man deeply angered by the Democratic campaign against his Administration.
HAGERSTOWN, Md., Sept. 11 --The 6,000 children in Hagerstown's eight public schools got their first experience of learning by television today.
Techniques for performing new types of chemical studies with a fraction of a drop of blood from a sick person were described by a Swiss chemist here yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 11--Carmen Basilio will make his bid to regain the welterweight championship of the world tomorrow night. The onion farmer from near-by Chittenango will oppose the titleholder, Johny Saxton of Flushing, Queens, in a fifteenround contest at the War Memorial Auditorium here.
Frederic W. Wile Jr. has resigned as a vice president of the National Broadcasting Company. He became the third officer to resign in less than a week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- President Eisenhower said today he had "no name in mind" yet for the Supreme Court vacancy caused by the retirement of Associate Justice Sherman Minton.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 11--A new four-year economic plan will be started next year, Kiang Piao, Chinese Nationalist Minister of Economic Affairs, announced today.

Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell last night accused Adlai E. Stevenson of "half-truths and false implications on matters dealing with economics and labor policy."

MOSCOW, Sept. 11--The Soviet Union has agreed to grant Indonesia a credit to be repaid over ten to twelve years in Indonesian raw materials. Moscow will provide machinery, manufactured goods and technical assistance under the treaty, now being negotiated in Jakarta.
There is a veritable fish pond under our raft. Today we succeeded in spearing three of them with a five-pronged "trident" Marc made from a slat of wood and large fish hooks that he straightened.

The strange hanging of a librarian "looks more and more as though it could be an experiment on his part that went awry," Deputy Inspector John E. Sexton said yesterday.
Mack Trucks, Inc., which claims the title of the nation's oldest bus manufacturer, has acquired C.D. Beck Co., Inc., Sidney, Ohio builder of intercity buses, and the C.D. Beck Realty Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11-- Dr. Edwin Ewart Aubrey, chairman of the Department of Religious Thought at the University of Pennsylvania, died last night in University Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Wynnewood, a suburb.

PARIS, Sept. 11--It was said authoritatively here tonight that the next step in seeking to settle the Suez Canal question would depend on the United States. This step was understood to entail measures requiring United States backing to be effective.

AS the Maid in Shaw's "Saint Joan," which began the new Phoenix season last evening, Siobhan McKenna brings us a performance that has already been fervently admired in Dublin, London, Cambridge, Mass., and Philadelphia.

The east side of Third Avenue, between Fifty-fourth and Fifty-fifth Streets, is typical of many stretches of that oncedingy boulevard today. Unlike some parts of the avenue since the elevated structure was torn down, there has been no refurbishing of the buildings there. Nevertheless, they somehow loop newer and brighter since they have shed the shadow of the "El."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- The Southern states were urged today by President Eisenhower to help carry out Federal court orders to end public school segregation.

From her high-backed wheel chair, Mrs. Catherine McParlan looked on delightedly yesterday as her relatives and friends joined her in celebrating her 101st birthday. The celebration was held at the House of Calvary, Featherbed Lane and Macombs Road, the Bronx.
The Brush Beryllium Company, Cleveland, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to a proposed offering of 400,000 shares of the company's common stock.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11-- Jubilant Maine Democrats are wearing their broadest victory grins in twenty years.
WEDGEPORT, N.S. Sept. 11 --Europeans have been coming here for more than 400 years to catch tuna and have been catching them pretty briskly until recently.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., Sept. 11 --Harvie Ward Jr. of San Francisco began the defense of his United States amateur golf title in impressive fashion today. Following a bye in yesterday's first round.
Arthur Judson, for thirty-four years manager of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, has resigned as of Oct. 1.
STURGIS, Ky., Sept. 11--Racial tension here and at near-by Clay eased somewhat today, although Clay was still firmly in the hands of a crowd of segregationists.

ALBANY, Sept. 11--Governor Harriman released today a report blaming one of former State Conservation Commissioner Louis A. Wehle's chief targets for the death of thousands of pheasants on a state game farm.
MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, Sept. 12--Senator Alexander Wiley was locked in a neck-andneck contest early today in the Wisconsin Republican primary race for renomination to his Senate seat.

The blueprint on which Birdie Tebbetts has diagrammed the 1956 National League pennant for his Cincinnati Redlegs calls for his club to "keep on winning." The wily and ambitious pilot has outlined other plans--and hopes --but his top item makes continuous victory a "must."

Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz reserved decision yesterday after hearing the arguments of independent oil refiners in a securities case. They are seeking to intervene in opposition to a sale of the securities of the Universal Oil Products Company of Des Plaines, Ill.

Charges by the Kings County Medical Society of unethical cut-rate competition have ended a Brooklyn housing project's plan to inoculate several hundred adults with Salk poliomyelitis vaccine. The inoculation program had been arranged by the tenants association of the Boulevard Houses, a 1,400-family middleincome project in East New York.

Floyd Patterson, a heavyweight boxing contender from Brooklyn, has recovered completely from a bone fracture in the right hand and can begin training immediately for a championship fight with Archie Moore.

At the height of the Senate battle last February over the bill to exempt producers of natural gas from direct Federal regulation one veteran Senator said: "Never * * * have I seen such intensive, varied and ingenious types of lobbying. * * * I have been badly overlobbied."

Generalisimo Rafael L. Trujillo of the Dominican Republic asserted yesterday that a manuscript denouncing his regime had been offered to him for $25,000 by its author, Dr. Jesus de Galindez. Dr. Galindez, a Spanish-Basque lecturer at Columbia University, mysteriously disappeared six months ago today.

Adlai E. Stevenson declared last night that it was the responsibility of the President to do all in his power to create a climate of compliance with the Supreme Court decision outlawing racial segregation in the public schools.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 5-- Dollars are now more plentiful and cheaper in Brazil. But in Rio de Janeiro bread is dearer and a haircut costlier.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 11-- As the time limit in the surrender terms offered to Cypriote terrorists neared, Field Marshal Sir John Harding, British governor and military commander, warned today that the insurgents would be destroyed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --A Weather Bureau expert testified today that the two airliners that collided over the Grand Canyon June 30 had been flying in relatively clear skies with good visibility.
Democratic victories in Maine have bolstered Adlai E. Stevenson's hopes of winning the Presidency.
TORONTO, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press)--Althea Gibson of New York won two matches today and advanced to the final round of the international invitation tennis tournament.
LONDON, Sept. 11--Stock market activity dwindled further today pending tomorrow's debate in the House of Commons on the Suez Canal crisis.
Sal Maglie, once the pet hate of every Brooklyn fan, last night became the toast of all Flatbush when he pitched and batted the Dodgers into a firstplace tie with the Braves in the National League.

An apartment house for fiftyeight families on plot 120 by 100 feet at 1503-05 Walton Avenue, northwest corner of 172d Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Esther M. Kersham to Louis Zucker for investment. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $177,000 in a deal negotiated by E. Osborne Smith, Inc., broker.
Babies in need of homes will be helped by three theatre parties to be held this fall and next spring.
The third annual New York Summer Festival, this year called "New York Is a Summer Festival," yesterday was called the most successful.
As Her Most Serene Highness the Princess Grace of Monaco, the former Grace Kelly of Hollywood and Philadelphia, came home yesterday for a two-month visit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) --The Army made a formal bid today for the right to employ a family of guided missiles "in a wide variation of ranges and yields" to carry out its basic mission of land warfare.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --The Government came up with a batch of reports today showing business bigger and better.
The International Association of Chiefs of Police was asked yesterday to step up the war against juvenile delinquency under a twenty-sevenpoint program of action.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) --Dr. Norman Levi Bowen, former president of the Geological Society of America, was found dead today in his apartment.

Many patrons have been announced for the benefit performance of the Royal Danish Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House next Tuesday evening. Kenneth A. Ives is chairman for the event, proceeds of which will aid the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.

SHENANDOAH, Pa., Sept. 11 --The engagement of Miss Annamary Monahan to William Radford Coyle 3d of New York and Springtown, Pa., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. James Joseph Monahan. Mr. Coyle is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Radford Coyle Jr. of Springtown.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 --There's no doubt about it. People are fascinated with the making of motion pictures. So much so that, even as paying guests and with the California sun at its hottest, they will refrain from plunging into a hotel pool just because there is a motion picture camera working in the immediate area.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 11-- The Virginia House of Delegates reiterated today its opposition to integrated public schools.
RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 12-- The Moroccan Government put into effect today an order expelling more than fifty French citizens.
John L, Schoenfeld, vice chairman of the State Commission of Correction, died of a heart attack yesterday. His age was 73.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 12--the name Rutgers has a special connotation in American football, as does Rugby in the English game.

A stout cigar-chewing man waved a catalogue aloft in a crowded, smoke-filled room yesterday. His action probably spelled a slight increase in the price housewives hereabouts will have to pay for oranges today.

Development of a cheaper, Easter way of making the type of synthetic rubber latex needed by foam rubber manufacturers was announced yesterday by the sponge products division of the B.F. Goodrich Company.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12 (AP) --The Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company said today it had completed laying 110 miles of pipe between Cadiz and Eastlake, Ohio, for the world's first commercial pipeline transportation of coal. Still to be completed are three huge pumping stations that will be some thirty-five miles apart.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 12--The captains of four ports in Mexico have received official orders to suspend indefinitely the repatriation by sea of "wetbacks" (Mexican laborers who have entered the United States illegally).
THE SUITS at Hattie Carnegie are ones to sigh over. The legacy of taste and flawless tailoring left to her designing staff by this superb stylist remains intact.
