MADERA, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP) --A B-52 Stratofortress jet bomber returning to its base burst into flame at 3,000 feet today. It nosed into a dive that tore off one wing, and crashed near U.S. Highway 99, strewing burning wreckage across the four-lane expressway nine miles southeast of Madera.
PLYMOUTH, Mich., Sept. 17-- Charles H. Bennett, head of a concern that has supplied air rifles to three generations of children, died here today. His age was 93.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17-- Secretary of State Dulles left for London today for the third time since the Suez crisis began. He was committed to the basic principle of a plan for a canal users' association, though he was understood to be ready to negotiate on details.

The election of Attorney General Jacob K. Javits to the United States Senate was urged yesterday to prevent the spread of Tammany influences in Washington. Mr. Javits is opposed in the Senate race by Mayor Wagner.
The Navy exhibited yesterday a full-scale model of an earth satellite in which man hopes, a year from now, to make his first tentative probings of outer space.
The American-Marietta Company, makers of chemicals, building materials and household products, set a new high in sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) --Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, said today that former President Truman's claim of proof that Vice President Nixon had called Mr. Truman a traitor was "without foundation."
TOKYO, Sept. 17--A further delay in the resumption of negotiations between Japan and the Soviet Union for a peace agreement was indicated tonight.
Dr. Henry DeWolf Smyth, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission from 1949 to 1954, believes that the Government's "atoms for peace" program is too much talk and too little action.
Mr. and Mrs. Frank Cookman Wright Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of Mr. Wright's sister, Miss Marjorie Wright, also of New York, ...
Plans for the construction of the second of ten new piers in the Port of New York Authority's $85,000,000 Brooklyn waterfront development program were announced here yesterday.

The life and personality of Lord Byron is the subject of a new biography by Eileen Bigland, entitled "Passion for Excitement." The book "casts new light" on the strange and eccentric character of the great Romantic poet.
The Bendix Home Appliances division of the Acvo Manufacturing Corporation soon may make automatic electric washers and driers for the Philco Corporation.
Monroe H. Sander, paint and varnish manufacturer, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 120 East Seventy-ninth Street. His age was 62.

LONDON, Sept. 17--The eighteen-nation mandate given to the Western Big Three for the first phase of the Suez Canal dispute is likely to be whittled down in the next phase, according to present indications.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17--Activity increased today in futures trading on the Board of Trade. Soybeans made their best advance in some time as heavy short covering started. Deferred wheat futures were strong, especially the July, and September corn ...
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 17 --The new movie partnership of Fields Productions, Inc., organized by Joseph Fields, playwright, and United Artists involves as a starter the making of three pictures.
ALEXANDRIA BAY, N.Y., Sept. 16--Some of the ballooning dreams of heavy St. Lawrence Seaway traffic were deflated here today by Seaway and Great Lakes experts.

The smoothness with which the public schools of Louisville, a metropolis of some 400,000 people, were integrated last week stands in ironic contrast to the difficulties through which some of Kentucky's smaller communities are passing.

TRENTON, Sept. 17--Gov. Robert B. Meyner asked the Legislature today to raise the state gasoline tax by 1 cent a gallon to help finance a $175,442,882 two-year roadbuilding program. This would increase the levy to 5 cents a gallon.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17--Following is the text of a letter on the Suez question sent to the President of the Security Council today by Omar Loutfi, Egyptian representative:

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 17--Egypt charged today that the new Western Big Three plan for operation of the Suez Canal by a users' association was a violation of the United Nations Charter and of the Constantinople Convention of 1888.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17--With one victory needed to clinch the American League pennant, Casey Stengel spent today's open date girding his Yankees for their next effort at settling the race.
For a while yesterday it looked as if Friday's stock market rally would continue. Prices moved up smartly in early trading, reflecting a heavy inflow of investors' orders over the week-end.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17-- A remedy for the threatened water shortage in western Westchester County was worked out today. Engineers began laying the groundwork and said the plan would be fully operative by the end of the week.

MUSICAL comedies don't close out-of-town any more; they go on television. "The Lord Don't Play Favorites," last night's original on "Producers Showcase" over Channel 4, would have taxed the hospitality of New Haven.
Nehemiah (Ned) Rosing, a former official of the Legal Aid Society and of Tau Delta Phi national fraternity, died on Sunday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 53 years old.
The "extremely dangerous" bodyguard of Johnny Dio, labor racketeer, was being sought last night by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the acid blinding of Victor Riesel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17--President Eisenhower was told today that the Midwest farm belt was safe Republican territory again this year.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 17--President Eisenhower today sent Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru his personal assurances that the United States was determined to work for a peaceful solution of the Suez crisis.
GENEVA, Sept. 17--Switzerland has expressed a desire to become associated with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (Gatt).
MONTROSE, N.Y., Sept. 17 --Dr. Harry Levi Hollingworth, internationally known psychologist and educator, died today of a heart attack at his home here. He was 76 years old.
Two songwriters told a Congressional subcommittee yesterday that "freedom of music has been seriously impaired by a powerful combination of interests."
CAIRO, Sept. 18--In the view of the Middle East and Asian leaders, the United States is the chief keeper of the keys to a peaceful settlement, of the Suez Canal crisis.
ALBANY, Sept. 18--The Soviet Union and New York State are joining hands in an effort to understand more about heart disease.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18--Michael Todd sought an injunction in Superior Court today to prevent Los Angeles County from seizing the negatives and prints of his new motion picture, "Around the World in 80 Days."
Three Iranian athletic officials who are on a five-month tour of the United States arrived here yesterday. They will make a two-week study of local school athletics.

Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India, assailed the Eisenhower Administration yesterday for "settling for an unworkable truce in a narrow area" when it had a chance to achieve "peace in all of Asia."
More than $50,000,000 in municipal securities will reach the market today.
Eight floors formery occupied by the American Tobacco Company as executive offices at 111 Fifth Avenue, at Eighteenth Street, have been leased by Berley Co., agents.
THE state's important hunter-safety program is afoot again, and many gun clubs and other organizations are helping to train young hunters to kill game instead of their brothers.
A design for a machine that can "feel" things for its operator was suggested here yesterday at the eleventh International Instrument-Automation Conference and Exhibit.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 18--The State Education Department again will ask the Legislature to grant to five large cities the opportunity to have fiscally independent school systems.
TRENTON, Sept. 18--Gov. Robert B. Meyner assailed the Legislature today for not approving a 1-cent-a-gallon rise in the state gasoline tax.

The Rev. Dr. Donald B. Cloward executive secretary of the Council on Christian Social Progress of the American Baptist Convention, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. His age was 60. He had been ill since last June.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- President Eisenhower told Republican campaigners today to stick to truth, to avoid exaggerations or claims of perfection and to leave "the yelling" to the opposition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) --The Communist party asked the Subversive Activities Control Board today to reverse its finding that the party was an agent of Moscow and should register with the Justice Department.
Jacob K. Javits, Republican nominee for the United States Senate, yesterday appointed Charles S. Hamilton Jr., as director of his campaign.
Wall Streeters close to the rails have their eyes turned today toward the new issue market.

Plans for an apartment house in the Stuyvesant Square section were announced yesterday by S. Edwin Kazdin Co., brokers, who have sold five buildings on a plot 119 by 103 feet at 222 to 232 East Fifteenth Street for the Ukranian Autocephalic Orthodox Church of St. Vladimir, Inc. The new owners are Joseph Chinich Sons, builders.

HERE is Outer Mongolia: a trackless waste of 615,000 vast square miles--about the size of Spain, France, the United Kingdom and Italy combined--and one of the most remote countries in the world. This is the area of Central Asia from which that conquering scourge, Genghis Khan, sprang in the thirteenth century to strike terror everywhere in Asia and Europe.

WHY "Camille"? Since it is inconceivable that anyone should have an artistic interest in the old Dumas fils rumpus, one looks for a more practical motive for the production that opened at the Cherry Lane last evening.

WHILE the bulldozers and the riveters noisily revise New York's skyline, tearing down the old and building anew, a scattering of New Yorkers works diligently and lovingly to preserve relics of the city's historic past.
The twenty-seven-member general grievance committee of the Brotherhood of Railroad. Trainmen voted unanimously yesterday in favor of a strike against the New York. New Haven Hartford Railroad.
Importers of Italian Wool fabrics appealed yesterday to President Eisenhower to reject a tariff increase on the products as proposed by domestic producers.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18--A matter of seconds after Brooklyn's defeat by St. Louis had been posted, Milwaukee thickened the National League penant plot to the consistency of a rich gumbo by nailing down a 6-4 verdict over Pittsburgh tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Not "Give 'em Hell" but "Give 'em Heaven"--that is clearly going to be the Republican campaign strategy.
AN intriguing Milanese designer and an admired New Yorker proved yesterday that the language of fashion is universal--only the accent and expression make the difference.
Work has been "slowed somewhat but by no means halted" at the smaller ship repair concerns in this port by a walk-out of machinists.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18--The New York State Thruway was cited today as an outstanding example of construction in conforming to standards of the Federal Interstate Highway System.
Billy Rose displayed his showmanship yesterday at the House Antitrust subcommittee hearing on the television industry.

CHICAGO. Sept. 18--The Yankee dressing quarters became a madhouse as the players raced off the field and for a time it was difficult to tell who was more excited, Casey Stengel as he congratulated his players, or Bill McCorry, the traveling secretary, for whom the evening's worries were just beginning.
Despite a partial recovery in late trading, the stock market declined again yesterday. The skid was considerably sharper than on Monday, sending averages down to the lowest levels of the month.

A hearing in Federal Court here will start today to take depositions to help fix responsibility for the crash between the Italian liner Andrea Doria and the Swedish liner Stockholm on July 25. Fifty persons lost their lives in the accident.
TOKYO, Sept. 18--Leaders of the Opposition Socialist party announced today they would support the Government in its effort
WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 18 --Gen. Douglas MacArthur paid an informal visit to the United States Military Academy today to get some first-hand information about the Army football team.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18--Canadian Seaway authorities have signed contracts for a total of more than $156,000,000 in this country's share of the huge project to make 2,000 miles of waterway available to deep-sea Atlantic shipping.

For variety a person could take another Look at the National League standings and in particular the loss column. No, not way up there, but way down where the New York Giants and the Chicago Cubs ara situated.

Has the International Longshoremen's Association established "democratic ideals, clean and wholesome free trade unionism"? Has it eliminated "all semblance of crime, dishonesty and racketeering"? Has it expelled from the union officers guilty of accepting gifts and bribes from employers? Has it abolished the shape-up method of hiring? Has it removed from all positions of authority union officials with criminal records?

American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported gains in net income for eight and twelve months ended Aug. 31, but a slight decline in August from the preceding year's net income. This was the second consecutive month in which net lagged behind the 1955 level.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Eastern and Western railroads agreed today to seek increases in freight rates ranging up to 15 per cent.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18-- The United States now has under development as many as four types of long-range guided missiles, three of which could be delivered to any continent. The fourth is of intermediate range.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 18 (AP) --Lawrence D. Bell, dean of the country's aviation executives, resigned today as president of the Bell Aircraft Corporation and was elected chairman.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18--Reactionary price trends were the rule in grain and soybean futures today, following sharp upturns on Monday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Adlai E. Stevenson devoted himself today to "digging up the truth" for his forthcoming campaign swing through ten Midwestern and Southern states.

The strains of "The St. Louis Blues" poured mournfully from the Ebbets Field pipe organ at 11 o'clock last night, but not because the Cardinals were mourning. The Redbirds rallied to beat the Dodgers in the ninth inning, 6--5.
The "manufacture" of demand was praised yesterday by Robert F. Carney, chairman of Foote, Cone Belding, as advertising's "unique and great contribution" to the economy.
GIRLS who range around the six-foot mark in height and feel like the orphans of fashion have been adopted by Abraham Straus.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Sept. 18 --International studies of economic problems common to the Canadian Atlantic provinces and the New England States were recommended today by delegates to a joint conference of the regions.

LONDON, Sept. 18--The British Government announced today that the Gold Coast would be given independence next March 6. The decision is subject to Parliamentary approval, but this is considered certain.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 18--Senator Estes Kefauver accused Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. tonight of making "devious and grossly misleading" statements in denying Administration wrongdoing in the Dixon-Yates "scandal."

Four dozen fidgeting school children--their eagerness numbed by a brisk northwest wind and an hour of microphoned rhetoric--pinched, nudged, poked and scowled yesterday afternoon awaiting the unveiling of "their" statue of Hans Christian Andersen in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- The Eisenhower Administration stepped into a hot dispute over disposal of an Indian cemetery in downtown Kansas City, Kan., today. It hoped to save the political scalp of a Republican legislator.

FLINT, Mich. Sept. 18 (AP)-- The Buick Division of the General Motors Corporation announced today it would complete its 1956 model run tomorrow and start 1957 model assemblies Oct. 15. The new models are ...
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 18 (AP)--The New York State Publishers Association called today for repeal of "secrecy and censorship" provisions of the state's new Youth Court act.
Directors of the Sun Oil Company yesterday declared a 6 per cent stock dividend on the common, payable Dec. 10.
JUGGLER trying to keep six plates in the air has it easy compared with C.C. Philippe of the Waldorf-Astoria.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 18-- The Nassau County police renewed their quarrel with The New York Daily News today. The issue was the blame for the failure of the police to keep secret the kidnapping of Peter Weinberger on July 4.

JOHN CHURCHILL, Duke of Marlborough, "the greatest of English soldiers," and his wife, Sarah, "a great woman" but an "intolerable" one, are two of the most interesting human beings in English history. They dominate A.L. Rowse's "The Early Churchills: An English Family"* just as they dominated England for so many years in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Reading about them in this superb book is a richly rewarding experience.
An hour-long anniversary tribute to the late George Gershwin will be heard Sunday on "The Woolworth Hour: Best in Music" over the Columbia Broadcasting System radio network.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 18-- Argentina's "liberating revolution" deposed the dictatorship of President Juan D. Peron a year ago tomorrow. However, since then the nation's restless Army has not been able to settle down and enjoy the fruits of the victory.
A jet ace of the Korean war has flown the Bell X-2 rocket plane to a new altitude record for manned flight.

INWOOD, L.I., Sept. 18--Two New Jersey shotmakers, Bob Crowley of Mountain Ridge and Otto Greiner of Knickerbocker fired two-under-par 71's to pace a field of 166 as the forty-first Metropolitan Golf Association open championship began today over the exacting Inwood Country Club course.

Blessbull and Alibhai Lashes waged an interesting duel in the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday, with the former winning. There were seven contestants in the mile and a furlong event, but it was this pair that provided the excitement.
BOSTON, Wednesday, Sept. 19 (AP) --Massachusetts Democrats yesterday nominated a former member of Congress, Foster Furcolo, to run for Governor at the head of their state ticket in the fall election.
CAIRO, Sept. 18--Egypt declared today a policy of virtual trade boycott against the West and in favor of business with the East.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18-- The head of the united labor movement asserted today that the Republicans would have to accept blame for ten years of depression after the Hoover Administration if they now took credit for prosperity under President Eisenhower.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 18--A 14-year-old American boy shot a robber dead today as the man leveled his pistol to shoot the boy's father, the German police reported.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Government experts have concluded that Western Europe will have to reduce its oil consumption if the Suez Canal is inoperable and the Middle East pipelines are cut.
WASHINGTON, Sept.18 (AP)-- Democrats get a far higher score than Republicans in a labor analysis and appraisal of key votes in Congress.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 18-- Caught in the wake of a $67,000 loss on its first Shakespearean project, the Toledo Zoological Society has dropped the Shakespeare-Under-the-Stars Festival.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18 (UP) --Billy Talbert, the non-playing captain of the United States Davis Cup team, scored a major upset today when he defeated Neale Fraser of Australia, 2-6, 6--4, 6--3, in the second round of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament.
WHITTIER, Calif., Sept. 18-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon promised today to stick to the high road in the 1956 Presidential campaign unless the Democrats got rough.
The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation is expanding its operations into the fields of cellulose casings and polyethylene film through acquisition of the Visking Corporation.

Francis O. Wilcox, Assistant Secretary of State, warned yesterday that it would be "sheer folly" for the United States to cut its support for nonpolitical United Nations programs while the Communists were out to exploit them.
Vincent Astor announced plans yesterday for a forty-six-story office building to occupy the block bounded by Park and Lexington Avenues and Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets.
A major new effort to cope with the growing size and complexity of libraries was begun here yesterday.
PEIPING, Sept. 18--Marshal Peng Teh-huai, Defense Minister, announced today that Communist China was "no longer a country with a weak air force."

New York is considered cleaner than it was a year ago-- ten months of intensive effort have removed some of its doubtful distinction as the dirtiest of the world's large cities. But, Mayor Wagner said yesterday, the time has not come to "hang up the broom."

The curtain rises on another act of the Suez Canal drama today when representatives of the eighteen nations meet again in London. These are the same countries that met in London last month and drew up a plan for the international control and operation of the canal. President Nasser of Egypt rejected the plan, as he has everything that conflicts with his intention of keeping and running the canal for and by Egypt alone.

PORT SAID, Egypt, Sept. 18 --The chief of Egypt's Suez Canal administration said today: "The pilot crisis is over. We now have an ample number of pilots for all ships that might want to come through."
Henry L. Moeller, a civil engineer and a retired brigadier general of the New Jersey National Guard, died Monday at his home, 39 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness. His age was 70.
THE first local museum attraction of the new season opens to the public today--a retrospective exhibition of work by Theodore Roszak at the Whitney Museum.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- President Eisenhower expanded his campaign plans today to include a two-day strike into the heart of the politically sensitive Farm Belt Thursday and Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 (UP)--The Philadelphia Phillies virtually slammed the door on Cincinnati's pennant hopes when they swept a double-header from the Redlegs tonight, 4--3 and 7--4, behind the pitching of Curt Simmons and Robin Roberts.
VINCENT ASTOR, is 65 years old and six feet four inches tall. He has been described in print as a "gaunt, stoop-shouldered giant" with "grasshopper legs."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-- Following are the texts of the remarks today by President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon at the National Airport:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (UP) --The Small Business Administration told President Eisenhower today that it had enough funds to meet the credit needs of all "sound" small concerns unable to obtain funds elsewhere.

PURCHASES N.Y., Sept. 18 --Mrs. George Brady of Scarsdale took a one-stroke lead in the Elizabeth Wheeler 54-hole medal play championship of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association at the Old Oaks course today.

Last night's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Randolph Singers, David Randolph conducting; offered two novelties. One was a performance of a work by Robert L. Beckhard, and the other was the first New York appearance of Mr. Randolph's beard.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 18--Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies warned today against allowing an "open season for military dictators."

The blast of the "smallest" pistol ever produced in a court was said yesterday to have knocked down two patrolmen. However, the Court of Special Sessions ruled that the one-inch pistol was not a firearm.

BACK in the old days any luncheon meeting of the Football Writers Association was better than a vaudeville show--and a lot funnier, too. There invariably was a sparkingly witty exchange between Sleepy Jim Crowley of Fordham and Mal Stevens of New York University. There would be amusing talks from Lou Little of Columbia, Chick Meehan of Manhatten and also a hilarious interlude from some visitor such as Jimmy Conzelman.
The Yankee fan reached over and snapped off the television set. He rose from his easy chair and called to his wife upstairs, "They've clinched it, dear."
MONTREAL, Sept. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Senator Adelard Godbout, former Liberal Premier of Quebec, died in a hospital here tonight after a fall in his home in which his skull was fractured.
BOSTON, Sept. 18--With the air of a professor deliveririg a lecture, Joseph (Specs) O'Keefe today gave his version of the $1,218,211 Brink's, Inc., robbery.
BOSTON, Sept. 18--Mr. and Mrs. Lyneham Crocker have made known the engagement of their niece, Dr. Anne Wight, to Asa E. Phillips Jr. of Boston. The wedding will take place in Brookline on Nov. 18.
The Citizens Waterfront Committee broke a lengthy silence yesterday to urge that the merged labor movement open its ranks to the International Longshoremen's Association.

Harvey M. Matusow, turnabout witness in Communist trials, was on trial himself yesterday in Federal Court here. He was accused of having uttered "a vicious and monstrous lie" designed to release his fellow-travelers from prison.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Sept. 18--Queen Juliana chose her most important annual speech as a means to express Dutch disappointment over the Failure of civil air negotiations with the United States.

"Major Barbara" isn't worrying any more about permanent quarters. At the Martin Beck, the Shaw revival, which employs a glittering array of performers, will be a temporary resident-- Oct. 30 through Nov. 17. Expectations of moving to the ANTA Theatre proved to be wishful thinking. "Middle of the Night," the current attraction there, didn't want to be disturbed by going elsewhere.

FOR the second program of its season at the Metropoli tan Opera House, the Royal Danish Ballet brought out one of its most beloved classics, August Bournonville's "Napoli, or The Fisherman and His Bride," first produced in 1842.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) --Cash dividends paid by corporations during the first eight months of this year ran 15 per cent above the 1955 level and seemed well on the way to setting a new record for a year, the Government reported today.
City Council President Abe Stark rode in on the Queen Mary yesterday a much more important man than he had been when he left the city on Aug. 17 for an overseas vacation.

Corporate security offerings totaling more than $190,000,000 will reach the market today in one of the biggest volume days in recent months.
The Roman Catholic Church has always played a great role in Spanish history. It is now playing its greatest, for it has never had more power than under the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday in dull trading on the New York Exchanges. Potatoes, coffee, cocoa, copper, lead, zinc, hides, burlap and soybean oil declined; sugar rose, and price movements for cottonseed oil, rubber and wool were mixed.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York has a new manager--Bruno Zirato, who has been co-manager of the orchestra since 1947. His appointment, which is effective Oct. 1, was made unanimously yesterday at the annual board of directors meeting.
ROME, Sept. 18--Space physicists are convinced that at least thirty and perhaps a hundred artificial moons will be launched before the first manned rockets voyage into space.
SAPPORO, Japan, Sept. 17-- The harassment of Japanese fishing fleets in northern waters has been increased by the Soviet Union to an extraordinary degree in recent months.

A NEW type of full-color spectacular was offered last night on Channel 4; it was Jack Webb's thirty-minute commercial for Mr. Webb.
An unusual concept of a "safe" automobile was outlined yesterday by two leaders in traffic research.
The Rev. William Howard Melish won his legal battle yesterday to retain the post as supply priest at the Protestant Episcopal Church of then Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 18--Yugoslav leaders are putting the best face on the visit here tomorrow Of Nikita S. Khrushchev, but with definite misgivings about the possible effects of his arrival on Western public opinion.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18--Mickey Mantle's fiftieth home run brought the struggle for the American League's 1956 pennant to a dramatic close tonight.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 18-- Margaret (Wiffi) Smith launched her bid for the women's United States amateur golf title today. The 19-year-old girl from St. Clair, Mich., who holds the British and French women's amateur crowns, was forced to an extrahole match in her opening test.
LONDON, Sept. 18--Secretary of State Dulles worked hard in London today to hold together the eighteen-nation group that had united in favor of international operation of the Suez Canal.

LONDON, Sept.18--The stock market ended quietly today in advance of a speech to be made by the Chancellor of the Exchequer tomorrow, when he is expected to comment on the economic consequences of the Suez crisis. Business again contracted except in South African gold mining and Western Hemisphere oil shares.
Mayor Wagner's administration is considering the introduction of bills in the City Council to set up tighter controls over contracts with concessionaires in city parks.
STURGIS, Ky., Sept. 18--The Union County School Board voted today to bar Negro students from the public schools here.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 18-- Virginia's House of Delegates approved today, 61 to 37, Gov. Thomas B. Stanley's bill to withhold state funds from schools that adopt integration.

MONTCLAIR, N, J., Sept. 19 --Edwin Merton McBrier, an original partner of the late Frank W. Woolworth in the fiveand-ten-cent store business, died here today in the Mountainside Hospital after a short illness. His age was 91.

The Garrett Corporation, en-... gineers and makers of products closely allied with the aviation, machine tool and hardware industries reported yesterday record sales and earnings for its last fiscal year.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 19--Boston College opens its football season against Miami in Florida and Coach Mike Holovak can't sleep for thinking about it.

The new "soft" tactics of communism require changed propaganda efforts by the democracies, Ernst Tillich, West German anti-Communist leader, said here yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 19--An International Labor Organization conference to discuss the working conditions of seamen and ships' officers opened here today. Governments, ship owners land seafarers are represented.
CHICAGO, Thursday, Sept. 20 --Union meat packers began a strike at 12:01 A.M. today against Swift Co., the nation's largest packinghouse.

Futures on the New York exchanges continued generally weak in dull trading yesterday. Copper, wool, rubber, hides, burlap, sugar and tin declined; potatoes rose, and price movements for coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil and soybean oil were mixed.

OYSTER BAY, L. I, Sept. 19 --One race of the two that were planned in the Canadian-American 6-meter team match was sailed today in moderate, shifting southeast air. When it was over the United States had a tentative hold on victory.
STURGIS, Ky., Sept. 19--Eight Negro students were denied admittance to the Sturgis High School this morning.

DACCA, Pakistan, Sept. 20-- The East Pakistan Assembly repealed today the Public Safety Act under which persons could be detained without trial.
TORONTO, Sept. 20 (Canadian Press)--A play written by a wartime pilot of suburban Scarborough will be made into ...

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 20-- Frederick W. Roedel, a jeweler here and a member of the executive board and finance committee of the New York State Retail Jewelers Association, died today of a heart attack at the age of 70.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 20-- The new Elizabeth Wheeler champion of the Women's TriCounty Golf Association is Mrs. George Brady of Scarsdale.
OHRBACH'S is the Cook's of the fashion world--invaluable agents if you're planning a shopping tour of the great stylesetting salons of London, Paris and Rome.

VALLETTA, Malta, Sept. 20 (AP)--A British ship captain said today Egyptian hiring agents had lured away sixteen of his crew in a Libyan harbor. He said he sped out to sea to keep others from deserting.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 20 (AP) --The Navy and Georgia will meet in the Oyster Bowl football game here next year on Oct. 19, it was announced today.

The Government yesterday completed the direct questioning of Roly M. Cohn, its chief witness in the perjury trial of Harvey M. Matusow. The defendant has worked for the Communists and for the Government and repudiated each of them.
The late Isaac Newton Falk, an ardent New York Giant baseball fan and a member of the staff of The New York Times reference department (morgue) for twenty-six years, willed ...
The Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. said yesterday that any increase in the tariff on wool goods would be inflationary and would create "price chaos" in the industry.
The common stock of the American Hardware Corporation, New Britain, Conn., producer of locks a builders' hardware, will be admitted to trading on the New York Stock Exchange next Monday.
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 20-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon continued tonight his role as chief Republican answer-man to Democratic attacks on President Eisenhower.
Jersey-bound service on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad was delayed for twenty-three minutes during the rush hour last night when a motorman became ill shortly after leaving Christopher Street.

The New York Knickerbockers will play twenty-two league games in Madison Square Garden during the 1956-57 National Basketball Association campaign. Six more contests are listed for the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.
Customers of New York City banks wrote checks last month at the fastest August pace in twenty-five years, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

GREEN BAY, Wis., sept. 20 (AP)--J.M. Conway, president of Charmin Paper Mills, Inc., of Green Bay, announced today that negotiations had been nearly completed for the transfer of Charmin's assets to the Procter Gamble Company of Cincinnati in exchange for common stock of the latter concern.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 20 (AP)--A pro-segregation rally will be held in suburban Fountain City Sunday afternoon, with Asa Carter of Birmingham, Ala., billed as the chief speaker.
LE HAVRE, France, Sept. 20 (Reuters)--The liner United States was rerouted to Cherbourg today when Le Havre tugmen went on strike over a new wage claim.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20--The President of the American Medical Association told hospital administrators here today that his profession was concerned with "attempts by certain hospitals to inject themselves into the practice of medicine."

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 20 (UP)--A co-medalist, Ken Venturi, was fourunder-par today as he advanced to the third round of the California amateur golf tournament with a 7-and-6 victory over Jack Wallace.
The taxpayer building containing four stores at 42-44 Main Street, White Plains, N.Y., was sold by Main Street Associates to a syndicate headed by John E. Marqhsee and L. William Kay 2d.

A campaign urging Government approval for large theatreowner organizations to produce motion pictures appeared likely yesterday. This was indicated at the opening of the five-day first annual international convention and trade show of the Theatre Owners of America at the Coliseum.
A total of 101 nursing students here were graduated last night.
KINGS PARK, L.I., Sept. 20 --The School of Nursing at Kings Park State Hospital celebrated its sixtieth anniversary here today with a brief ceremony and dinner dance.
GENEVA, Sept. 18--In their latest look at East Europe, United Nations economists have spotted an unusual number of stresses and strains.
Two more manufacturers of cement and a maker of heavy construction machinery announced price increases yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20--A United Nations atomic energy conference attended by representatives of eighty-one states opened here today. approve the draft statute, or article of incorporation, of the proposed international atomic energy agency.

PARIS, Sept. 20--Most Parisians had difficulty finding bread today. The great majority of bakeries in the Paris region did not open for business as bakers continued their protest against the government's refusal to allow higher prices.
The Railway Express Agency announced yesterday that it would soon provide a single carrier surface transportation service for export-import trade with Japan.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20 --The Rev. Peter K. Emmons, president of the board of trustees of Princeton Theological Seminary here, today laid the cornerstone for the seminary's $1,500,000 Robert E. Speer Library, begun last spring.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20--Following are the texts of a speech by Joao Carlos Muniz of Brazil, president of the atomic energy conference, ...
Frank Callan Norris was named yesterday the winner of the $10,000 Harper prize novel contest for his story "Tower in the West." The book is planned for publication Jan. 2.
The Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra will open its first American tour in Washington on Nov. 4.
L.C. Stowell, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Underwood Corporation, will retire on Nov. 1. He was named president of Underwood in 1945 and chairman in 1955.

Commodity prices on the New York exchanges moved irreguularly higher yesterday in slightly more active trading. Cottonseed oil, cocoa, potatoes, copper and zinc rose; wool, hides and sugar declined, and price movements for coffee, rubber and Burlap were mixed.
BY all odds the youngest rider at Aqueduct Race track is blue-eyed, chubby Jeanette Louise Devine, 8 months old.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 20 --After the most unsatisfactory fortnight Qf practice he says he has put in during his long coaching career, Lloyd Jordan has his reservations about Harvard being a strong contender for the Ivy League championship.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 20--Nikita S. Khrushchev left Belgrade this morning with President Tito for the privacy of the state farm at Belje in eastern Croatia.
The Long Island Rail Road has resumed its special one-day week-end excursion fares to Brooklyn and Manhattan that it began last spring and discontinned during the Summer.
A daughter, their second, was born in the LeRoy Hospital last Saturday to Mr. and Mrs. William Bleecker Matteson of New York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20-- Miss Bernice Ann Wilson daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan M. Wilson of Washington, and Pvt. V. Everard Munsey Jr. of ...
Burning issues of past Presidential campaigns were transcribed into political cartoons with a ferocity seldom matched today, the New-York Historical Society has found in a review of its collection.

STURGIS, Ky., Sept. 20-- Eight Negro pupils, barred from the all-white Sturgis High School, have started a boycott of their own. They refuse to enroll in the all-Negro school in Morganfield, eleven miles away.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (U.P.) --Horace B. McCoy, a veteran career Government worker, was appointed today as administrator of the Department of Commerce, Business and Defense Services Administration.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20--The pennant hopes of the Braves suffered a damaging blow today when the Milwaukeans lost a 10-inning 2-1 decision to the Pittsburgh Pirates.
ALBANY, Sept. 20 (AP)--Richand H. Balch, Public Service Commissioner, was appointed today to Governor Harriman's Advisory Council on the Uses of Nuclea Material.

PARIS, Sept. 20 (AP)--The Buchan Bakers of Seattle won the seventh straight game of their basketball tour tonight by beating a French. Army team, 74--68. The A.A.U. champions led, 40--36, at the half.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP). --Ten American ship pilots who have responded to an Egyptian offer of high pay for work on the Suez Canal were invited by the State Department today to talk it over.
The Transport Workers Union threatened yesterday to strike the Third Avenue Transit System "early next week" unless the carrier agreed to an "immediate" meeting on several grievances.
DENVER, Sept. 20 (AP)--Gov. Edwin C. Johnson, who has had many roles in his varied career, will add another soon--a movie ...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) --The Secretary of Labor said today that if Democrats were serious about their party's platform pledges to repeal the TaftHartley Law and enact a $1.25 ...
The performance of "Carmen" on the evening of March 9 at the Metropolitan Opera House has been taken over by the New York Vassar Club to benefit its scholarship fund.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 20-- The extraordinary Suffolk County grand jury returned today additional indictments against Albert Friestadt of Bay Shore, William Egelman of Islip and Irving Garfinkle of Huntington Station for ifrst and second-degree grand larceny.
Senator Ellender has now denied that he made the slurring remark about the Korean people that was attributed to him in Jakarta. If he can set the record straight with the Koreans so much the better.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 20--Mrs. Evans Morgan of Wee Burn and Mrs. William Hanssler of Bonnie Briar won the Women's Westchester-Fairfield annual two-ball foursomes tournament with a combined score of 43, 42--85 at Westchester Hills today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20-- Representatives of 1,200,000 steel workers voted today pay rises of $10,000 a year each to their three top union officers.
The procedure for the compulsory inspection of motor vehicles was demonstrated here yesterday by inspectors of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau.
WHENEVER the southwest winds let people alone for a day or so, the bluefish anglers of the Long Island South Shore do brisk business.
The meeting of representatives of the twenty-one Presidents of the United States and Latin America this week in Washington accomplished all that it set out to do.
ALBANY, Sept. 20 (AP)--With summer still on the calendar, snow fell in New York State today.

LONDON, Sept. 20--The British Government has not decided what approach, if any, it will make to the United States for financial assistance to offset whatever economic damage the country may suffer through the Suez crisis.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference reported yesterday that twenty-six of its 105 member schools have received approval of their applications for special waivers of the one-year residence rule for freshmen.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Sept. 20--Douglas Gilmore Anderson, former Vice president of Pillsbury Mills, Inc., of Minneapolis and for the last eight years a youth leader here, died last night in Cottage Hospital.
Cities Service Company announced yesterday that its crude runs to refineries for the first eight months of 1956 were 4 per cent below the level for the same period last year.

Princess Anne Marie Galitzine and Arthur Mountiford Longfield Ponsonby of London, nephew of the late Earl of Bessborough, former Governor-General of Canada, were married at the London Registry Office yesterday afternoon.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will allow two representatives of the Texas Attorney General's office to inspect some of its records here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--Assets of national banks on June 30 amounted to $111,000,000,000, Controller of the Currency Ray M. Gidney announced today.
The assurance of State Public Works Superintendent Johnson that his department is gearing itself for an expected increase in road-building is to be welcomed.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 20 (AP)--The "Suez squadron," which France alerted after the canal crisis broke, arrived here today. The squadron includes the 35,000-ton battleship Jean Bart, a cruiser, an aircraft carrier and ten destroyers.

The Briarfield, a six-story apartment house at 140-55 Burden Crescent, Kew Gardens Queens, was sold by Theodore Basch to Kerbel Zipes, realty operators, in a deal arranged by Stanley Russell Associates, Inc, brokers.

The appointment of Carl O. Newton as vice president in charge of sales of the L.S. Starrett Company, effective Oct. 1, has been announced by Arthur H. Starrett, president of the precision tool manufacturing company.
DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP)--A five-foot effigy of a Negro hung from the flagpole at Seacrest High School when students arrived for classes today.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 12 to 21 points yesterday, with far months strongest.

Dr. Ramon de Lara, former rector of the University of Santo Domingo and later a surgeon and gynecologist in Caracas, Venezuela, died yesterday in the Meurice Hotel here, following an operation. His age was 72.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 20--James J. Wadsworth, who acted as temporary chairman when the atomic conference convened here this afternoon, is a tall, easy-going native of the Genesee Valley in upper New York State. Known to virtually everyone as "Jerry," he is one ...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--The Government has been asked to exclude foreign bidders on Government contracts for hydraulic turbines.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 20 --The government of Premier W.A.C. Bennett swept to a landslide victory for the third time in four years in British Columbia last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP)-- The International Corporation Administration announced today it spent more than $1,000,000,000 to sell surplus United States farm products to foreign countries during the last three years.
The Navy announced yesterday that it had awarded more than $2,230,000 in contracts to shipyards on the East Coast for the repair and overhaul of six vessels.
BOSTON, Sept. 20--The Brink's robbery gang once considered burning out a city-wide burglar alarm system on the night of the $1,218,211 robbery, a self-confessed member said today.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Friday, Sept. 21--Three Greek Cypriote rebels were hanged by the British authorities in Nicosia CenItral Prison today for violence and murder.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UP)--The Chicago White Sox entered into a full working agreement with the Indianapolis Indians of the American Association today.
Succoth, the Jewish holiday known as the Feast of the Tabernacles, was hailed yesterday in sermons by spiritual leaders in temples and synagogues here.
Rails were a bright spot in the late trading yesterday. Nevertheless, the market declined for the fourth straight session, and key averages closed at the lowest levels in almost three months.

The Brooklyn campaign for $174,500 in the Girl Scout annual fund drive was opened at a meeting of Brooklyn men's committees in the St. George Hotel yesterday. Miss Dorothy Stratton, national executive director of the Girl Scouts, said:
A secondary offering of 7,700 shares of Rome Cable Company common stock at $27.125 a share is being made by A.C. Allyn Co.
Columbia University has established scholarships for the first time at the ten-year-old School of General Studies, the undergraduate school for adults.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP)-- Plant changes here and in Pennsylvania and California were announced yesterday by the Standard Register Company, manufacturer of business forms and equipment.

IF the taste and elegance that Offenbach distilled in his music were carried over into the new libretto that the City Center has provided for "Orpheus in the Underworld," there would be occasion for rejoicing this morning.
AS the new school year gets under way, parents can expect to hear anguished cries from their offspring. Last year's allowance, it will appear, has become as tight a fit as last year's Sunday suit.
An agreement was signed yesterday for construction of a shelter at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for the 100,000 animals that are shipped through the airport every year.
Loans to business on the books of leading New York City banks rose $69,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

ALFRED DUGGAN'S seventh historical novel, "Winter Quarters," is published today. To the loyal body of discriminating readers who regard Mr. Duggan as one of the few modern masters of historical fiction this will be good news.
HONG KONG, Sept. 20 (UP) --An invitation from Communist China to United States reporters to visit the mainland expired today with no acceptances.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 20-- Karl V. Wheeler, a retired steel executive, died this morning at his home here. He was 71 years old. Mr. Wheeler retired seven years ago after forty-five years in the steel industry. Until three months ago, he lived in Westfield, N.J.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP)--Don Williams, the New England middleweight champion, tonight pounded out a ten-round unanimous decision over Maurice (Choo-Choo) Jenkins of Newark, N.J. Each weighed 156 pounds.
ALBANY, Sept. 20 (AP)--C. Addision Keeler Jr., a 25-year-old Binghamton lawyer, was appointed today a confidential law assistant in the Appellate Court Division, Third Department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (U.P.) --Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, Republican of Massachusetts, received White House assurances today that the United States was making "good progress" in negotiations with Tokyo on restricting Japanese textile shipments.
DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 20-- Retail prices will be up an average of $75 a car in the 1957 Ford line.

The Vacation Camp for the Blind, which since 1926 has tried to meet the special needs of the blind, will benefit from the Sept. 29 matinee performance of the Royal Danish Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.
This fall, when the famous Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra makes its regular tour of the Low Countries, Leonard Felberg will go along as the newest member of the violin section.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) --President Eisenhower today set the week beginning Oct. 7 as National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week. He said that "opportunity for employment should not be denied any qualified person because of a physical handicap."

The contempt of court conviction of a partner in one of the largest trucking concerns in the garment center was reversed yesterday and his three-month prison sentence voided. The action was taken in a 2-to-1 decision by the United States Court of Appeals.
Western Union Telegraph Company has been awarded a $5,600,000 contract to provide specially designed automatic communication centers overseas for the United States Air Force.
Robert E. Kintner, president of the American Broadcasting Company, defended television network practices yesterday before the House Antitrust subcommittee investigating the industry.
POTSDAM, N.Y., Sept. 20-- Jacob K. Javits, State Attorney General, called today for closer partnership between government and business to help underdeveloped and distressed areas of the state.
LONDON, Sept. 20--The preservation of unity has taken precedence over practical achievements as the main objective of Western diplomats in the Suez Canal conference here, according to some delegates.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 21 (Reuters)--The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia printed today a letter from the Bolshoi Theatre saying that its ballet group would not make a scheduled visit to London because of the Nina Ponomareva affair.

Nearly five weeks have elapsed since Horace Stoneham, the president of the Giants, gave Bill Rigney, the manager of his team, a partial vote of confidence. At that time, it might be recalled, the Giants were in eighth place, going nowhere and, apparently, taking Rigney along with them.

Net income of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for the first seven months this year dropped to $27,288,839, a decline of $1,216,446 from the $28,505,285 reported for the same period last year, the road announced yesterday.
TOKYO, Sept. 24--Shunichi Matsumoto, Japan's expert on the treaty negotiations with the Soviet Union, left for Moscow tonight. He will attempt to prepare the ground for the proposed top-level parley.
Three unidentified men, described as in their early 30's, escaped with $1,500 in cash and checks from the Triboro Bar and Grill, 340 Paladino Avenue at East 118th Street, last night.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 20-- An attempt to reconstruct Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's winning political combination of 1953 collapsed today. There was an argument about who tried to make up with whom.
CAIRO, Sept. 20--Talks on troubles along Palestine armistice lines continued here todday.
Anthony (Tony) Anastasia, Brooklyn dock boss, suffered one outright defeat and at least a partial setback last night.

ALEDO, Ill., Sept. 20 (AP)--A collision of a bus and a truck loaded with corn killed two persons and injured at least ten others near here today. The victims were the bus driver and a woman passenger.
A new theatre group that will present former Broadway stage successes at the Palace Theatre at Fort Wayne, Ind., beginning Nov. 5 has been organized by Douglas Conway, actor.

CAIRO, Sept. 20--President Gamal Abdel Nasser was depicted today as hopeful that the London conference would produce a formula for negotiation rather than rigid proposals he would be forced to reject.
The American Society of Civil Engineers has elected Mason G. Lockwood president.

United States and Canadian newsprint mills set new monthly production records in August with combined output of 724,674 tons, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday. This figure was 7.2 per cent higher than combined output in August last year.
BOONE, Iowa, Sept. 20-- President Eisenhower opened his campaign for the 161 electoral votes of the Middle West tonight with a fifty-mile drive through the rolling countryside of central Iowa.
The Florida Development Commission rejected yesterday the only bid received for $5,500,000 of twenty-nine-year Sarasota County bridge revenue bonds.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 20--The military police questioned four Indonesian editors for having printed stories that violated the new Army decree prohibiting press criticism of Government officials, it was reported today.
The Ohio Edison Company will double the size of its steamelectric power plant that is now under construction at Stratton on the Ohio River, Walter H. Sammis, president, announced yesterday.

A series of workshop meetings for Democratic candidates for Congress and the Legislature will get under way tomorrow. Governor Harriman is to speak at the session for Queens County candidates, which will be held from 3 P.M. to 6 P.M. at 64-57 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 20-- Miss Carroll Winslow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Wallace Winslow, was married here this afternoon to Robert Brentano, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. August Brentano of Newburgh, Ind., by the Rev. Harrold A. Murray.
SILVER SPRING, Md., Sept. 20 (AP)--Following is the text of Adlai E. Stevenson's speech here tonight:

IT doesn't seem long ago that everyone was taking for granted that Mickey Mantle would breeze off with baseball's Triple Crown, the championships in hitting, homers and runs batted in. But with only a little more than a week of the season remaining, Master Mickey is assured of only home run laurels.
Thirteen small tenants of the General Motors Building at 1775 Broadway have banded together to tell the court that what's good for General Motors is not good for them.

CHERRY POINT, N.C., Sept. 20 (UP)--One Marine pilot was injured seriously and a second escaped with minor injuries when their jet fighters crashed here today. The planes developed engine trouble and crashed as they took off from the Marine Corps Air Station here.
Druggists have been watching supermarkets and other retailers take away a good portion of their volume on well-advertised drug items. Hand-wringing and complaining do not help, they have found.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Sept. 20--The setting at the Lawrenceville School was different this afternoon. Larry Tiihonen, the head football coach of the Red and Black for the last twenty-seven years, wasn't on the gridiron. He was in his office in the school's huge fieldhouse.

James R. Bivens of 66 Prudence Drive, Springdale, Conn., assistant director of employe relations for the Columbia Gas System, died Wednesday night of a heart ailment in Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 50.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 20-- Virginia's House of Delegates approved today bills aimed at curtailing groups bringing racial litigation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20-- United States payments to foreign countries advanced during the second quarter of this year, chiefly as a result of sharp gains in the outflow of private and Government capital.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 20 (AP) --Buddy Young, who survived nine years of professional football, although only 5 feet 4 inches tall and 170 pounds, retired today.
Scores of public officials joined with relatives and friends yesterday at a funeral service for Francis J. Sinnott, Kings County Clerk who died Sunday at the age of 65.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Sept. 20 --Northwest winds that piped to 25 knots, churned Long Island Sound into white frost and snapped stays like rubber bands also produced two victories today for the United States in six-meter sailing against Canada.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) --The number of new polio cases rose to at least 956 last week, the highest weekly total for the year.

The former chief officer of the Waterfront Commission declared yesterday that the same reasons that led to the expulsion of the International Longshoremen's Association from the ranks of organized labor in 1953 "compel its exclusion in 1956."

What Chairman Lewis L. Strauss of the United States Atomic Energy Commission called "the bounties of the beneficent atom" is the subject of "perhaps the largest conference in the entire history of international collaboration," which opened yesterday at the United Nations, in this city.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP)-- Goldnose outlasted the 2-1 favorite, Speed Rouser, and won the $5,000 Wardsworth Purse today in 1:10 3-5, the fastest sixfurlong time of the current Hawthorne meeting. Goldnose returned $20.20. Tuosix was third.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 20--Miss Carolyn G. Hourigan, daughter of Mrs. John A. Hourigan of Wilkes-Barre and Glen Summit, and the late Mr. Hourigan, was married today to Thomas J. Mack of Wilkes-Barre and Bear Creek at St. Jude's Roman Catholic Church in Mountaintop.

The Jan. 17 performance of "Bells Are Ringing," the new musical comedy starring Judy Holliday, will be a benefit for the Wellesley College Faculty Endowment Fund. The musical will open at the Shubert Theatre on Nov. 29.
The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that it had mailed to more than 8,000 subscribers application forms for opening night tickets.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics decreased to 91.5 on Wednesday from 91.9 on Tuesday. The figure for Sept. 21, 1955, was 89.9.
MISSOULA, Mont., Sept. 20-- Senator Estes Kefauver accused President Eisenhower today of peddling a false bill of goods to the nation on the farm problem.
James T. Phillips was promoted yesterday to senior vice president and chief actuary of New York Life Insurance Company. Raymond C. Johnson was named vice president in charge of agency affairs.

State Investigation Commissioner J. Irwin Shapiro said yesterday he had turned over to the Westchester District Attorney "important" information on the unsolved murder of John Acropolis, a union leader.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--President Eisenhower expressed confidence today that a current Congressional inquiry here would not "impair" racial integration of the District of Columbia's public schools.
William J. Ronan, Dean of the New York University Graduate School of Public Administration and Public Service, was sworn in by Mayor Wagner yesterday as First Deputy City Administrator.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) --The Internal Revenue Service showed today the 1957 model tax forms that 60,000,000 Americans will use next spring to pay taxes on their 1956 income.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 20 (U.P.)--A schedule of "award" games honoring former players and coaches elected to the Football Hall of Fame was announced today by George E. Little, the executive secretary of the shrine.
ALBANY, Sept. 20--George P. Monaghan, the State Harness Racing Commissioner, won ground today in his running battle with the United States Trotting Association.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 20--A three-man delegation from the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Trade has arrived here. Thjodviljin, Communist newspaper, said today the negotiations were going well and there was a good prospect that Iceland could sell more goods to the Soviet Union in the future.
There is one factor for which Generalissimo Francisco Franco is universally reproached in Spain: he has made no preparations for what will happen after his death or incapacitation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UP) --Ezra Taft Benson told President Eisenhower today he was "very much encouraged over the improvement in the agriculture picture."
An operating expense goal of $960,000 has been set for they 1957 finance campaign of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 20-- Dr. Walter Kolb, Social Democratic Lord Mayor of Frankfurt, died of a heart attack early today. He was 54 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP)--Argentina today became a member of the World Bank for Reconstruction and Development and of the International Monetary Fund and announced it will follow "a firm policy of international economic cooperation."

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 20--Robert W. Ostendorff of 66 Milton Road, Rye, was killed at 9:20 P.M. last night when he was struck by a westbound car while crossing the Boston Post Road near Beach Avenue here. He was a bookkeeper, 65 years ...
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.
OLEAN, N.Y., Sept. 20 (UP) --The Rev. Malachy Wall, who has been serving for the last two years as a Franciscan missionary at St. Bonaventure monastery in Paterson, N.J., has ...

Central registration closed yesterday with a new record. Although the official tabulation for the five boroughs will not be available until today, Board of Election officials said it was in excess of 25,000. The old figure was 22,788 set in 1952, the last Presidential year.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 20-- Two teen-age golfers gained the semi-finals of the women's United States amateur championship today.
The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists opened negotiations yesterday for new contracts with the television and radio networks.
ROME, Sept. 20--Man's endeavor to explore the universe by launching rockets and satellites into space received today the formal benediction of Pope Plus XII.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 20 --Mrs. A.B. Cook of Plainfield won low gross with a 51, 51-- 102 in a women's New Jersey Senior Golf Association one-day tournament on the Arcola Country Club course today. First place in the net class went to Mrs. Burtis Horner of Glen Ridge, who shot a 119--32--87.

The Big Sisters, Inc., which through casework service tries to help girls under the age of 16 and boys under 10, will benefit from the Feb. 19 performance of "Bells Are Ringing.'" The musical starring Judy Holliday opens Nov. 29 at the Shubert Theatre.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (UP) --Gilbert Shea of Los Angeles upset Hamilton Richardson of Westfield, N.J., today in a marathon quarter-final match of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament, 11--9, 10--12, 6--3, 6--4.
ROME, Sept. 20--Man's endeavor to explore the universe by launching rockets and satellites into space received today the formal benediction of Pope Plus XII.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 20 --Mrs. A.B. Cook of Plainfield won low gross with a 51, 51-- 102 in a women's New Jersey Senior Golf Association one-day tournament on the Arcola Country Club course today. First place in the net class went to Mrs. Burtis Horner of Glen Ridge, who shot a 119--32--87.

The Big Sisters, Inc., which through casework service tries to help girls under the age of 16 and boys under 10, will benefit from the Feb. 19 performance of "Bells Are Ringing.'" The musical starring Judy Holliday opens Nov. 29 at the Shubert Theatre.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (UP) --Gilbert Shea of Los Angeles upset Hamilton Richardson of Westfield, N.J., today in a marathon quarter-final match of the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament, 11--9, 10--12, 6--3, 6--4.
CHICAGO, Sept. 20--Mediation efforts were stalled tonight in a strike of union meat packers that closed thirty-nine Swift Co. plants throughout the country.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 20-- Chemical alarms that "ring out" warnings in the presence of minute quantities of deadly poison war gases have been developed by the Army Chemical Corps.
Twentieth century central heating cooled the demand for fur rugs, but Black, Starr and Gorham is making a hot bid for its return.
The navigating officer of the Swedish liner Stockholm conceded yesterday that the Italian liner Andrea Doria had been temporarily obscured by a fog bank shortly before the two ships collided.
An unidentified woman, about 65 years old, plunged to her death yesterday from the roof of a ten-story building at 93 Nassau Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20-- In ten years the Soviet Union's Navy has risen from seventh to second place among the world's navies, a seven-man team of North Atlantic Treaty Organization experts declared here today.
The State Temporary Commission on the Courts has named Timothy N. Pfeiffer as counsel, it was announced yesterday by Harrison Tweed, the commission chairman.
The Red Cross will collect blood today from Maris Stella Council, Knights of Columbus, at 1848 Cornaga Avenue, Far Rockaway, Queens.

ESKISEHIR, Turkey, Sept. 20 (AP)--Donald A. Quarles, United States Secretary of the Air Force, today presented to Turkey fourteen supersonic Thunderflash jet photo planes. They were the first of fifty scheduled for delivery to the Turkish Air Force.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 20 (UP) --An average of 2,000 migrant farm workers are leaving Mexico every day to harvest crops in the United States, the Labor Ministry said today. The total under contract for the year was listed at 359,362. This was some 40,000 below the 1955 figure.
Spokesmen for the leading five power companies of New York State reaffirmed yesterday their intentions of fighting public development of hydroelectric power at Niagara Falls.
TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 20 (AP) --A special stockholders' meeting of the Thermoid Company was halted today when the company's president, Warren E. Hill, read a court injunction barring the meeting.

PARIS, Sept. 20--Political and labor leaders of six European states demanded today that a treaty establishing a supranational atomic community and a survey of its costs and possibilities be completed this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 820,666 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
