SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Sept. 23--Dr. Henry T. Moore, president of Skidmore College, hailed the gifts of the Ford Foundation today as an "answer to the Soviet challenge." He spoke at a convocation ceremony. He has announced his intention of retiring next July 1.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 23 (AP)--Dr. Aurel Varranai, correspondent of Reuters news agency, was released from a Hungarian prison yesterday, his family said today. Dr. Varranai, a Hungarian citizen, was arrested in 1952, spent four and a half years in prison on charges never made public and now is free on probation. He is in good health, his wife said.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 23--The Duffy Stables' Andante scored 15 points to win the open jumper championship in the third annual Sands Point horse show at Manor Haven Park today.
Jed Harris flew to Hollywood yesterday to persuade Anne Baxter to accept a starring role in his production of "Child of Fortune" and to come East for rehearsals, beginning a week from today.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 23--The Cohasset (Mass.) Yacht Club today lost the third and final race of its 210 Class interfleet series with Western Long Island Sound, 301 points to 30. Cohasset had captured the series yesterday by taking the first two races.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--The Republicans hit back today at Adlai E. Stevenson's farm speech amid indications President Eisenhower may offer new proposals when he makes a major farm address at Peoria, Ill., on Tuesday.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, which still remembers "Mama," is making plans to revive the television program early in January. It would be presented on Sundays from 5 to 5:30 P.M.

NEW SMYRNA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP)--Four firemen were hospitalized and twenty-five others received first aid as the result of a fire in a bank today. The blaze was brought under control after eleven hours. Damage was estimated at $200,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Adlai E. Stevenson said today in a telegram read at a Negro mass meeting that House hearings into school integration here "are serving no useful purpose."

CHICAGO, Sept. 23--The lard price trend last week was irregular, but there was fair support on the decreases. The expectation has been quite general that the export trade would become more active in the future.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (UP) --Five children were suffocated in bed early today when fire swept their third-floor apartment.

The semiannual report of Eversharp, Inc., to be released today by Fred J. Young, president, shows a net income of $1,170,362 for the six months ended Aug. 31. In the similar period last year the company cleared $986,483.
MOST men are pretty scornful of the bulk and multi farious contents of women's pocketbooks. Hillel Tennenbaum has made a good living and lots of friends by taking the opposite view.

The young American pianist Dorothy Garver made her New York debut at Town Hall Saturday night. Miss Garver has an appealing stage presence, dignity and poise. If she felt any debut nervousness she did not show it.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 23 (UP) --Rock 'n' roll riots raged here last night and early this morning for the third consecutive day. The police arrested thirty-three teenagers to break up the disturbances outside a theatre showing the American film "Rock Around the Clock."

TWO genuine novelties were disclosed by the Royal Danish Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday, evening. One was their distinctive version of the long familiar "Coppelia," and the other was the first presentation here of any version of "The Whims of Cupid," which is, according to all available evidence, the oldest ballet anywhere extant.
Joseph Klettlinger bought the rooming house at 2410 Grand Avenue in the Bronx through Feinberg Bros., brokers, who ...

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 23 --Albert A. Young Jr., with Wisp, took the lead for the de Coppet Trophy by winning the second test in the six-race International Class series off Larchmont Yacht Club today. He way second yesterday.

Lester Smith, chairman of the board of Dairy Corporation of America, has been elected president of the Ice Cream Manufacturers of New York State. Mr. Smith succeeds Hoover C. Sutton, vice president of Sealtest Ice Cream Corporation, Buffalo division.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months ...

The five-story building containing stores and offices on a lot 19 by 100 feet at 10 East Fifty-fourth Street has been sold by the Marquise de Cuevas, the former Margaret Rockefeller, to Arthur Maxwell Co. for investment. O'Gara Co. was the broker in the sale of the building, which is now vacant.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Sept. 23 (UP)--Ken Venturi defeated Dr. Bud Taylor, 2 and 1, today to win the California State amateur golf championship.
A White House conference to develop means of reducing racial tension is being "constantly examined," a Presidential aide said yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept 23 (AP) --Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today that Adlai E, Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential nominee, was a "great wit," but that Indiana voters were "delighted and happy" with President Eisenhower.

Former Justice Mitchell May of the Supreme Court was honored at a testimonial dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mr. May, a native of Brooklyn, celebrated his eightysixth birthday last July 20.
The Children's Aid Society has named Edwin K. Merrill an associate director. He had been treasurer since 1950.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- The Administration is understood to have a job in mind for Gov. Christian A. Herter of Massachusetts if President Eisenhower is re-elected.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 23--St. Benedict's High School of Newark avenged last year's opening game loss by defeating St. Mary's of Rutherford, 35--6 today. Pete Brogan scored two touchdowns and passed for a third.
The Dessoff Choirs will begin rehearsals tonight at 7 o'clock at the Turtle Bay Music School. Auditions before the rehearsal may be arranged by calling the choirs' office, LEhigh 5-8290.
Reflecting surfaces of stoves must be clean to provide efficient heat.
Four dwellings on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 36 and 38 Cranberry Street and 68-70 Hicks Street, in the "Heights" section of Brooklyn, were sold by the ...
The appointment of George H. "Snuffy" Stirnweiss, former New York Yankee second baseman, as a new business representative of the Federation Bank and Trust Company ...
EVERY age has a hallmark drawn from the world of fashion. Charactertistic of the fabrics of the last ten years is a thin thread of gold.

VIENNA, Sept. 23 (AP)--The Buchan Bakers of Seattle chalked up another victory in their European basketball tour today. They won, 57--44, from the Polish national team before a crowd of 20,000 in Warsaw, the Polish Radio reported.

The record of Attorney General Jacob K. Javits was praised by a New York clergyman yesterday in an appeal for truthful statements in an election year. Mr. Javits is the Republican candidate for the Senate.
Five acres of land in the Bronxville-Fleetwood section of Yonkers, near the Cross County Shopping Center, have been purchased by Martin W. Juster, a builder, for improvement with ...
The Rev. Daniel A. Poling celebrated yesterday the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination by preaching before his son's congregation.
Purchase of life insurance in August amounted to $4,544,000,000, according to the Life Insurance Agency Management Association.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP)--Cold, sharp winds brought Moscow its first snowfall of the season today. There were several fiveminute flurries as the temperature hovered just above freezing.
Charles J. Kushell Jr. of New York City will become financial vice president of Montgomery Ward Co. on Dec. 1, John A. Barr, president, announced yesterday.

The steamship charter market assumed a firmer tone last week with rates rising slightly in almost all segments of the field. Activity in the market, although slightly below the previous week, was generally considered to be sounder since some long-term business was involved.

The 1957 New York March of Dimes campaign of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will be led by Harris Ashton Dunn, vice chairman of the board of The Bowery Savings Bank. The city goal is $3,000,000.

Mrs. Nora Mayer was married yesterday in the home of her parents to Marc Brown by Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein. She is the daughter of Arthur L. Mayer, former foreignfilm producer, theatre owner and publicist, and Mrs. Mayer of ...

The Brooklyn State Hospital Psychiatric Forum will meet for the first time this season Oct. 4 at 8:30 P.M. at 681 Clarkson Avenue. Dr. L. Vosburgh Lyons, chief of neurological services of the city's hospitals, will speak on "Some Common Misconceptions About Psychiatry." Admission is free.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (UP)-- Frank Lary fired a two-hitter today to turn back the Cleveland Indians, 11--1. He thus became the first twenty-game winner for the Detroit Tigers since Hal Newhouser turned the trick in 1948.

City and state governments expect to offer $69,425,131 of bonds but no short-term notes this week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with revised totals of $114,795,455 of bonds and $1,600,000 of notes offered last week.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 23 (Reuters)--An honorary Doctor of Laws degree was conferred today on President Sukarno of Indonesia by Charles University. The award was made in the presence of Czechoslovak Government officials including Premier Viliam Siroky.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Sept. 23--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Carlson, formerly of Chicago, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Donna Rae Carlson, to John Ely Pflieger. He is the son of Mrs. Pierrepont Isham Prentice of 760 Park Avenue, New York, and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and John J. Pflieger of Port Washington, L.I.

LONDON, Sept. 23--The Financial Times index of thirty industrial ordinary shares, based on July, 1935, as 100, at the end of last week was 180.6, compared with 181.2 the week before, 184.1 a month earlier and 194.5 a year ago.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23--Trade volume in commodity futures on the Board of Trade increased last week, but were smaller than for the same period a year ago.

Until the ninth inning, the Giants had made only one hitDon Mueller's single in the third --against Philadelphia's Curt Simmons yesterday at the Polo Grounds. When the home side finally got an attack rolling, it was much too late to disturb the outcome and the Phillies won, 6--2.
EPHRATA, Wash., Sept. 23 --Senator Estes Kefauver said today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon was promising prosperity as former President Herbert Hoover did just before the depression.
More people in the United States are drinking more coffee a day than ever before, according to a survey conducted by the Pan American Coffee Bureau.

New York State laws barring racial discrimination in Government-aided housing have proved "workable, effective instruments" in helping minorities obtain decent housing, it was reported yesterday by Charles Abrams, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination.
Berlin ... Korea ... Iran ... Indochina ... Suez. For ten years the world has moved from one international crisis to another.
Despite indications of good business in coming months, the men's clothing industry is evidently planning production on a conservative basis, the Clothing ...
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23-- A wreath-laying ceremony at the grave of Benjamin Franklin today preceded the formal opening tomorrow of the International Printing Pressmen's thirty-sixth convention.

LONDON, Sept. 23--A combination of unfavorable economic developments at home and continued uncertainty about the ultimate outcome of the Suez dispute kept stock market trading at a low level last week.

HONG KONG, Sept. 23--Communist Chinese shore batteries on Amoy Island opened fire without warning on the West German freighter Monika yesterday. One crew member was killed and three others were injured.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)--Five drivers won 1956 titles today in the twenty-second annual national outboard championships.
TRENTON, Sept. 23--More than 60,000 persons attended the opening day of the annual New Jersey State Fair today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Sept. 23--A Jordanian soldier went berserk today, firing a Bren gun at a group of Israelis, United Nations observers were informed by Jordan. Three Israelis were killed and fifteen were wounded.

CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., Sept. 23--Good News, a 45-foot white yawl, and Game Cock, a 30-foot gray sloop, both finished second in their respective races today. However, the No. 2 finishes enabled Good News and Game Cock to capture trophies on Long Island Sound.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Sept. 23-- Premier Habib Bourguiba smothered an incipient revolt last week in the ranks of Tunisia's labor movement.

Joseph A. Talalay of New Haven, Conn., consulting engineer and inventor, has assigned his patent rights in foam rubber in Israel to Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel. Announcement of the move was made here yesterday by Jacob Mark, a director of the American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute. He accepted the assignment papers at his home, 1000 Fifth Avenue.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Sept. 23 (AP)--Pope Pius XII received Dr. William V.S. Tubman, President of Liberia, in audience today.

The Dexter Chemical Corporation, New York, has formed a paper chemicals division, Joseph B. Evans, vice president, in charge of sales, announced over the week-end. Mr. Evans said that John F. Kneeland has been named Northeastern sales manager of the division.

A daughter, their second, was born last Tuesday to Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel H. Hartshorne of Brooklyn in the Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. Mrs. Hartshorne is the former Miss Valerie Howard Thomas.
The following report, published recently, may be of interest to members of school parents' associations:

CARE has opened a Food Crusade through which it is hoped to feed about 20,000,000 hungry persons in nineteen countries. It is expected that 5,000,000 food packages will be distributed during the coming year, and an appeal is being made for contributions to cover some of the additional shipping costs.

DETROIT, Sept. 23--Walter P. Reuther challenged top leaders of the Republican party today to support a legislative program for the four-day week foreseen yesterday in a speech by Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

The quadrangle at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street, was dedicated yesterday afternoon to the memory of Louis Marshall. Mr. Marshall, a constitutional lawyer, was chairman of the seminary's board of directors from 1904 until his death in 1929.
Traffic will be barred from Rockefeller Plaza from 10:30 tonight to 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, so that one of its three blocks can be "paved" with pink soap.

Luana Knighten, who was to have had a principal role in the off-Broadway revival of "Take a Giant Step," died yesterday morning of a heart attack in her apartment at 108-16 155th Street, Jamaica, Queens. She was 30 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 23--Two provisions in the Constantinople Convention of 1888 are expected to become pivotal points in the Security Council's discussion of the Suez Canal situation. The treaty guarantees in perpetuity free access to the waterway by the ships of all nations in peace and war.
"LA TRAVIATA" had its first performance of the season Saturday evening by the New York City Opera Company under the direction of Joseph Rosenstock.

Two hundred and sixty parishioners lined West 65th Street yesterday as the cornerstone was laid for a new parish house and chapel at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity. The church is at Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

OPAZATIKA, Northern Ont., Canada, Sept. 23--In the Ojibway tongue Opazatika means lake of the Poplar Islands, a great, slate-colored body of water beneath the flat septentrional sky. Here hideous, huge pike lie like timber in the weedbeds peering malevolently at the upper world through evil, mesozoic eyes.
ALBANY, Sept. 23 (AP)--Governor Harriman announced today details of a new study into human factors in traffic accidents. He said it "holds promise of dramatic long-range advances" in prevention.

The 1956 New York High Fidelity Show, which opens Thursday afternoon at the New York Trade Show Building, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, will bid primarily for the patronage of the average music lover.
After years of research, a new Deutz air-cooled exhaust turbocharged Diesel engine has been completed by Kloeckner-Humboldt-Deutz, AG., Cologne, Germany.
Rabbi David de Sola Pool, after fifty years as minister of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, turned over its spiritual leadership yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Louis C. Gerstein.

UNION CITY, N.J. Sept. 23 --Demarest High of Hoboken defeated the Dickinson eleven of Jersey City, 14--7, today.

SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 21-- The Legislative Assembly, El Salvador's unicameral congress, revoked today a 1952 law under which the Government had taken action on different occasions to expel its political enemies.

The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, today will begin a special campaign for $65,000. The drive will continue through Oct. 26. Volunteers wearing yellow and black armbands will collect funds at many places in the city. The money will be used by the Lighthouse for its twenty-nine services among more than 5,000 blind in this area.

DENVER, Sept. 23--Following as the text of the first of Adlai E. Stevenson's policy documents spelling out his new America program. It is accompanied by a letter from Mr. Stevenson transmitting his declaration to Democratic leaders, officials and can- didates for office:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) --Two generals served notice today that the Army intended to build up its air arm to help ground troops carry out wartime missions in the atomic age.

A luncheon showing of fall and winter fashions by Pauline Trigere will be shown at the ballroom of the Ambassador Hotel at 12:30 tomorrow, not Wednesday, as was previously announced here, Reservations should be made in advance.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23--Irregular moves marked trading in grain and soybean futures last week.

Sol Goldenthal has been elected treasurer of the B.V.D. Company. Mr. Goldenthal is also executive vice president, a director and director of sales of the company, Ralph Feriola, vice president and treasurer of the National Bank of Westchester, was elected a director.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) --Federal courts are beginning to reduce the backlog of cases, it was reported today.

A cancer research laboratory established at Albert Einstein College of Medicine by the Jewish fraternal order, B'rith Sholom, was dedicated yesterday. The ceremony was held at the college, Morris Park Avenue and Eastchester Road, the Bronx.
A booklet explaining the technique and advantage of hedging operations in Maine potato futures has been issued by the New York Mercantile Exchange. If futures trading is properly ...
Applications will be received until Oct. 19 for the seventh annual "Musical Talent in Our Schools" recitals sponsored by The New York Times and its radio station, WQXR.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23 --Princeton University opened its 211th academic year today on the steps of Nassau Hall.

Robert L. Moore Jr. and William Morton have been named second vice presidents of the Sheraton Corporation of America. Mr. Moore, who joined the hotel chain in 1953 as director of advertising and public ...
Sherman M. Fairchild resigned yesterday as a director of Pan American World Airways with a plea for a Congressional review of the Civil Aeronautics Board regulations that forced him to step down.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 23--Miss Diana Barbara Loprete, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Loprete of Llewellyn Park, has become engaged to Herbert Milton Rinaldi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Rinaldi of North Bergen. They will be married in February.

The president of the independent International Longshoremen's Association charged yesterday he had been "doublecrossed" by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
Stanley M. Isaacs resigned from Americans for Democratic Action yesterday immediately after the A.D.A. state convention had endorsed Mayor Wagner for United States Senator.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Sept. 23--Vice President Richard M. Nixon will recommend that the White House act to make sure that hog prices remain stable in the Farm Belt from now until the Presidential election.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 --Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru used the power of his personal prestige tonight to try to halt a wave of Hindu-Moslem antagonism that has come up in India in the last few weeks.

President Meany of the merged labor movement was not merely paying lip service to a code of ethics when he rejected last Friday a bid by the International Longshoremen's Association to re-enter the house of labor.

LANGHORNE, Pa., Sept. 23 (AP)--Paul Goldsmith of St. Claire Shores, Mich., won the 300-mile grand national championship late-model stock car race today at Langhorne Speedway. He was timed in 4 hours 6 minutes 33.97 seconds.

DENVER, Sept. 23 (UP)-- Democratic leaders discussed the possibility today of sending Senator Estes Kefauver on a "whistle-stop" type of campaign by light plane through Western states. The Vice-Presidential candidate would be able to stop at airports unable to handle large commercial aircraft.
The Samuel Strausberg Pavilion of Beth-El Hospital, Linden Boulevard and Rockaway Parkway, Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday.

Wade Fetzer Sr., chairman of W.A. Alexander Co. of Chicago, general insurance agents, and a former president of the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York, died Saturday at Hinsdale, Ill. His age was 77.

NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Sept. 23 (UP)--Skeeter Johnson of Cambridge, Md., captured the, 136-cubic-inch national hydroplane championship today. He won both heats on the Ohio River. In the 266-cubic-inch race, Henry Lauterback of Portsmouth, Va., had a first place and a second to take the national crown.
Thousands at an Interfaith Day rally on the Mall in Central Park joined yesterday in proposing that President Eisenhower get religious leaders to confer on desegregation.

If it were merely an ordinary political group, the Communist party in this country would merit little attention. Its membership of less than 25,000 and its several tens or hundreds of thousands of sympathizers are an infinitesimal portion of the American people and exert little influence on our normal electoral processes.
Bus drivers of the Third Avenue Transit System will meet tonight at the Transport Workers Union headquarters, 210 West Fiftieth Street, to consider a brief work stoppage tomorrow.

ZURICH, Sept. 23--Strong disapproval was registered by the Swiss commercial banks at the action of the Confederation in consenting to lend 200,000,000 Swiss francs to the World Bank out of sterilized budget surpluses. The rate of interest, 3 3/8 per cent, is below that on World Bank loans issued in Switzerland through the Swiss commercial banks.

Mr. and Mrs. James Alexander Linen 3d of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Ellen Scranton Linen, to Nathan Mobley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mobley, also of Greenwich.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 23 (AP)--Fred Hawkins, El Paso, Tex., won his first major golf championship after ten years of effort by capturing the $l5,000 Oklahoma City open tournament with a 9-under-par 279 today.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 23--Two hundred Nicaraguan Opposition figures have been rounded up for questioning as a result of the shooting of President Anastasio Somoza, his sons revealed this afternoon.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 23--With one of their most sprightly allaround performances of the last month, the Milwaukee Braves downed the Chicago Cubs, 7--4, today to keep their National League pennant hopes vibrantly alive.

It was a dual personality day for Mayor Wagner yesterday. In the morning he was the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, visiting party headquarters in Suffolk County communities with Adrian Mason, Democratic chairman of the county, at his side.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) --George Meany called on all political candidates and their supporters today to subscribe to "the code of fair campaign practices."
The ninth anniversary of the death of former Mayer Fiorello H. La Guardia was marked yesterday at his grave in Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx.

A date has now been set, six months hence, for the proclamation of the independence of the Gold Coast. It will be a new self-governing nation within the British Commonwealth framework. It will have a new name, Ghana, and it will embark upon a new political life.

MADRID, Sept. 23 (AP)--Secretary of Air Donald A. Quarles opened today the first United States emergency air base in Spain by landing at Torrejon Airdome, fifteen miles northeast of Madrid. Mr. Quarles flew from Madrid in a United States plane with Ambassador John Davis Lodge and Lieut. Gen. Eduardo Gonzalez Gallarz, Spain's Air Minister.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23-- Secretary of State Dulles warned tonight that "the danger of war would recur" in the Suez Canal dispute if Egypt continued to reject a solution "in accordance with the principles of justice and international law."

CHICAGO, Sept. 23--The appointment of Mrs. Ivy Baker Priest as national chairman of the Easter Seal campaign for 1957 was announced here today by the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults, Inc. Mrs. Priest is Treasurer of the United States.

Miss Marya Aphrodite Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Gabriel Alexander of New York, was married here yesterday to Nicholas John Spiliotis, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholas Spiliotis of Queens Village, Queens. The ceremony was performed in St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church by the Rev. John Psillas.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 23 (AP)-- Cincinnati's Redlegs overpowered the St. Louis Cardinals with home runs today, taking both ends of a double-header. Ed Bailey's pinch homer in the tenth gave the openin game to the Redlegs, 3--2. Two homers accounted for four runs in the 5-4 second game.
National Automotive Fibres, Inc., has elected Paul V. Shields as board chairman, John G. Bannister, president and chief executive officer, announced over the week-end.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesa, Sept. 23 (Reuters)--A state of emergency was declared tonight in Southern Rhodesia by the Governor, Sir Peveril William-Powlett. He acted because of a strike of African rail workers scheduled to start at midnight.
A new company, Power Sources, Inc., has been formed by Microwave Associates, Boston and Technical Operations, Inc., Arlington, Mass., it was announced yesterday.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Sept. 23--The New York Times and Herbert L. Matthews, a member of its staff, have been sharply attacked in Arriba, the Falange organ. The attack is being reproduced in all provincial party organs.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits declared yesterday that no inconsistencies were involved in his support of Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

City Stores Company, represented in this area by Franklin Simon and Oppenheim Collins, has appointed William E. Heaton as general merchandise manager, it was announced over they week-end by Ben R. Gordon, ...

The New York School of Social work, Columbia University, has selected the first five winners of the new fellowships established by the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind. The recipients were Josephena Catena of Newark; Grace P. Davidson of Lynn, Mass.; Catherine Frankl of Brooklyn; Richard Stander of Bayside, Queens, and Barbara Stecker of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) --President and Mrs. Eisenhower attended services at the National Presbyterian Church today and heard the Rev. Dr. Edward L.R. Elson pronounce religion as one of the main bulwarks against communism.
SUEZ, Egypt, Sept. 23-- Suez Canal pilots are working themselves to the limit to maintain schedules with the reduced staff left after the walkout of foreign pilots Sept. 15.

Mine Safety Appliances Company, Pittsburgh, has formed a wholly owned subsidiary, MSA Research Corporation, to consolidate and expand its basic research in chemistry, physics and nuclear energy. John T. Ryan, president of the parent company, is president of the new subsidiary. Principal laboratories will be at Callery, thirty miles north of Pittsburgh.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 23-- Chancellor Konrad Adenaur will motor to Brussels tomorrow for a two-day official visit in Belgium. The occasion will be marked by signature of a state treaty modifying the two countries' common frontier in favor of West Germany.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 23--Kathy Whiteside of Hartsdale was named equitation champion of the Harrison junior horse show at the Kentucky Riding Stables today. It was the sixteenth horsemanship tri-color ...

DUBLIN, Sept. 23 (AP)--Wexford retained the all-Ireland senior hurling championship today, defeating Cork, 2 goals and 14 points (20 points) to 2 goals and 8 points (14 points), before a crowd of 80,000. Tipperary took the all-Ireland minor championship, winning from Kilkenny by 4 goals and 16 points (28) to 1 goal and 5 points (8).
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 23-- The citations for the honorary degrees conferred today by Princeton University follows:
AMSTERDAM, Sept. 23--The Dutch Government appears fully alive to the adverse influences of falling exchange reserves, a deteriorating payments balance and inflationary trends.
The Brooklyn Dodgers gained an 8-3 lead over the Pirates yesterday, but the game in Pittsburgh was called in the ninth inning to comply with Pennsylvania's Sunday curfew ...
The New York Tuberculosis and Health Association reported 6,214 new cases of tuberculosis in New York City in 1955, bringing the total of known cases to 24,132.
The port of Brownsville, Tex., is celebrating its twentieth anniversary this year by becoming the No. 1 cotton port of the nation.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 23--Mrs. William O. Riordan has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Beatrice Elaine Riordan, to Calvin Philip Craig. He is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Calvin F. Craig of Bronxville.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP)--Tom Gorman and the Kansas City Athletics spoiled Billy Pierce's bid for his twenty-first victory of the season today. The Athletics won, 3--2, but the Chicago White Sox came back behind Gerry Staley to take the second game of a double-header, 5--1.
LONDON, Sept. 23--The Foreign Office said today it expected the Suez Canal question would be dealt with swiftly by the United Nations Security Council.

Policemen and firemen searched the Paramount Theatre, Broadway and Forty-third Street, after an anonymous person called the theatre at 8:15 o'clock last night and said a bomb would "go off in the balcony in five minutes." Most of the 2,800 patrons were unaware that a search was being made. Nothing suspicious was found.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 23--A huge balloon carrying four passengers in its wicker basket rose from Roosevelt Field here today at 11:04 A.M.

BUFFALO, Sept. 23 (UP)-- Sam Baker booted four field goals today to pace the Washington Redskins to a 19-17 victory over the Detroit Lions in a National Football League exhibition game before 23,812 fans at Civic Stadium.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 23 (UP)--Quarterback Bobby Thomason's accurate passing led the Philadelphia Eagles to a 21-14 victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners today to wind up the pro football exhibition season.

Staten Island Community College, a coeducational, two-year institution, will open to more than 100 students today at 50 Bay Street, St. George. The college is administered by the city's Board of Higher Education under the supervision of State University trustees.
BOSTON, Sept. 23--The cornerstone of a Marian shrine designed to be the biggest of its kind in the United States was dedicated today by Archbishop Richard J. Cushing.

STANLEY MYER ISAACS is a man of many contra dictions, but no one seriously has questioned his dedication to principle as he sees it. He firmly believes in good government, social progress and humanitarian works.

The first and most obvious remark to make about the attempt on the life of President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua is that assassination is no way to settle political differences. He will have the wishes of all United States citizens for his recovery.
ELK POINT, S.D., Sept. 23 (UP)--This small Missouri River town that residents fear may be sinking into the earth held religious services today despite widening cracks in the church building.
That rapidly vanishing segment of the American labor force--the domestic servant-- has dropped from ninety-four to thirty-four for each 1,000 persons in the last fifty years.

PROVIDENCE, Sept, 23 (U.P.) --The New York Rangers scored their third straight exhibition hockey victory tonight by defeating the Boston Bruin 'B' team, 4--1. Dave Creighton, Ron Murphy, Guy Gendron and Andy Bathgate scored for the winners. Fleming Mackell tallied for Boston.

DENVER, Sept. 23--Adlai E. Stevenson proposed tonight that the United States assume the responsibility of maintaining its older citizens on the standard of living to which they had been accustomed before retirement.
Under legislation just enacted by the Virginia Legislature--or General Assembly--communities that try to conform to the Supreme Court's desegregation decision of May 17, 1954, will be in hot water.

Britain and France have now moved decisively to put the Suez case before the United Nations Security Council. They have asked for a meeting day after tomorrow. CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP)--A strike scheduled for tomorrow against the Chicago, North Shore, and Milwaukee Railway was postponed today to give the National [Railway] Mediation Board a chance to try for settlement.

Domestic cotton futures got off to a slow start last week, then turned firmer to end the week with gains. At the close of trading on Friday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 11 to 32 points from the previous week's close.
Lehigh Valley Railroad reported August operating revenues of $6,151,888 and net income, before sinking funds, of $479,724.

Coats went back into the closet yesterday as the first day of autumn brought summer weather to this area again.

PARIS, Sept. 23--"Requiem for a Nun," by William Faulkner, has opened the autumn theatre season here. The general opinion is that a great American tragedy has been ably translated and adapted by Albert Camus, journalist, playwright, essayist and author.

The engagement of Miss Sheila Gayle Rand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rand of Deal, N.J., to Gerald L. Kravitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kravitz of Wanamassa, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. The couple will be married in February.

Spotting the visitors two goals in the first eleven minutes, the American Soccer League AllStars rallied to top the Maccabi Soccer Club of Tel Aviv, 3 to 2, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
NEWARK, Sept. 23--Arthur Joseph of 5 Navesink Avenue, Highlands, N.J., an author and a retired hotel man, died today in Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. His age was 70.

The construction of a $15,200,000 building for a new United States courthouse and Federal offices in Brooklyn's multi-million-dollar Civic Center has been approved. Repre sentative Francis E. Thom McAn will open its 120th shoe store in the Metropolitan New York area on Thursday in the Lake Success Shopping Center, New Hyde Park, L.I. Thom McAn is a division of Melville Shoe Corporation. CAIRO, Sept. 23 (Reuters)-- Egypt and Libya signed a oneyear trade and payments agreement here today. It provides also for a Libyan-Egyptian Navigation Company, financed by joint capital.

Expenditures of all Latin-American governments total $10,000,000,000 a year, the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York reported in its Latin-American Business Highlights, released for publication over the week-end.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced over the week-end the appointment of Thomas E. Monaghan as general counsel, effective Nov. 1. MORRO BAY, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP)--Three large waves struck a forty-foot fishing boat late yesterday, spilling two boys and a woman into the Pacific. The father of one boy leaped into the ocean in a rescue attempt. All four are believed to have drowned. The boat had fourteen aboard.

JACK KELLY is a big, handsome man who had a hand in the most spectacular give away of 1956. He gave away the bride, his daughter Grace, when she marrigd Prince Rainier of Monaco.
