WASHINGTON, Sept. 25-- Representative John W. McCormack was asked today to request an end of the special subcommittee hearings on racial integration in the schools or the national capital Mr. McCormack, a Massachusetts Democrat, is majority leader of the House.

With a rally in the stretch, Frank Rand Jr.'s Begorra took the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. The outcome was not pleasing to many in the crowd of 17,948 because the favorite was just about left at the post.

PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 25 (AP)-- President Eisenhower, in his farm speech tonight, did not explain what he personally meant by "full" income parity but the phrase has been used extensively by farm leaders.
Five matinee performances by the New York City Opera Company will be broadcast over Station WNYC this season, begin ning with "La Traviata" on Saturday afternoon.

An executive of a textiles concern said yesterday that the United States was "a sitting duck" for Japanese textile shipments. The Japanese have found it so easy to sell large quantities of textiles here that they have not worked to develop markets in other areas, according to Donald B. Tansill, president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc.

The engagement of Miss Susan Goldman to Stanley J. Scher has been announced by her mother, Mrs. William M. Goldman of 350 Central Park West. Mr. Scher is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Scher of Brooklyn.
THE newly appointed president of New York Univer sity, Dr. Carroll Vincent Newsom, donned his first pair of long pants to handle his first teaching job. He was 14 years old at the time.
The thirty-first annual World's Championship Rodeo opened last night at Madison Square Garden. It will continue through the night of Oct. 14.
BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 26-- President Somoza continues to show some improvement, today's Gorgas Hospital bulletin said.
ISMAILIA, Egypt, Sept. 26-- Five American sea captains reported to the Suez Canal Authority's headquarters here today for jobs as pilots on the waterway.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26--Willis Gale, chairman of the Commonwealth Edison Company, proposed today that the Government offer cash payments to help utility companies build demonstration atomic power plants.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 26-- Earl Warren, Chief Justice of the United States, warned today that the preservation of freedom and justice in this country called for ceaseless vigilance by all citizens.
A son, their seventh, was born to Mr. and Mrs. James E. Murray of Panorama Farms, Earlyville, Va., on Sept. 16 in the University of Virginia Hospital at Charlottesville.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26--A strong market developed today on the Board of Trade for corn futures. There was considerable commission absorption, which started short covering. Soybeans and oats had a firm undertone, reflecting in part the strength in corn. Wheat was heavy early in the session, especially the December and March deliveries.

A.L. Nickerson, president of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., has been appointed chairman of the planning council of the International Management Association. He will head an advisory group of executives for the organization, which is an affiliate of the American Management Association.

Contract negotiations between the shipbuilding division of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America were resumed yesterday under the auspices of Federal mediators.

Directors of the Western Electric Company yesterday elected Arthur B. Goetze to succeed Frederick R. Kappel as president of the company, which is the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Mr. Kappel was elected president of A.T. T. last week.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (U.P.)--Tony DeSpirito rode a winner today on his third comeback try from a near-crippling spill.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 26--Mr. and Mrs. Robert DeBevoise Warren have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Rutter Warren, to Timothy Covert Tredwell.
The Dodgers' National League pennant hopes suffered a severe blow when Brooklyn lost to the Philadelphia Phils, 7--3, at Ebbets Field yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (UP) --The Westinghouse Electric Corporation today announced plans for a nuclear reactor, the first to be built by a single industrial company for its own research, it said.
The discovery of a new oil field in eastern Venezuela was announced yesterday by a Sinclair Oil Corporation subsidiary, the Venezuelan Petroleum Combany.
Ralph Harris Jr. has been named director of education for International Business Machines Corporation. Robert E. Pattison has been appointed director of engineering training.

The store at 30 West Fiftyseventh Street has been leased by Hyman Marks, who will use the space for a restaurant after alterations. The quarters, formerly occupied by H. Hicks Son, were leased from the 30 West Fifty-seventh Street Corporation through the L.J. Phillips-Wood, Dolson Company, broker.
OCEANSIDE, Calif., Sept. 26 (AP)--The premature explosion of a mortar shell killed two First Division Marines and critically injured a third in training yesterday at near-by Camp Pendleton.
Foxhead, a 100-acre estate in the Town of Cortlandt, Westchester County, was sold by Mrs. Rosalie L. Fox through George Howe, Inc., broker. It includes a swimming pool and a fifteen-acre lake.

Republicans of the Seventh Assembly District North, taking in the Morningside Heights area, have elected John J. Quinn leader to succeed the late Helen M. Noonan. Mr. Quinn is an Assistant State Attorney General.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--A permanent wave may take the place of the traditional dunking for Boston University's crew coxswain if a determined freshman from Forest Hills, Queens, has her way.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 26 (AP)-- Jimmy Brown, a back, and Rudy Farmer, a guard, were named co-captains of the Syracuse football team today for the game against the Pittsburgh Panthers at Pittsburgh on Saturday.

Personnel of Fort Tilden, Rockaway, Queens, will give blood to the Red Cross today. Collections also will be made at the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street, and the New York Telephone Company offices at 89-63 163d Street, Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--A House of Representatives subcommittee was told today that integration in the capital's schools had been pushed too fast.
The city has found developers who are willing to include 420 middle-income cooperative apartments with the higher rental housing of the Lincoln Square project.

Title to nine buildings in the business section of Binghamton, N.Y., has been taken by a syndicate headed by I. Jerome Riker of New York. The properties were held at $1,500,000 and were bought for cash from the O'Neil estate through George F. O'Neil, who lives in Paris, France.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 26 --The Community Chest Drive will begin here tomorrow.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 --A new common room, named in memory of the Rev. Samuel J. Braun, was dedicated today at the annual convocation of the Harvard Divinity School.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26-- For the first time in several years the Sailors Union of the Pacific today picketed a ship at Antioch, northeast of here, in protest against the use of foreign crew members in a CanadaUnited States shipping operation.
UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 26--Announcement of the establishment of The Shoemaker Memorial Foundation to aid pupils of the First Supervisory District of Oneida County and a bequest of...
HENDERSON, Ky., Sept. 26 --The boycott of the Weaverton Grade School lost some ground today.
The Hercules Powder Company is diversifying its operations through the proposed acquisition of the Huron Milling Company of Harbor Beach, Mich.
Harvey Matusow, an erstwhile Communist informer, was quickly convicted on all five counts of a perjury indictment yesterday afternoon in Federal Court.

Five four-story buildings on a plot 93 by 56 feet at 488 to 496 Third Avenue, northwest corner of East Thirty-third Street, have been sold by Herman Scheckner to David Green for investment. L.V. Hoffman Real Estate, Inc., the broker, arranged the deal for cash over mortgages amounting to $220,000. Title was insured by the Home Title Insurance Company.
The City College Fund announced yesterday the reappointment of Harold Lifton as its campaign chairman for the third consecutive year.
HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 26--Two men were killed late today while assisting in the rescue of a third man who had been overcome by fumes in a sewer manhole near here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26--The nation's traffic experts started worrying today over whether they had more money in sight for road building than they were geared to spend efficiently. The embarrassment of riches was a major topic at sessions today of the Institute of Traffic Engineers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26--The Security Council decided today to debate both the British-French complaint against Egypt's nationalization of the Suez Canal Company and the Egyptian counter-complaint.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26--Not because they are largely an undemonstrative lot did the Braves fail to whoop it up today on learning that the Dodgers had lost to the Phillies.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 26-- It has been a good many Years Since Navy lost so accomplished a pair of football players as checked out last June when George Welsh and Ron Beagle received their ensign bars.
Summer sales of Best Foods, Inc., did not meet expectations, Leonard G. Blumenschine, chairman and president, told stockholders at their annual meetings yesterday. He blamed adverse weather.
Irving Sherman, a confidant of former Mayor William O'Dwyer, pleaded innocent yesterday to Government charges that as an alien he had entered the country illegally from Canada in 1941.

The National Music Council announced yesterday the award of its annual Conductor Citation to Howard Mitchell, director of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, for "distinguished services to American music" during the 1955-56 season.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Sept. 26 (AP) --The superintendent of Waukegan Township High School said today he would interview parents of thirteen students suspended because of racial difficulties at the school during the last week.
Leopold Stokowski will conduct the first performances of three works at the Carnegie Hall concert on Sunday, Oct. 14, which opens the fall season of the Symphony of the Air.
The Jolie Gabor jewelry store at 699 Madison Avenue, between Sixty-second and Sixty--third Streets, was robbed of an undisclosed amount of bracelets, gold pins and pearls last night.
Two new features will arrive at first-run theatres today.

One of the nation's most enterprising unions set in motion yesterday a far-reaching program to stimulate smallhome construction and increase the funds available for service to the union's 440,000 members.
A collection of H.L. Mencken's writing on American politics "in the Republican Twenties and the Roosevelt Thirties" will be published Oct. 10 by Johns Hopkins Press.
The Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund will celebrate its Silver Anniversary with a combination musicale and dinner at the Sheraton-Astor on Oct. 30.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation released yesterday its proxy material for a special meeting of shareholders Oct. 31 in Detroit. The recent agreement with the Curtiss-Wright Corporation will be voted upon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --President Eisenhower promoted Maj. Gen. Herbert M. Jones today from deputy adjutant general of the Army to adjutant general.
CORNWALL, Conn., Sept. 26 --Miss Nancy Lois Hart and John Hodge Markgraf will be married in the spring.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 26 (AP)--Nimble Colby today scored a straight-heat victory in the $14,078 Hanover Filly Stake for 3-year-old trotters. The event was the highlight of the Lexington Trots' ten-day meeting opener.

Cornerstone-laying ceremonies for a fifteen-story Hall of Residence at the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center were held yesterday afternoon in the Medical Science Building at 550 First Avenue.
The appointment of Lawrence G. Haggerty as president of the Farnsworth Electronics Company division of the International Telephone and Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has been announced by...
The text of a televised address made yesterday by Attorney General Jacob K. Javits, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, as recorded by The New York Times, follows:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 26 --Mrs. Philip Cudone, the defending champion representing the home club, today led the way into the semi-finals of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's thirty-first annual match-play championship at the Montclair Golf Club.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 26 (AP)-- An investigator in the Ruotolo kidnap-murder case said today the police had obtained a list of the names of about 1,100 persons who could have helpful information, and that all of them will be questioned.

Metal Hydrides, Inc., is offering common stockholders the right to subscribe for 85,268 additional shares of common stock at $17.50 a share, on the basis of one share for each three shares held of record Sept. 26. Subscription rights will expire Oct 10.

THE first of four consecutive performances of Frederic Ashton's ballet, "Romeo and Juliet," on the score by Serge Prokofieff, was presented last night by the Royal Danish Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House.

P.C. Spencer, president of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, has been elected a director of the Texas Pacific Coal and Oil Company of Fort Worth. Sinclair recently acquired about a 30 per cent interest in Texas Pacific, a producer of oil and gas.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (U.P.) --Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, the freakish flailer from Far Rockaway, Queens, again outpointed Bob Baker of Pittsburgh tonight in their return twelveround bout before 12,641 fans at Forbes Field for a split decision.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 (UP)-- Governor Harriman today proclaimed the first week of October as Parent-Teacher Membership Week.
The election of Clayton Huff, assistant treasurer of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., as president of the Advertising Agency Financial Management Group...
Dr. Carroll Vincent Newsom has been named president of New York University, effective Oct. 1. His appointment was announced yesterday by George E. Roosevelt, chairman of the board of trustees.
Sir Ifor Evans, provost of University College at the University of London, last night received a medal from New York University at a reception given in his honor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Inflation and how to fight it occupied delegates to the eleventh annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund today.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 26-- Bolivia's "revolutionary" Congress today began the slow process of adopting a new "workers" constitution for the nation.
Mrs. Charles Ulrick Bay will give a reception today at her home, 720 Park Avenue, for Eugene Ormandy to mark his twentieth year as conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

A daily ragweed pollen count compiled by the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital for the information of hay fever sufferers and physicians is shown in the table below. Because of the laboratory procedures involved, the most recent figure available is for the...

The United States withdrawal of promised aid to Egypt for construction of the Aswan High Dam will go down in history as "a mistake equaling, if not surpassing, the decision to support the partition of Palestine," Garland Evans Hopkins said here last night.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked by an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired unless specified.
Harold A. Rousselot, a general partner of Francis I. DuPont Co., New York investment firm, was installed last night as the second president of the Society of Class Presidents of Columbia College.
The National Swedish Chorus of seventy-five male voices from Stockholm will sing at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 23.
SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Sept. 26 (UP)--Fire-fighters today attacked scattered blazes left by a 10,500-acre forest fire that at one time periled the resort area around Lake Arrowhead.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)-- The Defense Department announced today that a military training exercise for all services would be held in the Panama Canal Zone and the Republic of Panama next April.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Fifty-three per cent of the religious population of the United States is Proestant, 40 per cent Roman Catholic and 6 per cent Jewish. The remaining 1 per cent is presumed to include members of the Eastern Orthodox Churches.
YONKERS, Sept. 26--Mayor Wagner told a Democratic campaign audience here tonight that the Republican peace claim was "artificial from beginning to end."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 --President Eisenhower told the American Legion Commander, W.C. Daniel, today that trout fishing in rocky streams had become "too hard" for him.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Sept. 26--Another obstacle to the plan to federate Britain's West Indies possessions has been overcome with the victory of Dr. Eric E. Williams' party in Trinidad's elections last Tuesday.
LONDON, Sept. 26--The stock market was unsettled today by the latest decline on Wall Street and by the Jordan incident, as well as by fresh reports of impending capital issues.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 26-- The United States Bureau of the Budget has given final approval to the construction of a $19,170,000 Federal office building at Baltimore.
The International Nickel Company yesterday announced educational grants totaling approximately $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture today revoked the registration of G.H. Miller Co., Chicago egg dealer, as a futures commission merchant and the registration of Gilbert H. Miller, president, as a floor broker, effective Nov. 1.

A VERY subdued and softspoken Arthur Godfrey appeared last night on Channel 2 in the resumption of his Wednesday evening variety show. The humorist is working this season in a studio instead of a theatre and as a result is playing more directly to the home viewer.

ILFORD, England, Sept. 26 (Reuters)--Eleven barefoot players from Uganda caused the biggest upset of the amateur season by beating the British Olympic team, 2--1, tonight. The Britons scored in the first minute and led at half-time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Washington transit riders inspected today a new model bus with picture windows and air conditioning. They were asked whether they would like to ride in such vehicles regularly.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 26 --Following is the text of Adlai E. Stevenson's speech here tonight:
Richard McLiverty, the eighth son of Mrs. Anna McLiverty to go into military service, has added new laurels to the family's record, his mother learned yesterday.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 26 (AP)--Bishop Stephen E. Keeler, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Minnesota, died last night in the United States Army hotel at near-by Patrick Henry Village.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 27-- Japan, one of the major shipping nations, will remain out of the Suez Canal Users Association pending United Nations discussion of the issue, Government leaders decided yesterday.
Two major producers of printing equipment announced yesterday 7 1/10 per cent price increases for matrices up to 14 points in size.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--When Adlai E. Stevenson at Miami last night added Milton S. Eisenhower to the cast of characters he charges with responsibility for the many things he denounces in the Administration's record, the Democratic candidate greatly increased the prospect...
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP)--One load of Prime Steers sold at $34, a new high since March, 1955, in the livestock market here today.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 26 --Adlai E. Stevenson tonight attacked President Eisenhower for "consistent rejection" of positive national leadership.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 26 (AP)--The Army was reported today to have fired a test device hundreds of miles out over the Atlantic Ocean in the first long-distance experiment of its intermediate-range ballistic missile program.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --Britain ruled out today any early move to make sterling fully exchangeable with other currencies in world trade.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26--Universal will carry forward its new policy of teaming leading Hollywood and European stars by paring June Allyson and O.W. Fischer in "My Man Godfrey." The picture will mark the acting debut in this country of Mr. Fischer, a top-rated German actor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --Senator Olin D. Johnston said today the Senate Post Office Committee, which he heads, would make a "further inquiry" on the repainting of collection boxes and trucks.

NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 26--There was considerable activity on the Brooks School campus today. Middlesex School from near-by Concord appeared for its annual football scrimmage with the Green and Black.
Enlisted service personnel will continue to enjoy the facilities of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club at 283 Lexington Avenue as a result of proceeds from the Flamingo Ball.
A 100-year-old man died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital, after having survived an intestinal operation and a heart massage procedure that restored his heartbeat during the surgery Monday.
Theodore Rij, bodyguard to John (Johnny Dio) Diaguardi, labor racketeer, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in connection with the acid-blinding of Victor Riesel.

Adlai Stevenson said something is Miami Tuesday that badly needed to be said, even if he was partisan in his presentation and overlooked the mote in the Democratic eye to call attention to the undoubted beam in the Republican.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 (UP)-- Governor Harriman announced the appointment today of a committee to take charge of the first in a series of conferences on community services to the aging.
Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., heads a group making public offering of the unsubscribed part of a 318,098-share offering of United Aircraft Corporation 4 per cent preferred stock to shareholders.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 (AP)--Czechoslovakia's Olympic champion runner, Emil Zatopek, has had to interrupt training on physician's orders, Radio Prague said today. Zatopek, getting into shape for the Melbourne Olympics Nov. 22 to Dec. 8, recently underwent an operation. He is now permitted light exercise only.

The birth of a new profession would seem to be clearly on the horizon--the profession of space lawyer. Attending the recent International Astronautical Congress in Rome, several speakers pointed out that there is no body of law to handle the problems that will inevitably...

ALBANY, Sept. 26--James M. Landis of Harrison, a former dean of the Harvard Law School, will attempt to resolve the controversy between State Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan and the United States Trotting Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) President Eisenhower accepted today with regret and a "well done" the resignation of Herbert V. Prochnow as Deputy Under Secretary of State.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- President Eisenhower challenged Poland today to prove she had shed Stalinist methods by giving the Poznan rioters a fair and open trial.
NONTAUK POINT, L.I., Sept. 26--There is something about fishing for the leaping and dangerous mako shark that not even the strongest and biggest deep-fighting fish, such as the giant tuna, can match.
ORIENT, L.I., Sept. 26--Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson declared offshore here today that the Eisenhower Administration had given record support to scientific research in agriculture.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26--The Yankees, all wrapped up in seeing their ace southpaw, Whitey Ford, bag his twentieth victory of the year today, ran into something they, weren't looking for on this cold, blustery afternoon.
John L. Kaiser, credit manager of Dan River Mills, Inc., has been elected president of the New York Credit Men's Adjustment Bureau, Inc.
"Tonight,' the late evening television series started two years ago by Steve Allen, will be reduced from ninety minutes to an hour beginning Oct. 29.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 26--The appointment of Forrest Hyde as general chairman of the development program for Newman Hall at the University of Virginia was announced today.

Just as baseball can have its "hot stove league," so has speedboat racing developed a season for second guessing. The regatta railbird likes nothing better than to rehash, relive and retell about his favorite race thrill.

Wool prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops fell 2.2 to 2.9 cents a pound and grease wool dropped 2 to 2.8 cents. The decline was one of the sharpest of the year. During the session losses were as much as 5 cents a pound.

JERICHO, L.I., Sept. 26-- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley carded an 80 for 160 over the new Meadow Brook Club course today to take a seven-stroke lead in the Women's Long Island Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal play championship.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced yesterday that it had obtained the $6,000,000 supplementary flood loan that it had applied for early this year. The loan, arranged with a group of banks headed by the ChaseManhattan Bank, has government participation.
AT our front door, as it were, lies Suffolk County. This easternmost region of Long Island annually contributes to the tables of New Yorkers untold tons of onions, potatoes, cauliflower and duck.

A Moscow dispatch published in The New York Times Sept. 8 erroneously referred to Isaac Stern, the American violinist, as a holder of the Stalin Prize. The fact is that Mr. Stern holds no Soviet award.
John R. Crews, Kings County Republican chairman, announced yesterday the appointment of J. Bertram Wegman, a former Assistant United States Attorney as county campaign director.
The trial of William Power Maloney, attorney formerly in charge of the Justice Department's trial section, was scheduled yesterday in Federal Court for Nov. 5.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (U.P.) --Representative Samuel K. McConnell Jr., after a visit with President Eisenhower today, said "some Democrats" had helped to defeat the school aid bill because "they did not want the Eisenhower Administration to get credit."
BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 (AP)--Only twelve months military service for West German conscripts became a certainty today.
BERLIN, Sept. 26 (AP)--Communist East Germany announced today the completion of a 135mile railway circuit around Berlin that avoids any possibility of Western interference with its train movements.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 26--The Israeli Foreign Minister, Mrs. Golda Meir, told the chief of the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organization today Israel reaffirmed her pledge to maintain a cease-fire on the basis of reciprocity.
LONDON, Sept. 26 (Reuters) --Most British newspapers today treated an American businessman's criticism of shoddy British workmanship and high prices as a challenge.

A two-day conference begins in Albany this morning that is of immense importance to the people of New York State. It is the Governor's Worker Safety Conference, which, while itself the culmination of some months of planning, represents the beginning of a program...
The election of Donald B. Smiley as vice president and treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., succeeding Edwin F. Chinlund, who is retiring, has been announced by Jack I. Straus, chairman.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 26 (AP)--Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, retiring Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, landed in Ankara today to pay a farewell visit to the Turkish Government and military leaders.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 26-- Westchester County received permission from the state today to operate a "traveling platemobile" for the sale of automobile license plates.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., Sept. 26--Vice President Richard M. Nixon revived tonight the controversial "soft on communism" accusations be leveled against Democrats in 1952.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 26-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer called tonight for an "elastic" confederation of European nations that could re-establish Europe's international prestige and independent influence on world affairs.

Interhandel, Swiss investment corporation, and two groups of its stockholders yesterday obtained an injunction preventing the Alien Property Office from revising the capital structure of the General Aniline and Film Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --Democrats started today a chain telephone call campaign designed to increase the radiotelevision audience for Adlai E. Stevenson's nation-wide campaign speech Friday night.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 26--Fire in a combined storage barn and residence at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, scene of the annual national lawn tennis championships, caused $15,000 damage here today.

Safeway Stores, Inc., reported yesterday a record net income of $16,462,979 from its 1,980 food outlets for the thirty-six weeks ended Sept. 8. This is more than double the $7,896,023 earned in the corresponding period last year, when there were 2,009 stores.

ROCHESTER, N.J., Sept. 26 (AP)--Michael H. Prendergast, state Democratic chairman, today charged that Republicans "specifically faked figures" on state aid for education during the 1954 gubernatorial campaign.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 26 (U.P.)--Warren Scarfe of New South Wales virtually assured himself a berth on Australia's Olympic cycling team today by winning the 1,000 meter race in 1 minute 15.26 seconds during the national cycling championships. Dick Iloog, the favorite, was second.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 26--Mrs. Edith Barretto Stevens Parsons, a sculptor whose work had been displayed throughout the country, died this morning at her home after a long illness. She was the wife of Howard Crosby Parsons.
Nelson Rockefeller was named chairman of the Temporary Commission on the Constitutional Convention at the group's first meeting, held yesterday at 270 Broadway.
OXFORD, England, Sept. 26 (Reuters)--A Church of England conference wound up here today with a declaration that divorce should be permissible "in certain cases."
FLINT, Mich., Sept. 26--The 1957 Buick line was described today as new throughout almost all the 5,291 parts in each car. The models will go on sale across the country on Nov. 9.
QUEMOY ISLAND, Sept. 26 (UP)--Admiral Felix B. Stump said after a surprise inspection of this outpost island today that the Chinese Nationalists had transformed it into a "strong defensive fortress."

NOTHING really important seems to have happened since Judy Garland was last here five years ago. Again the police barriers were up in front of the Palace last evening, and the block was choked with fans.
CLINTON, Tenn., Sept. 26 (AP)--Dynamite was exploded tonight in a field near the home of one of the newly admitted Negro pupils of Clinton High School.
TRENTON, Sept. 26--Three retired New Jersey State Police officers admitted here today that wiretap and eavesdropping devices had been used by that agency in criminal investigations.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26 --Dr. Harold William Chase, assistant professor of public and international affairs at Princeton University, has been appointed...

Maas Brothers, Inc., which is owned by the Allied Stores Corporation, will open its fifth store in Florida on Oct, 1. The new unit, which will be in Sarasota, will be the first complete department store in that trading area. It will occupy 80,000 square feet on two floors and will have an outdoor shop.

CHICAGO, Sept, 26--Two unions striking against Swift Co., the nation's largest meat packer, said today they had reached agreements on new wage contracts with three more Swift competitors. Thirty-nine Swift plants have been closed by the strike.
PARIS, Sept. 26--The heads of the French and British Governments met here today to discuss a possible reversion to a tough policy toward Egypt.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (U.P.) --The Republican National Committee today sent party officials across the nation a new campaign film featuring President Eisenhower and other Administration leaders.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (U.P.)--The booming British aircraft industry announced today it has exported $200,000,000 worth of planes so far this year, 10 per cent more than it sold abroad in all of 1955. The industry's best customer was the United States, which paid $4,200,000 for British-built planes. The "best seller" was the turbo-prop Viscount airliner.

LONDON, Sept. 26--Seretse Khama, former Crown Prince of the Bamangwato tribe of Bechuanaland, is scheduled to return home next month after eight years of exile resulting from his marriage to a white woman.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 26 --Religion and the arts will be welded into one here tomorrow when Wittenberg College dedicates its new $1,550,000 chapel and library.

A part collie dog that sniffed himself breathless--and found $4,700--turned out yesterday to be another man's best friend. The money belonged to his master's next-door neigh bor, and eventually it was returned to its rightful owner.
THE GREEN ROOM at Bloomingdale's is featuring black --in tweed, satin and faille. It is especially prolific in black silk crepe in dinner-dress form.

Two welterweight bouts, each ten rounds, were arranged yesterday by Promoter Teddy Brenner for next month at St. Nicholas Arena. Danny Giovanelli, Brooklyn, will meet Joe Miceli, New York, on Oct. 8. Sugar Hart, Philadelphia, will box Earl Dennis, New York, on Oct. 15.
BERLIN, Sept. 23--The popularity of the United States show at the Berlin Industrial Exhibition is so great that it will get a second run a month from now.
The commercial helicopter finally made its way into downtown Manhattan yesterday as operations began at the city's new heliport.
To help maintain the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House's services the Nov. 19 and Dec. 13 performances of the play "The Sleeping Prince" have been planned as benefits.

More than $94,000,000 in news municipal bond issues, including a $75,000,000 third installment on Connecticut's Q445,000,000 turnpike financing, were announced yesterday. Sales during the day amounted to more than $26,000,000.

Herbert Leeds has been named director of merchandising for Exquisite Form Brassiere, Inc., and its affiliate companies. Mr. Leeds joined the company in 1953 as advertising director. In his new post he will be responsible for the company's merchandising relations with its retailers.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 26 (AP) --Harry S. Truman fire another shot today in the continuing dispute over whether Vice President Richard M. Nixon had ever called him a traitor.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (U.P.)-- Bert F. Kline Sr., editor of daily newspapers in Pennsylvania for many years, died today of cancer after an illness of several months.
BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., Sept. 26--Miss Sharon Ann Murphy and Robert Spencer Keyes were married here this evening at St. Dunstan's Chapel, Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Cranbrook.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 --Pakistan's new Government has officially notified all its diplomatic missions that it will "loyally adhere" to all treaty commitments with the West.
The Port of New York was virtually assured yesterday of at least a month's reprieve from a threatened pier strike.
CAIRO, Sept. 26 (AP)--An Egyptian stamp commemorating nationalization of the Suez Canal company went on sale today, two months after President Gamal Abdel Nasser took over the canal operation.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 26--A Polish Air Force officer, who fled with a MIG-15 to the Danish island of Bornholm, said today he had left his country because he hated his Russian superior officers and the "whole Soviet system."
LONDON, Sept. 26--Alarm over a decline in public support for the Government is expressed in resolutions to be put before the Conservative party's annual conference next month.
Adam Frank Sr., a retired lawyer, died in Washington Tuesday after a long illness. He had practiced law here before his retirement several years ago. His age was 87.
SOUTH SALEM, N.Y., Sept. 26--Harsh criticism was aimed today at the Westchester County Planning Commission for looking too far into the future and telling the public what it saw.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP)--Wage negotiations between the railroads and eleven unions were broken off today. Both sides asked help from the National Mediation Board.

The Foundation for Traffic Safety, a unit of the American Automobile Association, has donated $50,000 to the Teachers College of Columbia University for basic research in traffic safety. The basis research for answers to the acute problem of death on the highways will take five...

Lower wheat loadings and a decline in miscellaneous merchandise traffic last month held gross revenues o the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway t0 $48,951,395. Gross in August last year amounted to $50,156,080.
PEIPING, Sept. 16 (Reuters) --The Chinese Communist party's new Constitution, approved here today, makes no mention of Mao Tse-tung, the Chinese head of state.

Admiral Vee won the first running of the Nassau County Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The race, a mile-and-afurlong event, attracted seven, contestants. The 16,360 players, at hand didn't think too highly, of Admiral Vee's chances. A middling choice, he paid $13.50 for $2.

SATURDAY, 11 A.M.: "Ballet Girl," a film story told by Claire Bloom about life behind the scenes of the Royal Danish Ballet, will be shown at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue, at 103d Street, and again at 3 P.M. Stories of the ballet...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Under rising pressure from the Republican party, President Eisenhower is ready to expand his television campaign. He will go beyond the six-speech effort on which his re-election strategy was originally built.
New York Republicans heard a warning last night against complacency in the current campaign.
American insistence on reciprocity in negotiating bilateral airline agreements between nations was criticized yesterday by a foreign airline seeking rights here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- American motorists were assured today that the Government had no plans for rationing gasoline or other petroleum products in view of the Suez Canal crisis.

A crowd of 700 persons filled the nave of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, at 10 A.M. yesterday for a memorial service for Douglas M. Moffat, United States Ambassador to Australia.
TUPELO, Miss., Sept. 26 (U.P.)-- Elvis Presley, rock 'n' roll singer, returned today to his native town.
MEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 26-- Lambda chapter of the Alpha XI Delta sorority at Tufts University has voted to resign from the national body.
The Stockholm's third mate testified yesterday he did not summon the Swedish liner's captain to the bridge before the collision with the Andrea Doria because he saw no reason to do so.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold warned today that the Israeli-Jordanian crisis must be brought "under control rapidly." He indicated that otherwise he would ask the Security Council to take up the matter.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) --Ezra Taft Benson, Agriculture Secretary, accused Democrats tonight of trying to "promote" a farm depression in order to harvest votes in November.
The annual maintenance fund campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York was opened yesterday with a luncheon at the Barbizon Hotel. The goal is $315,000.
FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 26-- Clarence Blair Mitchell of 177 East Eightieth Street, New York, a lawyer and author, died here today at his country home, Pennbrook. His age was 90.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 26 (U.P.)-- The New York Rangers today signed two holdover goalies for the National Hockey League season, but optioned a rookie, Marcel Paille, to the Cleveland Barons of the American League.

MONTREAL, Sept. 26 (U.P.)-- Maurice (Rocket) Richard today was unanimously chosen captain of the Montreal Canadiens. He succeeds Emile (Butch) Bouchard, who retired at the end of the last National Hockey League season.
The presidents of the two leading networks were costarred yesterday in the House Antitrust subcommittee investigation into television.
Contracts awarded last month for construction work in New York State amounted to $184,310,000, a decline of 26 per cent from the volume in August, 1955, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.
Extensive reorganization of the city's Office of Civil Defense, including a 28 per cent cut in its $1,862,502 budget, was recommended, yesterday by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse.

Representatives of the major advertising associations will gather in Washington today to work out a method for mobilizing American advertising skills to tell the world of this country's desire for peaceful progress.
NORWICH, N.Y., Sept. 26-- Frank Zuber, who made a fortune in the oil business and who was Mayor here from 1929 to 1943, died last night at Chenango Memorial Hospital. His age was 80.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 --The Hollywood branch of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists opened contract negotiations today with representatives of local television and radio stations, program producers and advertising agencies. The contract covering the union's 5,000 members here expires Nov. 15.

The Most Rev. Peter Sigismondi, Archbishop of Rome and general secretary of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith arrived at the New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for a twoweek visit in this country.

The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plans to build a $1,000,000 factory to produce tread rubber at Chehalis, Wash., ninety-two miles south of Seattle. Construction will begin next month and production lines are expected to be operating by Feb. 1, E.J. Thomas, president, announced yesterday.

The election of Orville S. Carpenter as president and a director of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation was announced yesterday by George R. Brown, chairman of the natural gas pipeline company.

PARIS, Sept. 26--The French Cabinet postponed today the definition of a new status for Algeria. Its purpose is to await clarification of the Suez Canal dispute and resolution of internal political questions.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. 26 (Reuters)--The British Mofor Corporation, whose dismissal of 6,000 men in July led to a three-week strike of 25,000 of its employes, has reached agreement with the fourteen trade unions involved on the question of compensation in future layoffs.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 26--The House Committee on Un-American Activities ended today a three-day inquiry into Communist infiltration of Connecticut industry. The investigation will be resumed in Washington after the election.
The Celanese Corporation of America has announced the election of Richard W. KixMiller, vice president in charge of the Celanese chemical division, to the board of directors.
Contributing to a quieter city, the Sanitation Department is installing rubber strips on hoppers of its 1,400 waste-collection trucks, the Mayor's Committee for a Quiet City announced yesterday.

SED properly, trimmings can be the seasoning of a room, the salt and pepper that accent the flavor of the decor. Rediscovered recently by interior designers, tassels, heavy fringes and twisted silken ropes have entered a new period of popularity.

CENTRE ISLAND, L.I., Sept. 26--Titia, a Canadian six-meter sailed by Bill Gooderham, overhauled Herman Whiton's Goose on the final leg to defeat the home-club sloop today in the third race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club International Challenge Cup series today.
VIENNA, Sept. 26 (UP)-- Antonin Zapotocky, Czechoslovakia's Communist President, has accepted an invitation to visit Indonesia, a communique said tonight.
BERLIN, Sept. 26 (Reuters)-- The New York City Ballet took nearly twenty curtain calls tonight after its first evening at the West Berlin Festival.
Plans for a research center in Yorktown, Westchester County, were announced yesterday by he International Business Machines Corporation.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26--James S. Staples, the Canadian whose information about a bribe attempt led to the expulsion of a Soviet diplomat from Canada last month, said today he would leave his present job at the end of the week because of unfavorable publicity.

"Unless we can promise that the dollar will remain stable and retain its purchasing power in the future, much of the incentive of people to save will be lost." These are the words of Walter H. Dreier, president of the United States Savings and Loan...
LONDON, Sept. 26--A Foreign Office spokesman revived today the assertion that Britain might use force as a last resort to settle the dispute with Egypt over control of the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting members banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 19:
New headquarters were officially opened yesterday for the Travelers Aid Society of New York with the blessing of Francis Cardinal Spellman and praise from Mayor Wagner on its work.
A secondary offering yesterday of 36,465 shares of F.W. Woolworth Company stock at $45.25 a share by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Beane was oversubscribed.
ALBANY, Sept. 26--The Public Service Commission today ordered the New York Central Railroad to continue operating thirty-nine of the forty-nine passenger trains now running on its West Shore line.

CHICAGO, Sept, 26 (AP)--The Chicago Cardinals of the National Football League today reacquired Jim Root, their No. 1 quarterback in 1953, on waivers from the Cleveland Browns. Released by the Cards in 1954, Root played Canadian football that year. After an Army hitch, the former Miami of Ohio star signed with the Browns.
The initial steps toward the application of nuclear power to a supertanker have been taken by the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Following is the text of a foreign policy address by Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State, before the Western Suburban Democratic Club of Maryland in Bethesda tonight:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --Farmers have signed 79,985 agreements to put nearly three million acres under the 1957 winter wheat acreage reserve program of the soil bank through Sept. 21, the Department of Agriculture said today.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 26-- Westchester communities were urged today by the chairman of the County Water Agency to "stop dragging their heels" in developing dual and triple pipelines to dependable water resources.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The National Academy of Sciences said today that Dr. Harry Wexler would be in charge of all United States scientific efforts in Antarctica during the International Geophysical Year 1957-58.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Following is the transcript of the news conference held today by Secretary of State Dulles:
HONG KONG, Sept. 26--A former resident of Hong Kong was sentenced to death Monday at a public espionage trial in Canton, Wen Wei Pao, local Communist publication, reported...
Frank Costello lost two legal decisions yesterday in his denaturalization trial but still succeeded in keeping off the witness stand.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Dean Acheson, asserted today that the Eisenhower Administration was dissipating the strength and unity of the free world that United States leadership had built up in the postwar years.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Sept. 26 (Reuters)--Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, discussed the Suez deadlock today with Emir Feisal, brother of King Saud and Premier and Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia.

BUFFALO, Sept. 26 (AP)--The Confraternity of Christian Doctrine meets a major need of the church and of society in our time, the defense and spread of Christian concepts, the Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Worcester, Mass., said tonight.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 1,177,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the end of the reporting week supplies were 176,944,000 barrels, compared with 175,767,000 a week earlier and 151,805,000 a year ago.
"THE FIELD OF VISION," by Wright Morris, is a stylishly symbolic novel about wandering Nebraskans who review their wild destinies at a Mexico City bullfight.
Robin Roberts and the Phillies, 7; the Dodgers and Don Newcombe, 3.
The 1956 Seeing Eye membership drive will be led by Mrs. Frederick J. Brotherton of Englewood, N.J., and Quogue, L.I. The drive will begin Oct. 16 and continue through Nov. 20.
The Friends Committee for Children will gain as a result of the American premiere of Frank Martin's operatic version of "The Tempest" by William Shakespeare.
Directors of the Lone Star Cement Corporation yesterday proposed to split the capital stock on the basis of 2 shares for one, subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting Dec. 11.

LAREDO, Tex., Sept. 26 (AP)-- Four Air Force fliers were killed today when two T-33 jet trainers collided eighteen miles east of here. They were stationed at Laredo Air Force base. Officials said two were instructors and two were student pilots.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 26-- Cornell University announced today the award of the first Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory Fellowship to John S. Priedeman of Asheville, N.C. Mr. Priedeman received a Bachelor of Civil Engineering degree in June.
The National Recreation Association opened yesterday a a recreation book center at its headquarters, 8 West Eighth Street. More than 750 books on recreation are on display.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits charged last night that Mayor Wagner lacked the qualifications to deal with the issues of peace before the United States Senate.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 26--Sharp criticism of the proposed organization of an international "atoms--for--peace" agency developed today among representatives of smaller nations.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP)-- Suzie Sims wowed the boys at Boston University crew practice today, but her dream of being coxswain for the freshman boat was short-lived.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 26--West Germany's booming trade with North America reached a post-war high in the first seven months of 1956, according to the German-Ameri can Trade Promotion Agency.
The Mayor's Committee for the World Fashion Center held an all-male fashion show yesterday at its headquarters at 10 East Fifty-sixth Street. It was attended by 100 members of the fashion industry.
Directors of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company have authorized the expenditure of $50,000,000 for a major mill expansion program at Luke, Md.
The formation of an organic chemicals division was announced yesterday by the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation.
MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Sept. 26--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ira Richardson Hiller 2d of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Alden Hiller, to Wilfred Emile Genest.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 26--Mrs. Harrison F. Flippin, the defending champion from Ardmore, Pa., today took a seven-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the thirty-first United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Secretary of State Dulles outlined a new policy of "patience" toward the Suez Canal dispute today.

ALBANY, Sept. 26--The executive committee of the State Bar Association has endorsed the court reorganization plan of the Temporary State Commission on the Courts as "a reasonable basis for developing a modernized, system of judicial administration."
DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 26--A dynamite explosion on the Connecticut Turnpike this morning injured three construction workers.
ANDERSON, Ind., Sept. 26-- Senator Estes Kefauver denounced President Eisenhower's major campaign speech on farm policy tonight as an attempt to sell the farmer an election-year "gold brick."
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 (UP)--A sharp drop in Argentine imports during August kept the trade deficit for the month down to $12,000,000, a Finance Ministry report showed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) --Eric Johnston, a spokesman for the movie industry, appealed today for a liberal foreign trade policy that would lower tariffs and expand free enterprises.
The election of Roy T. Hurley and Richard K. Paynter Jr. as directors of the General Cable Corporation has been announced by J.R. MacDonald, chairman and president.
The Minneapolis-Moline Company will halt production at its Minneapolis tractor plant for two months beinning next Monday. About 1,100 will be laid off.
The Department of Air Pollution Control removed a seal yesterday from a boiler that supplies heat and hot water in the 240-apartment building at 205 East Seventy-eighth Street.
A late rally yesterday countered sharp early losses, and the stock market closed mixed.

MIAMI BEACH, Sept. 26 (AP) --Oliver Peck Newman, a Commissioner of the District of Columbia before World War I and a former newspaper man, died in Miami Heart Institute last night. He was 79 years old.
The age of the homemaker has a lot to do with her family's diet. This is the finding of a survey reported recently by the United States Agriculture Department.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26--Faith Bacon, famed as a fan and bubble dancer twenty years ago, died tonight in Grant Hospital from injuries suffered when she plunged from a hotel window early today. She was about 45 years old.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (U.P.)-- Al Lopez, the Cleveland Indians' manager, said today he was "really tickled" with Sal Maglie's no-hit game for Brooklyn against the Phillies last night.

A sculptured grass flacon, designed to be carded in the purse but large enough to hold threequarters of an ounce of perfume, has been introduced by Carven. Called "Flacon De Voyage," the new container holds both "Ma Griffe" and "Robe d'un Soir." The first scent costs $20, while the latter is priced at $27. Available at Sake Fitth Avenue, Bonwit Teller and B. Altman.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (AP)-- A fifty-six-foot cruiser en route from Chicago to Florida has been missing in Lake Erie for three days, the Coast Guard reported today.
In its calm, easy way the Columbia Encyclopedia tells a good deal about ink.
Hurricane Flossy, supposed to have blown itself out on the way up from the Gulf of Mexico, started to give the Atlantic coast a sample of its power last night.

Mayor Nelson O. Howarth of Springfield, Ill., denied yesterday in a letter to The New York Times that he had said in an address in Springfield that he would support the Presidential candidacy of Adlai E. Stevenson.

LONDON, Sept. 26--Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, urged West and East today to agree on a policy of neutralizing the Middle East. He said this was the only means of maintaining peace in the area.
Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers in the recent sale of the four-story dwelling at 7 Sutton Place by the estate of Marshall Kernochan to Robert G. Goelet for occupancy.

Judge Nathan Turk of Owego, N.Y., Grand Master of Masons of New York State, will be instaled as commander in chief of the Masonic War Veterans at a dance in the Sheraton-Astor Hotel tomorrow night. Cloverleaf Post 13 is the sponsor of the dance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- The Federal Bureau of Investigation predicted today that if present trends continued 2,500,000 major crimes would be committed in the country this year. It would be the highest total in history.

A daughter, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. James R. Shepard of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., on Sept. 19 in Lenox Hill Hospital here.
A son, their third child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. H. Lawrence Parker of Greenwich, Conn., last Thursday in Doctors Hospital.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 26 (Reuters)--Terrorist gunmen shot to death a British soldier driving his car through a Nicosia suburb today. The car continued until it crashed into a house.

The General Telephone Company of Indiana, Inc., announced yesterday that it was offering to exchange 95,000 shares of its $2.50 preferred stock, no par value, for preferred shares of two other Indiana telephone companies in which it already owns substantial common stock interest.
IN one of his petulant moments a year ago, Duke Snider let go a blast at Dodger fans who had turned on him with a merciless booing.

William T. Ketcham, gray goods manager of Catlin Farish Company, Inc., and A.P. McAuley, president of the company bearing his name, have been elected directors of Worth Street, Inc., the promotional organization formed to help maintain the downtown area as a textile trade center.

The British Government has announced that the plan proposed by the Chancellor of the Exchequer in his last budget for the issuance of a premium saving bond will go into effect on Nov. 1. This plan constitutes a distinct departure in British revenue-raising practice.
The latest Israeli raid of reprisal into Jordan, in which anywhere from thirty to fifty Jordanians were killed, was deplorable.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 26 --Thomas E. Dewey charged today that Adlai E. Stevenson was advocating policies that would undermine the nation's defenses. He said the best guarantee for continued peace lay in the reelection of President Eisenhower.
Secretary of the Air Force Donald A. Quarles said last night that the United States would use atomic weapons in a "limited war" as well as in a big one.
A rare portrait of Gen. John Burgoyne, who surrendered his British army at Saratoga on Oct. 17, 1777, now hangs at the New-York Historical Society.
Electric power production for the week ended last Saturday rose to 11,482,000,000 kilowatt hours from 11,339,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
The 1,162-seat National Theatre, 208 West Forty-first Street, has been sold to Harry Fromkes for $900,000.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 26--Nicaragua has notified the twenty other American nations that Nicaraguans and others living abroad are plotting a revolution against her. The nations have been asked to control such subversive activities.
HARTFORD, Sept. 26--Alleged irregularities in United States Senate petitions filed by Miss Vivien Kellems of Stonington were disclosed today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 26--Patriarch Vikentije of Yugoslavia will visit Moscow early next month for the first contacts between the Serb and Russian Orthodox Churches since 1919.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--Ted Williams and Mickey Vernon of the Red Sox drove in two runs apiece Today in support of Frank Sullivan's six-hit pitching as Boston closed its home season with an 8-4 victory over the Washington Senators.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26--Miss Sharon Paul Ruttenberg and Jerrold M. Post will be married in June.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 26--A strong northeast wind and steep, breaking seas caused the postponement of today's competition in the international class team match between the Manhasset Bay and Royal Norwegian Yacht Clubs.
The quesiton of whether the Government will abolish the ceiling on interest rates on mortgages guaranteed by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration is likely...

Four new directors were elected yesterday by the Atlas Plywood Corporation at its annual meeting in Boston. They are: Simon M. Jaglom, president of the New York Commodities Corporation; Jack I. Poses, president of D'Orsay Sales Company, New York; Dewey E. Stone, president of Harodite Finishing Company, Dighton, Mass., and Charles A. Wyman, vice president of Pantasote Company, New York.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (U.P.)-- The Baltimore Orioles today signed Jessie-Johnson, 19, a right-handed pitcher, to a 1957 contract with their Class C Aberdeen (S.D.) farm.
BREMEN, Germany, Sept. 26 (AP)--A Scandinavian Airlines (SAS) official announced the line would inaugurate a nonstop flight from Bremen to New York Oct. 7.

GALVESTON, Tex., Sept. 26 (AP)--John Sealy Hospital officials reported today that Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, who is in critical condition with cancer, passed an easier night and appeared to have lost no further ground.
Cotton futures moved irregularly yesterday to close 5 points (25 cents a bale) up to 6 points (30 cents a bale) off. Volume on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate.
Members of an independent transit union threatened yesterday to quit their jobs unless they received guarantees that they would not be "forced" to become clerks and conductors.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) --John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, took issue today with Adlai E. Stevenson's suggestion that President Eisenhower's brother had urged the Administration to "appease" Juan D. Peron of Argentina.

MONTREAL, Sept. 26--Tadeusz Kassern, a former consular attache who defected from the Polish Government in 1948, received a visa today permitting him to enter the United States for permanent residence. Mrs. Kassern has received a permanent resident visa.

"Susannah," a new opera by Carlisle Floyd, will have its first performance tonight at 8:15 o'clock at the City Center. Erich Leinsdorf will conduct, and they principals will be Phyllis Curtin, Jon Crain, Norman Treigle and Eb Thomas.

AUGUSTA, Me., Sept. 26-- Official returns from the Maine general election today confirmed that Representative Robert Hale of the First District, Republican, defeated James C. Oliver, Democrat, by 29 votes. The vote was 58,028 to 57,999.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP)--Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, the Wimbledon winner in 1955, defeated George Worthington of Britain, 6--3, 6--4, today in the first round of the professional indoor tennis championship at Wembley Stadium.

A "basic" group of lipsticks as been introduce by Cashmers Bouquet. Called "Inner Glow," the lipsticks are said to protect against dryness and to offer long-lasting color. There are seven colors available. The only new one in the group is "Peachof-a-Pink." Lipsticks recall for 79 cents each at most cosmetic counters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)-- The Air Force lifted today the order that had grounded all B-52's after a fatal crash on Sept. 17.
The Army is offering for sale a number of lengths of subterranean communication cables in eastern Long Island, it was announced yesterday.

Heavy imports of Japanese woolens represent the greatest threat to the American woolen industry, the American Trade Association for British Woolens, Inc., said yesterday in asking President Eisenhower to refuse a tariff increase sought by domestic producers.

Volume is no longer the sole test of successful sales management, Dr. Henry Bund, vice president of the Research Institute of America, said yesterday in an address to the distribution committee of the National Association of Manufacturers.

The Union Pacific Railroad announced yesterday that its net income in August was $8,470,066, This was $172,485 more than the 1955 figure. But that gain was attributed to other than "transportation" revenue.

Gross revenues and net income of New York Telephone Company continued to show gains through August over the like 1955 period, the company reported yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission.

A spokesman for organized medicine urged caution yesterday on Forty-second Street-Beth David Hospital in setting up as community health plan for 750,000 white collar workers and executives in the midtown East Side area.

NORWICH, N. Y., Sept. 27 (AP)--The Rev. George W. McPherson, author of religious books and pastor of the Old Tent Evangelical Church, Baptist, in New York pot twentyfive years, died yesterday at the home of a son near here. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) --The head of a liberal trade policy group said today a "ground swell" of opinion appears to be developing in Congress for establishment of a quota system as the basis of United States import policy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The World Bank will not change policies that were severely criticized, at its annual meeting here this week, Eugene R. Black, president, told the final session today.

A warehouse and office building that is to be erected at Thirty-fifth Street and Hunters Point Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by Simon Manages Co. of New York and the Cabin Craft Company of Dalton, Ga., manufacturers and distributors of carpets.

The Board of Estimate yesterday adopted unanimously resolutions requesting, the Transit Authority.to hold public hearings on proposed bus service changes in Brooklyn and Queens.
William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, has come out against the party's new draft resolution confessing past errors and proposing changes in the party line.
The third mate of the Swedish liner Stockholm denied yesterday that it was the ship's practice never to reduce speed in fog regardless of its density.

National Airlines,, Inc., marked its twenty-second year of operations with record operating revenues and earnings. Results for the current fiscal year are expected to exceed those for the year ended last June 30, the air line said.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27--Adlai E. Stevenson warned tonight that within twenty years the Communist nations might seize production leadership from the free world.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (AP)--Mikhail Chulaki, director of the Bolshoi Theatre ballet troupe, said today he had decided "personally" that the company should go to Britain after all.

BONN, West Germany, Sept. 27--The West German Cabinet approved today legislation providing a one-year term of service for West Germany's military conscripts. Thus the Government bowed to overwhelming political pressure in favor of shorter military service.

Dr. William Harley Glafke, a gastroenterologist, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 70. His home was at 780 East Seventy-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The 166th session of the Supreme Court opened today in traditionally brief and dignified fashion.

LIKE Londoners and New Yorkers, the people of Santa Fe take a tremendous interest in the times their town has changed flags. This, of course, is less a matter of morbid statistics than of pageantry. The lot of man is one colonialism after another until a stable amalgam is achieved.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island, Oct.1--Fif ty or more hunters from the United States were here today to start the upland shooting season by blazing away at Hungarian partridges. There are pheasants here, too, and grouse, but nobody comes this far to shoot them.
TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 1--Lewis W. Douglas called today for the re-election of President Eisenhower.

The Most Rev. Raymond A. Kearney, Auxiliary Bishop and Chancellor of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, died of a heart attack last night in his home at 151 Beach 147th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens. His age was 54.

Harry S. Truman and Governor Harriman, who merged six weeks ago in an effort to prevent Adlai E. Stevenson from running for President, joined hands last night at a series of rallies to lift Mr. Stevenson's chances.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP)--Salable hog receipts expanded to 12,000 head in the livestock market here today, the largest since March. Prices were marked down.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1--Brazil proposed today that the proposed international atomic agency begin operations by establishing regional training centers.

BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 1--The shadow of former Senator Glen H. Taylor lengthens over Idaho's Senatorial contest. Observant Republicans swear the shadow is singularly bright. To Democrats, except for Mr. Taylor's followers among them, the shadow has a somber look.
Reports that E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., would break up its multi-million-dollar advertising account among several agencies were confirmed by the company yesterday.
The Mayor League Baseball Players' Association became a formal organization yesterday when Bob Feller of the Cleveland Indians was elected president.
PANAMA, Oct.--Ernesto de la Guardia Jr., was inaugurated today as Panama's twenty-sixth President. He is 52 years old, a business executive who studied economics in the United States.

The Newsweek Building at 132 West Forty-second Street, on the southeast corner of Broadway, was sold yesterday to a client of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., for an unannounced sum.

Heavy trade and commission house selling yesterday dropped potato prices to new lows for the life of the contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Volume was heavy as Maine potato interests sold in anticipation of a heavy yield because of good growing weather and favorable harvesting conditions during the last few days.

Mrs. Helen Rice Kilbreth of New York, widow of John Guthrie Kilbreth, was married here yesterday morning in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church to Porter Lawrence Willett, also of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Victor Baer.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 4-- A Scarsdale policeman was shot and killed early today, apparently while investigating a traffic violation. In a manhunt for the killer that followed, more than thirty shots were fired, but the gunman and a person believed to be his accomplice were still at large tonight.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 4-- Five Israeli civilians were killed and at least one other was critically wounded tonight in an ambush six miles south of Sodom near the Dead Sea.

PRICE tags at meat counters provide a cheery note for shoppers this week-end. Pork is an outstanding offering, while smoked hams are being featured in many chain and independent stores. In some outlets whole hams are 47 cents a pound.

Mental first aid for victims of accidents or catastrophes was recommended here yesterday at the third annual meeting of the Academy of Psychosomatic Medicine at the Plaza Hotel.

The master of the lost Italian liner Andrea Doria charged yesterday that the collision with the Swedish liner Stockholm had been caused by two failures aboard the Stockholm. He said they were a failure to steer a proper course and a failure to sound warning signals when the Stockholm changed course.
Strong activity in the textile market was reported yesterday for the first time in many months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The Export-Import Bank granted today a loan of $10,000,000 to Fiat S.s.A., largest manufacturer of automobiles in Italy. The money is to be spent for American machinery and equipment.
ABERDEEN PROVING GROUND, Md., Oct. 4 (AP)--The Army displayed today a new weapon apparently intended as a lightweight atomic artillery piece.
Plans for the sixth annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic were set in motion Wednesday at a meeting at the home of the benefit chairman, Mrs. A. Neil Lilley, at 1088 Park Avenue.
Hank Greenberg, general manager of the Cleveland Indians, denied yesterday the widely circulated rumor that Kerby Farrell soon woudl be named to succeed Al Lopez as Cleveland's field manager.
Operators were active in deals involving apartment houses in the Bronx yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP)-- Wholesalers' sales for the first eight months of this year were 9 per cent higher than in the comparable period of 1955, the Census Bureau reported today.

Looking beyond today's contest, when Don Newcombe will do the pitching for the Dodgers, it appears that Clem Labine is a strong possibility as a starter against the Yankees in the third world series game at spacious Yankee Stadium tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 4--The Cleveland Orchestra opened its thirty-ninth season, and its tenth under the leadership of George Szell, with a concert in Severance Hall this evening. To one listener who was making his first acquaintance with the surroundings, it was an absorbing event, as much for the physical properties as for the music and musicians involved.

"PLAYHOUSE 90," the new hour and a half series to be presented on a regular basis over Channel 2, did not have a very auspicious debut last night. It presented a war drama that ran the gamut of hokum.
Buffalo, N.Y., sold $11,375,000 of various general obligation bonds at competitive bidding yesterday to an investment banking group headed by Lehman Brothers. The bonds mature from 1957 to 1971.
The Rumanian Government has agreed to confer with United States representatives in Bucharest on Oct. 15 in an effort to settle differences between the countries.
ALBANY, Oct. 4--New York State has applied to the Federal Government for financial assistance, on an extra 453 miles of proposed state highways.
THOMAS WOLFE has been dead now for eighteen years, but the legend of his tempestuous talent and his frenzied life will not die soon.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Oct. 4-- Henry Hagen of The Knoll scored a 41, 40--81 today for a 36-hole total of 156 to win the New Jersey Senior Golf Association championship at the Baltusrol Golf Club.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4--Ezra Taft Benson intensified his role today in the Republican national campaign.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks increased $89,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The election campaign has taken a bad turn. It may be temporary, but for the moment the professional politicians, who are immoderate and pragmatic by nature, have overcome the moderate and idealistic candidates in both parties.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 4 (UP) --Golden Cape, the outsider in a field of seven, was declared the winner of the featured mile-anda-sixteenth race today. Cosmic Hero, who ran in front almost all the way and finished first, was disqualified and placed second.

Although attention is focused for the moment on the Suez crisis, which comes before the United Nations Security Council today, another problem is already looming above the horizon which could have even graver repercussions for the Western World.
PARIS, Oct. 4--French Premier Guy Mollet put all his political eggs in one basket today.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 4 --Hackley School's football team is out to make "a good impression" in its first year of competition in the Ivy Prep School League.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4--A Philadelphia surgeon announced here today the successful development of an operation for use against one of the most common heart ailments.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4-- United States film producers will supply films to Iron Curtain countries provided Russia and her satellites agree to conditions under which the American pictures will be shown.

The time-honored authority of a ship master to punish at his own discretion or "log" infractions of shipboard discipline by a crew member was limited yesterday for the first time in American shipping.
ROME, Oct. 4--The Communists and Left-Wing Socialists moved tonight toward burying their ten-year-old "unity of action" pact.

MINNESOTA calls itself the "Land of Ten Thousand Lakes," and that is no exaggeration. There are 10,000 and more, covering 4,000,000 watery acres. The state's name, a Sioux Indian word, supposedly means "cloud-tinted water."
SYRACUSE, Oct. 4--After tangling with the Panthers of Pittsburgh, and the Maryland Terrapins, Syracuse's football squad has an open date Saturday.

An effective breach in the invisible barrier against hiring Negroes for flight positions has been made with the public reaffirmation by the eighteen airlines serving New York State that they will judge all job applicants "without regard to race, creed, color or national origin."
Coach Lou Little expects Columbia to play better football against Princeton tomorrow than it did in losing to Brown last Saturday.
The Beekman Family Association has sold the five-story dwelling at 35 East Thirtyeighth Street to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, and Howard Geoghegan.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 4--An explosion in an office building in midtown Hamburg appears to have uncovered a large-scale arms export business to the Middle East and North Africa. The blast reduced the building, a four-story reinforced concrete structure, to rubble.
An elementary demonstration of stock market operations will be portrayed in a television drama titled "The Big Board."
POZNAN, Poland, Oct. 4-- Wladyslaw Gomulka was reported tonight to have thrown his influence behind the group of Communist leaders seeking increased liberation of Polish life.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 28-- Republicans and Democrats appear to be in a neck-and-neck race for Minnesota's eleven electoral votes.
THE "enfant terrible" of the American fashion peerage, Charles James, is now designing baby clothes.

The Territory of Alaska, which is inhabited by 200,000 or more human beings, who move around so fast sometimes it is hard to count them, has collectively arrived at the theory that if it behaves like a state maybe it will be allowed to become one.
Arthur C. Carruthers, a founder and former publisher and editor of Safety Engineering magazine here, died Wednesday in Bradenton, Fla., where he had lived after his retirement. His age was 78.
Depression-spawned laws that build a floor under store prices still are on the books in the midst of prosperity.
More than $3,000,000 was praised last night at the opening dinner of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies' thirty-ninth annual appeal.
BERLIN, Oct. 4--The United States view of policy for the free world is that the Soviet leaders must be deprived of further victories, Robert Murphy said tonight.

Adlai E. Stevenson carried his campaign into Harlem last night declaring that the achievement of equality of rights and opportunities for all Americans was "the great unfinished business before the United States."
A program of joint air-sea European cruises with Trans World Airlines was announced yesterday by the American Export Lines.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4-- Senator Estes Kefauver advocated today that the United States abandon its air base at Dharhan in Saudi Arabia rather than grant that country's demand to keep out American service men of the Jewish faith.
Despite news developments that brought sharp gains for individual issues, the stock market rally grated to a halt yesterday. It was merely a halt, however, not a new recession.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4--An eighty-two-state conference tentatively approved today the establishment of an international agency to promote the peaceful use of atomic energy. But the representatives of the members of the United Nations and affiliated agencies continued to debate the agency's precise powers and functions.
