A 16-year-old boy who was crippled when his mother burned his hand eight years ago for stealing pennies from her purse was arraigned yesterday on charges of grand larceny and felonious assault.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 4 --The Labor party criticized today the Government's colonial policies. At the same time it outlined its own proposals for the eventual termination of British colonialism.

HONG KONG, Oct. 4--President Sukarno of Indonesia told Chinese Communist leaders yesterday that his nation of 82,000,000 people supported the struggle to overthrow the Nationalist regime of Gen. Chiang Kai-shek, ...
RETURNING from several successful gallery exhibi tions and a stay for painting in Europe, Frederick Franck is showing his most recent work at the Passedoit Gallery, 121 East Fifty-seventh Street.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 4-- Gov. George M. Leader of Pennsylvania by-passed the State Legislature today and announced that most of the "top echelon people" in the state's mental health program would be put under civil service this month.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 4--After twenty-five years of lobbying to block construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway, the United Mine Workers decided today that its members would benefit from the project after all.

Northrop Aircraft, Inc., Hawthorne, Calif., has proposed a merger with the Vertol Aircraft Corporation of Morton, Pa. Whitley C. Collins, Northrop president, and Don R. Berlin, chairman and president of Vertol, made the announcement yesterday.
An increase in refined sugar prices was announced yesterday by two major refiners. A third company said that it expected to increase prices next month.

YOU could almost sniff the excitement last night in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art even before Leopold Stokowski came on stage to conduct the Symphony of the Air in a program of four orchestral premieres.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 --From Wall Street to Hollywood rumors are gaining momentum about a contemplated amalgamation of studio facilities to effect greater operating economies.
Theodore W. Kheel yesterday became impartial arbitrator for unions and employers in all public transportation here.
JACKSON, Mich., Oct. 4 (AP)-- Three official investigations were started today into the collapse of a partly completed office building that took the lives of ten workmen.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits drew a battle line last night between himself and Mayor Wagner on how to win a better life for Americans.
The world series went into a state of suspended animation yesterday as rain washed out the second game between the Yankees and Dodgers at Ebbets Field.
Mayor Wagner yesterday accused the Eisenhower Administration of "criminal negligence" and "inexcusable cowardice" in not approving an international convention against genocide.
Harvard University, in a protest against racial segregation in sports, has canceled plans to send its varsity basketball team into the South this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The issue which candidates declare to be fundamental to the popular choice on Election Day is not necessarily accepted as that by the voters. This has often been demonstrated in our political history.
John W. Conway, former assistant chief inspector of the Police Department, died Wednesday in Brooklyn Hospital at the age of 77. He had resided at 421 Avenue C, Brooklyn, until recently.

Times Square now has its own art gallery and, typically, it's on a billboard.

A YOUNG Canadian representative of a small but flourishing abstract school, Andre Jasmin, is having his first one-man exhibition in the United States at the Collector's Gallery, 49 West Fifty-third Street.
A machine that combines a roll of paper and a tankful of milk or cream to turn out filled cartons of either in a single operation was put on display yesterday.
The D'Arcy Advertising Company resigned yesterday as advertising agency on the Packard account of the StudebakerPackard Corporation, effective Nov. 1.
A 3-for-2 split of common stock of the Trane Company, manufacturer of air conditioning and heating equipment, was announced yesterday by D.C. Minard, president.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4--A half century is apt to pass before nuclear power usurps the present role of coal and oil in this country, the American Mining Congress was told today.

LONDON, Oct. 4--The newly formed Suez Canal Users Association agreed informally today that its operating budget for the first three months would amount to approximately 50,000 ($140,000).

The smaller banks in New York seem to be getting a bigger share of deposits.

IF Don Newcombe is a little arm-weary today, it probably is because of the fact that he pitched a tough ball game on Wednes day night. At least he thinks he pitched one, although the details were slightly vague to him yesterday. It was done in his sleep and therefore doesn't show in his record.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4-- Ethel Waters, Phil Harris and Cesar Romero have joined the cast of "Manhattan Tower." The National Broadcasting Company musical tribute to New York is due to be staged as a spectacular on Oct. 27.
A capacity gathering attended the Velvet Ball last night in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria in behalf of the Recreation Service for the Children of Bellevue.

Four players from this section's lesser football powers have won berths on the Eastern College Athletic Conference's first weekly All-East team.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Vice President Richard M. Nixon renewed tonight his campaign plea for the re-election of President Eisenhower to assure peace, prosperity and progress.

Dictators are notoriously happy when little or no attention is paid to them abroad, at least in the democratic countries. Since they impose a press censorship it is, in any event, hard to get news out of their countries.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island, Oct. 4--It seemed like a good day to rack up in front of a fire and reflect upon the relation of man to nature, but there are people around here who are not reflective types.
Interest in the Oct. 17 performance of "The Reluctant Debutante" for the benefit of the New York Committee of the Menninger Foundation is indicated by the large list of sponsors reported.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Saturday totaled 831,438 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
PARIS, Oct. 4--A rise in American private investment in Europe was forecast today by G. Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in an address to the American Club of Paris.

BERN, Switzerland, Oct. 5 (AP) --Switzerland's Minister of Economic Affairs said today that "exaggerated protectionist measures" to shield American watch manufacturers were "casting a shadow" on relations between Switzerland and the United States.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 5--The Labor party urged the Government today to safeguard the ailing textile industry by restricting the import of yarn and cloth.
Gopilal Sharma, soft-spoken student of Gandhi's gentle philosophy, arrived in town late Thursday with his demure 16year-old daughter Chandra.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island, Oct. 5-- This was a perfect day for hunting Hungarian partridges --bright, sunny, mild, with a steady wind to help the dogs find birds. So three hunters went out and killed ten pheasants without ever seeing a Hungarian feather.

MIAMI, Oct. 5 (UP)--Halfback Johnny Bookman intercepted three errant Boston College passes tonight and returned one for an 82-yard touchdown to pace Miami's 27-6 victory over the Eagles before a crowd of 37,381 in the Orange Bowl.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5--The Soviet Government has ordered fourteen industrial plants to adopt a new wage and output quota system that is expected to provide a pattern for the country's first basic wage reform in thirty-three years.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 5 --A new approach to the diagnosis and treatment of mental disorders was reported today by a young research biochemist of the Nobel Institute here.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 5-- The release from a mental hospital of George K. Churchill, 60year-old heir to a large fortune, was ordered today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 5--The police used tear gas to break up an anti-Government demonstration here today by several hundred students. The demonstration took place despite severe measures taken by the Government against strikers and the enforcement of state of siege regulations.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 5-- West German wage earners received today an across-the-board tax cut averaging 10 per cent.

Everybody was a hero in the Dodgers' clubhouse after yesterday's trouncing of the Yankees. Don Newcombe, who hardly filled a heroic role, either during or after the game, was not there. Newk had departed not long after Yogi Berra had knocked him out with his second-inning grand-slam homer.
Don Newcombe, smarting over his early knockout by the Yankees, became involved in an altercation with a parking lot attendant on his departure from Ebbets Field at 3:10 P.M. yesterday.

Capt. Piero Calamai, master of the, Italian liner Andrea Doria, was cross-examined yesterday about her navigation, engine-room and wireless logs. They have been missing since the collision with the Swedish liner Stockholm. He testified that they went down with the Doria.

The Jefferson School of Social Science, which as been listed as a Communist front organization, said yesterday that its enrollment for the fall term had slumped below 400, the lowest is its twelve-year existence.

A concert, performance of Handel's opera "Julius Caesar" will be given tomorrow night by the American Opera Society, Arnold U. Gamson conducting.

ALL far-thinking fashion women please note: herewith the goods on neat season's styles. The Fashion Group, an organization composed of every woman who is any woman in the fashion world, met this week to seriously look at just-off-the-loom spring fabrics.
The American premiere of the "The Tempest" by Frank Martin, Swiss composer, will be given Thursday evening by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center.
The marine division of the Metals Trades Council and the twelve-member Ship Shore Contractors Association reached agreement yesterday on terms for a new three-year working agreement.
Cotton futures moved 7 points up to 16 off yesterday in moderate volume on the New York Cotton Exchange. Only the spot month showed a gain.

Requests to found new associations or to form limited programs have come to the Young Women's Christian Association from sixty-three new communities. The national board diclosed this expanding interest yesterday at the end of the week-long semi-annual board meeting held at 600 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--The Secretary of the Navy overturned today a ruling by a general court-martial that S/Sgt. Matthew C. McKeon be dismissed from the Marine Corps. Secretary Charles S. Thomas also reduced the recommended sentence of nine months at hard labor to three, and canceled the $270 fine.

The Wheatley Stable's 2-year-old colt Bold Ruler made his seventh start yesterday and won for the sixth time. In the role of 9-to-10 favorite, he led home eight other nominees for next Saturday's Futurity in a six-furlong sprint through Belmont Park's Widener chute.
ALBANY, Oct. 5--The State Secretary of State's office ruled both the Socialist Labor and Sociatist Workers parties off the Nov. 6 ballot today.

Although he has not found a job as yet, James Everett Gordon has found many new friends. Two weeks ago Mr. Gordon was discharged as an auto washer in a Sturgis, Ky., garage. He had held the, $55-a-week position for seven years.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 6--All parties appeared in agreement here today that the Government of Honduras would win at least two-thirds of the seats in the National Constituent Assembly in tomorrow's election.

Who are these independent voters? How many are there? Do they really decide the election outcome?

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 6--New York State voters were urged by Governor Harriman today to approve the $500,000,000 highway bond issue and to vote "yes" on the middle-income housing program when they go to the polls on Election Day.

The answer lies in the fact that a landscape plant often receives inconsistent, improper care, while a plant in its natural surroundings is benefited by almost ideal cultural conditions.

Illness, outgrowing the parts and change of voice usually are unavoidable problems in such undertakings.

ACCRA, Gold Coast. IN the open-air night clubs where the people of Accra, black and white together, dance the West African highlife with tribal delight, one hears a song that goes: "Been-to, carful, fridgeful, jagwah." Then, continuing the beat that is a cross between calypso and samba rhythms, comes a line in the true vernacular tongue meaning: "These are the people."

PARIS. THE great retrospective ex hibition of the work of Henri Matisse at the National Museum of Modern Art, is the first large scale homage paid in France to the painter since his death in November, 1954. It brings together about a hundred examples and will Be current for at least two months.

Wall Street forecasts of the market future have seldom varied more than at present. On one side are the most optimistic predictions that stock prices will stay for some months in a range close to present levels and eventually break out on the top side, as "normal values" continue to rise.

A temporary injunction suspending a tariff schedule covering truck loading and unloading on piers has been denied to four trucking companies. District Judge David J. Edelstein denied the injunction in Federal Court last week.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) --Henry H. Laskau of New York retained his crown today by winning the senior national Amateur Athletic Union 15-kilometer walk in 1 hour 12 minutes 40 seconds. His time unofficially broke the American record of 1:14:36 set by John Knackstedt in 1934.

GIOVANNI PORIO came to the United States from Amantea, a fishing village on the Tyrrhenian Sea in Calabria, thirty-five years ago, when he was 14 years old and untutored. He was one of a group herded from small places in Italy by a padrone.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7 (AP)-- Mary Lena Faulk of Thomasville, Ga., fired a 7-under-par 69 today to win the $5,000 Heart of America women's golf tournament with a fifty-four-hole total of 214. It was her first major tournament victory in two years.

MADISON, Ind., Oct. 7 (AP)-- Miss U.S.I, piloted by Fred Alter of Detroit, roared away from the field early in both heats today to win the Governor's Cup race for Unlimited Class hydroplanes. Miss Wayne won the first heat yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 7--V.K. Krishna Menon, India's Minister without Portfolio, arrived here today after talks with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt on the dispute over Suez. He refused to make any comment about his mediation activities or his plans for further trips.

A Twentieth Century version of the Last Supper was unveiled yesterday at a Long Island church participating in World-wide Communion Sunday.

SENDAI, Japan, Oct. 7 (AP) --Shoji Rogake of Japan today neared the world record in the hop, step and jump with a leap of 54 feet inch. The 23-yearold paper company employe's leap was only 3 1/8 inches short ...

LONDON, Oct. 7--Support is growing here for the British Government's proposal to join the Western European nations in a common market. The project would constitute a major change in Britain's traditional policy of aloofness from European affairs.
At long-suffering last, Pennsylvania won a football game on Saturday for the first time since 1953, and the longest current losing streak of any major college eleven was broken.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7--Adlai E. Stevenson was met at Chicago Municipal Airport by Mayor Richard Daley and about 300 supporters. Before driving to Libertyville Mr. Stevenson called upon Cardinal Stritch of the Chicago Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church.

BRESSANONE, Italy, Oct. 7 --Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of large bonfires on the mountain tops hereabouts repeatedly have lighted up the peaceful valleys of the Upper Adige at night this summer and fall.
Alfred Iddles, president of Babcock Wilcox Co., has been elected president of the Atomic Industrial Forum, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Writing in a Catholic periodical, a Protestant layman has criticized the architecture of Roman Catholic churches in the United States as being "an Old Farmer's Almanack of styles."

Turkey seems destined to play in increasingly important role in the world oil picture. The friendly attitude of her Government toward the West and its liberal petroleum law lead to that conclusion among oil executives.

LONDON, Oct. 7--Prime Minister Eden is expected to return tomorrow after having spent three days in University College Hospital here with a severe cold.
ATHENS, Oct. 7 (Reuters)-- George V. Allen, new United States Ambassador to Greece, arrived here by air last night. He will present his credentials to King Paul Friday.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 7--A Royal Air Force man was killed today and another was wounded in a rebel ambush near Famagusta, in eastern Cyprus. A police station under construction at Akhna, between Famagusta and Larnaca, was damaged by time-bombs.

When the 1956 baseball season started, Thomas Virgil Sturdivant 2d was probably the least likely Yankee to become a world series hero. In fact, for a couple of months it was touch and go whether he even would remain a Yankee.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) --America's domestic and foreign waterborne commerce exceeded 1,000,000,000 tons for the first time in history last year, the Army engineers announced this week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 7--Most of the foreign ministers in New York for the Security Council session on the Suez crisis had no opportunity to relax in today's pleasant weather. Official chores kept them hotelbound and their telephone lines busy.

LEONARD BERNSTEIN opened the fifth season of "Omnibus" last night with an absorbing lecture on the evolution of American musical comedy. What a pity there wasn't just a little more entertainment to go with his academic treatise.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Oct. 7 --The M.D. Valentine Fire Brick Company plant here was destroyed by fire this morning. Damage to the nation's oldest maker of insulating fire brick was estimated by W.H. Peterson Jr., general manager, at $1,000,000.
Dominick Dominick, members of the New York Stock Exchange will open a branch today in the Socony Mobil Building at Lexington Avenue and Fortysecond Street. Mason B. Starring 3d is manager.

The Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation has announced that it planned to have a third electric generating unit at the Danskammer Point Stream Station in Newburgh, N.Y., in operation by the fall of 1959.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP)-- Senator William F. Knowland chided Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today for having made public a staff report of a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on disarmament. Mr. Humphrey, Minnesota Democrat, heads the subcommittee.
Modern home lighting techniques will be explained by Richard Kelly, lighting expert, at an illustrated lecture tomorrow.

Cardinal Spellman presided and Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly pontificated yesterday at a mass of thanksgiving marking the forty-sixth anniversary of the consecration of St. Patrick's Cathedral. Bishop Flannelly is administrator of the church.

Igor V. Kurchatov has announced on behalf of the Soviet Academy of Sciences that his Government will build at a cost of hundreds of millions of rubles a ten-billion electronvolt accelerator or atom smasher.

PARIS, Oct. 7 (Reuters)-- Italy's 4-year-old Ribot, today was acclaimed Europe's horse of the century when he won the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe-- richest turf event in Europe-- for the second year in a row.

Ricci-Tavi, the 2-to-5 favorite in the $6,000 New Dorp at Belmont yesterday, had to hustle to get home a neck ahead of Gold Bell II.

Thomas J. Culhane of Lansdowne, Pa., publicity director of the Catholic Relief ServicesNational Catholic Welfare Conference, died yesterday at Providence Hospital in Washington. His age was 58.

Margaret Sullavan ended a three-day mystery last night about her whereabouts and explained why she failed to appear for a television performance last Monday night.

In fact, the last episodes of a spine-tingling serial, that had been rivaling "The Perils of Pauline" in suspense, flickered fitfully to its foreordained conclusion. At the close, the Yankees were embracing the world championship once again. It's an old plot, but it's still serviceable.
